Visakhapatnam MP M Sribharat underlined the need for setting up more commercial complexes, office buildings and hotels in the city. Naredco national president Haribabu shared that property shows were organised in AP, Telangana and Maharashtra, so far.

Naredco State president Chakradhar in his inaugural address said that the support of the State government was helping in the growth of the real estate sector.

--eom

title: Russia finds LGBTQ travel agent guilty of extremism after suicide
content:
A Moscow court on Friday (November 14, 2025) found an LGBTQ travel agent who had killed himself in custody a year ago guilty of extremism, as Russia increasingly targets individuals it says undermine "traditional" values.

The posthumous ruling came a year after 48-year-old Andrei Kotov was found dead in his cell in a Moscow pre-trial detention centre.

Russia has heavily targeted the LGBTQ community under President Vladimir Putin, and Friday's ruling against somebody who had died a year earlier is seen as a particularly symbolic example of how zealous the crackdown is.

Kotov, who ran a travel company called Men Travel, had said he was beaten by 15 men when he was arrested in November 2024.

The Moscow Golovinsky court found him guilty of taking part in "extremist activity" as well as using underage people for pornography, the independent Mediazona website reported from inside the court.

His lawyer had said in December 2024 that Kotov's body was found in his cell and that investigators told her he died by suicide.

Rights groups have accused authorities of using the case as a show trial, not dropping it after his death to scare LGBTQ people.

In November 2024, Kotov described his arrest in court: "Fifteen people came to me at night, beat me, were punching me in the face."

Mr. Putin has for years denounced anything that goes against what he calls "traditional family values" as un-Russian and influenced by the West.

In 2023, Russia's Supreme Court banned what it called the "international social LGBT movement" as an "extremist organisation".

Human Rights Watch has said that the ruling "opened the floodgates for arbitrary prosecutions of individuals who are LGBT or perceived to be, along with anyone who defends their rights or expresses solidarity with them".

Russia has never been a hospitable environment for LGBTQ people, but has become far more dangerous since Moscow's Ukraine offensive, which massively accelerated the country's hardline conservative turn.

title: Palaniswami greets Modi, Nitish Kumar, Amit Shah for NDA’s victory in Bihar Assembly poll
content:
All India Anna Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (AIADMK) general secretary Edappadi K. Palaniswami on Monday greeted Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Bihar Chief Minister Nitish Kumar, and Union Minister for Home Affairs Amit Shah for the victory of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) in the Bihar Assembly election. In a post on his social media handle, he said the mandate reaffirmed the people’s trust in the alliance’s “collective leadership and commitment to stability and development.”

He added that people of the northern State had given a “fitting response” to the Congress-led INDIA (Indian National Developmental, Inclusive Alliance) bloc, “rejecting its falsehoods and attempts to undermine the institutions of democracy.”

title: Respond decisively to thwart Mekedatu reservoir project, says farmers’ association leader
content:
Chief Minister M.K. Stalin should respond decisively to Karnataka’s move to construct a reservoir in Mekedatu and ensure that the 50-year struggle of the lower riparian State to secure its fair share of Cauvery water is not in vain, P.R. Pandian, president, Coordination Committee of All Farmers Associations of Tamil Nadu, said in Coimbatore on Friday.

Mr. Pandian faulted the State Government for having moved against the Karnataka government in the Supreme Court rather than taking on the Jal Sakthi Ministry, Cauvery Water Regulation Committee, and Cauvery Water Management Authority for having accepted the dam proposal from the upper riparian State.

Mr. Pandian cited the apex court’s earlier stand that the verdict of the Cauvery Water Disputes Tribunal on the share of water for Tamil Nadu could not be appealed against and would be deemed final. This has been published in the Central Government Gazette.

“The water-sharing formula specified by the Tribunal is already a settled issue between the two States. With this being the case, Karnataka has no right to construct any new dam. The Chief Minister, rather than the Water Resources Minister, has to respond to Karnataka on the issue to gain National-level visibility,” Mr. Pandian contended. The State government has to appeal against the Supreme Court’s remark that Tamil Nadu’s challenge against the Central Water Commission’s directive to prepare the Detailed Project Report (DPR) for the project was “premature”.

He warned that acquiescing to Karnataka’s plan would cause desertification of 28 lakh acres in Tamil Nadu, and block water availability for 22 districts.

“Tamil Nadu’s food grains production will be hit hard,” Mr. Pandian cautioned, adding: “In the event of the Tamil Nadu government failing to respond appropriately to Karnataka, farmers’ associations in the State will convene an all-party meeting and take the next course of action.”

title: State hasn’t transferred murder investigation records to CBI, Armstrong’s wife alleges in SC
content:
The Supreme Court on Friday orally asked Porkudi, widow of slain BSP Tamil Nadu president K. Armstrong, to file an application recording her allegation that the State of Tamil Nadu is not handing over the probe papers to the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) despite a direction from the apex court.

Appearing before a Bench headed by Justice J.K. Maheshwari, senior advocate R. Basant, advocates Rahul Shyam Bhandari and G. Priyadarshini, representing Ms. Porkudi, submitted that the Sessions Court had released the accused on bail citing lack of records. “Your Lordships specifically directed that the CBI investigation must go on. Now, they are not handing over the papers to the CBI. The lower court is releasing the accused left, right, and centre on the ground that the papers are not there,” Mr. Basant submitted.

On October 10, the apex court had stayed a Madras High Court to quash the chargesheet in the case. It, however, had not intervened with the High Court’s direction to transfer the investigation to the CBI.

Senior advocate Siddharth Luthra and advocate Sabarish Subramanium appeared for the State, and advocate Yogesh Kanna represented Armstrong’s brother K.V. Immanuel.

The State had moved the apex court against the HC decision to quash the chargesheet. Mr. Luthra had further objected to the transfer of the probe to the CBI, arguing that it could not be done as a matter of routine by High Courts. He had submitted in October that the HC had been “swayed by extraneous considerations, including media narratives and prevailing political circumstances, ordering for de-novo probe and transfer of case to the CBI.

Armstrong was murdered at Perambur in Chennai by assailants, who approached him as food delivery agents, on July 5, 2024. A Special Investigation Team headed by the Joint Commissioner of Police had been constituted .The chargesheet submitted by the State Police had invoked multiple provisions of Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, the Explosives Act, Armstrong Act, forensic reports, witness statements and other supporting documents.

title: Roadside ad space increases, zone-based rules for bidders introduced
content:
Bengaluru’s advertising landscape is set for a major overhaul, with the State government releasing a new draft that increases the volume of advertising permitted along the city’s roads. The draft will introduce a stricter zone-based system, and standardise how rights are assigned to bidders for every road, circle and notified stretch.

In the revised draft, the government has allowed more advertising space on most Bengaluru roads. Earlier, rules had fixed lower limits—for example, 800 sq. ft of ads were allowed for every 200 m on 18 to 24 m roads, 1,000 sq. ft on 24–30 m roads, 1,100 sq. ft on 30–60 m roads and 1,200 sq. ft on the widest roads. The new draft increases these to 1,000 sq. ft, 1,200 sq. ft, 1,500 sq. ft and 1,600 sq. ft respectively. A major earlier restriction, a cap on how long the ads could be horizontally, has now been completely removed. The new draft does away with previous layout restrictions that controlled how ads could be arranged.

The new draft also revises how much advertisers must pay per sq. ft. Earlier, low-value stretches started at ₹50 per sq. ft (for ₹3000 per sq. ft.) and the rates climbed up to ₹90 (₹40000 per sq. ft.) for the highest-value areas. In the new draft, the starting band now begins at ₹45 (₹4000 per sq. ft), and the highest band tops out at ₹75 (₹25000 per sq. ft).

The draft retains the basic rule that the bidder who wins rights for any road stretch, circle or area can put up advertisements anywhere within that zone on behalf of clients. However, the rules governing private properties have been rewritten. Previously, the erstwhile BBMP bylaws imposed steep penalties on B-Register properties and sites without Khata, including double additional property tax, and in some cases full property tax plus double penalty until a Khata was obtained.

The new draft removes these clauses and said that no commercial advertisement can be put up on any property that does not have a valid Khata, unless the owner first converts it to an A-Khata in accordance with the law. The corporation will continue to have the power to immediately remove hoardings on properties without Khata or those missing from the property-tax register.

The rules also clarify that paying advertisement fees to the corporation does not give advertisers any right to enter or use private or government property on their own, permissions and commercial terms must be independently negotiated with each property owner. These payments to property owners are separate from the advertisement fees owed to the corporation.

The draft also redefines how advertisements inside government-owned premises will be handled. Earlier, railways, BMRCL, KSRTC, BMTC, and PSUs retained revenue from ads inside their campuses, and certain metro-related revenues were shared between BBMP and BMRCL. The new draft continues to let these agencies tender and retain income from advertisements inside their facilities, but removes the cross-sharing arrangements. Metro pillars, stations and all other BMRCL structures remain fully outside the bidder’s rights even if they fall within the bidder’s assigned stretch, and BMRCL will tender these separately.

title: Triple life term for man in ‘honour’ killing case
content:
The Principal District and Sessions Court awarded triple life term to a 50-year-old man for killing his 28-year-old son for marrying a Dalit woman. The daughter-in-law survived the attack, while the mother of the accused, who had intervened to protect the couple was also hacked to death.

The verdict was pronounced by Judge V.R. Latha late Friday evening, as the accused man Dandapani stood with folded arms.

The victim D. Subhash, from a most backward community and his wife Anusuya (25), from Adidravidar caste, had been married barely for 20 days on April 15, 2023, when their life was upended.

Subhash and Anusuya’s family were neighbours and friends in Tiruppur. Anusuya, a MSc Chemistry graduate, was working in a garments company in Tirupur, while Subhash’s father was a tailor. Anusuya was also a close friend of Subhash’s sister, and the two families were neighbours and friends, who had comingled.

Subhash, an MBA graduate, was living with his grandmother in Uthangarai in Krishnagiri. The duo got familiar with each during his visits to meet his family in Tiruppur and fell in love. In early 2023, Anusuya’s parents started to look prospective grooms for her, when Subhash informed his family of their relationship.

While the women of Subhash’s family knew of her caste, the accused Dandapani was unaware until that time. He had objected to their relationship. Subhash went ahead and married Anusya on March 27, 2023. The couple had temporarily moved base to the neighbouring Thirupathur district.

Dandapani had asked his mother Kannammal (65), who had raised Subhash, to invite the couple to her home on April 14, Tamil New Year’s day, promising rapprochement. Subhash and Anusuya arrived at his grandmother’s house on April 14. That night, the couple had slept inside the house, while Kannammal and Dandapani, who reached Uthangarai that evening slept outside the house. Just before dawn, at about 5 a.m., Dandapani went into the house and hammered his sleeping son to death.

He grabbed Anusuya and attacked her with a sickle, while Kannammal, who had woken up, and intervened to stop Dandapani from his murderous spree sustained grievous injuries and died on the spot. Anusaya had pretended to be dead to survive the attacker, who had returned twice to check her breath. The second time, Dandapani fixed her dishevelled clothes before leaving the crime scene. Later, she had dragged herself through a graveyard, before someone found her. She was rescued and taken to Uthangarai government hospital and later to Dharmapuri and Salem government hospitals.

The accused Dandapani had fled and was arrested near Theerthamalai, near Harur, in Dharmapuri, where he had attempted to slit his throat.

On Friday, Judge Latha sentenced Dandapani to triple life sentences for the two murders each and one under the Scheduled Castes/ Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act. He was also sentenced to 10-year term under Section 307 of the IPC( Attempt to murder). The accused was also slapped fines of ₹8,000 and all the sentences will be served concurrently.

title: A ray of hope for all ‘honour’ killing victims and survivors, says Anusuya
content:
“This verdict is a ray of hope not just for me, but for all the honour killing victims and survivors,” said Anusuya as tears streamed down her face. “I had not imagined for this to happen so soon within two-and-a-half years.”

She had witnessed the brutal killing of her husband, survived a murderous attack that had almost severed her limbs. Ms. Anusuya had since rebuilt her life with the support of the Tamil Nadu Untouchability Eradication Front (TNUEF) and her family consisting of a mother and younger brother.

Ms. Anusuya underwent nine plastic surgeries, multiple surgeries to her head and neck; studied B.Ed with the help of TNUEF, and has stood her ground through each hearing of the trial. “The first thing she asked us when we reached out was that she wanted to study B.Ed. We admitted her in Annamalai University, says P. Suganthi, general secretary of TNUEF. “The only time she didn’t attend classes was when she was undergoing surgeries.”

Two months ago, Anusuya did receive a string of text messages from her former friend and Subhash’s sister, pleading with her to save Subhash’s father by backing off from her testimonies. “I wasn’t fighting for justice just for me, but for Subhash and his grandmother. “I wanted to live with him, but that did not happen. Today, on the day of the verdict, I asked Subhash to be with me, to be my support.”

“Had it not been for TNUEF, comrades Samuvel Raj, Suganthi, Mohana, Valentina, my mother and brother and countless others, I would not have known what to do,” said Ms. Anusuya

Ms. Anusuya chose to stay away from the court complex and instead waited at the CPI (M)’s office. She hugged Ms. Suganthi, as she entered and wept inconsolably.

Historic verdict

“This is a historic verdict,” said P. Suganthi, general secretary of TNUEF, that led the fight for justice, by first reaching out to her at the Salem Government Medical College Hospital, where she underwent prolonged treatment.

“We had met the District Collector twice at that time asking for a job for Ms. Anusuya. But, since victim Subhash was not a Dalit, the SC/ST (POA) Act that orders a government job, a house and rehabilitation measures would not apply to Ms. Anusuya. That is why we demand a Special Act to deal with ‘honour’ killing, where cases like Ms. Anusuya, a Dalit, who survives an attack cannot go uncovered,” she said.

title: Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan Bangalore Kendra celebrates diamond jubilee in 2025
content:
The Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan, popularly known as Bhavans, was started in 1938 by KM Munshi. Its reach as a cultural movement soon spread in the fields of literature, performing arts and education as well as spiritual learning. The Bangalore Kendra of Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan began in 1965, and the chapter commenced their diamond jubilee celebrations with Santhavani.

Santhavani was inaugurated by film director TS Nagabharana and columnist Narahalli Balasubramanya, with devotional films in different languages and a book exhibition. As part of their diamond jubilee celebrations as many as 60 programmes have been planned for the following year.

The devotional film festival, which concluded on November 14, will be followed by Santhavani’s Segment Two with lectures, music, dance, drama, choirs and panel discussions scheduled from November 15 to 21.

“Our founder Munshiji, whom we refer to as Kulapati, chose the name Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan because he envisioned it as an institution without boundaries of geography, caste, religion, politics or language,” says KG Raghavan, chairman, Bhavans, Bangalore Kendra. “That is why it is called Bharatiya Vidya (Indian education). In keeping with this, he chose a tagline from the Rig Veda, that translates to let noble thoughts come to us from every side.”

Munshi was a prominent freedom fighter, lawyer, politician and prolific writer. He was on the committee which drafted the Indian Constitution, and served as the Governor of Uttar Pradesh. “India required an institution to foster value-based education and culture that would share ‘vidya’ or knowledge without barrier; Munshi’s passion sowed the seeds for Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan,” Raghavan says.

Talking about Bhavan’s e-book, The History and Culture of Indian People, Raghavan says, “Munshi was a visionary who undertook this mammoth project. Comprising 11-volumes, it took as many as 100 reputed historians nearly 32 years to write and compile it, labouring from 1944 to 1976. It contains nearly 10,000 pages of the nation’s history makers and their accomplishments.”

Later, the Kannada version of the book was undertaken by 60 translators under an advisory committee headed by AV Narasimha Murthy.

Dispelling darkness

The ongoing 60th special was curated by the Bhavans team in Bengaluru to integrate knowledge, wisdom and culture in an effort to bring light to areas of ignorance. HN Suresh, director, Bhavans Bangalore Kendra, says, “Today, Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan has 365 centres in India and 10 centres abroad. We publish thousands of books aside from the ones by Munshi who wrote 150 titles in English, Gujarati and Hindi, and publications in regional languages.”

Suresh goes on to say, value-based education is imparted in 165 Bhavans-affiliated schools across India. “Our association with the Infosys Foundation sees regular cultural programmes throughout the nation.”

Bhavans has brought out a special booklet with messages of hope and appreciation by world leaders and cultural icons who have been associated with the institution. Among them is His Holiness the Dalai Lama, who has said,”Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan makes a special effort to foster religious harmony with an emphasis on sarva dharma samabhav or equal respect for all religions, which I too, wholeheartedly support.”

Jnanapeeth awardee writer UR Ananthamurthy has also penned a few words in the same booklet: “If I have an education in Indian culture, a large part of it is from Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan’s books. At the level of book reading, Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan decolonised India and made us respect ourselves. There are great people in the world whom European colonisers not only cowed into political submission, but also made them forget their past. That could never happen in India, and we owe it to people like Munshi and Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan.”

Segment Two

Santhavani’s Segment Two includes devotional talks, discourses, presentations, music and dance recitals, and panel discussions that cover a gamut of reformist movements and philosophies of all faiths prevalent in India. Former Karnataka chief minister Veerappa Moily, scholar Shatavadhani R Ganesh, former ambassador to UNESCO Chiranjiv Singh will be part of the inaugural function on November 15.

Progressive reform movements, socio-religious efforts, and devotional traditions such as the Natha Parampara and Saints from Orissa are some of the topics that will be discussed. The socio-cultural influence of the Haridasas will be followed by a dance-drama on vachanakars on November 16. Other interesting presentations include the philosophical doctrines of Vallabhacharya Sampradaya, the Tattvapada tradition and a talk on Guru Bani.

“The Evangelist church choir will perform at the evening session on November 18. On November 20, Peter Machado, the Archbishop of Bangalore, will speak in the afternoon, followed by a ‘Message of Islam’ presented by Umar Teekay of Teekays Interior Solutions. This would be followed by a Carnatic music concert by Nithyashree Mahadevan,” says Suresh.

He adds that the concluding day of the festival will feature talks on Jainism and Buddhism and a musical on Ramanuja Vaibhavam. “The scope of Santhavani encompasses a wide range of presentations, both secular and scholarly,” he adds.

Santhavani will take place at Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan Bangalore Kendra till November 21. Entry free, but registration required on bhavankarnataka.com. Call 9845625899 for details

title: J&K L-G administration suspends police officer accused of thrashing senior official in Jammu
content:
Facing the threat of mass leave by bureaucrats, the Jammu and Kashmir administration on Friday (November 14, 2025) suspended an officer of Deputy Superintendent of Police (DSP) rank for allegedly thrashing an officer on duty.

In an order, the administration headed by the Lieutenant-Governor, which controls the J&K Police, suspended Sunil Singh, serving as the Sub Divisional Police Officer (SDPO), Gandhi Nagar, Jammu, “pending an inquiry”.

The order said the suspension was initiated under Rule 31(1) of the J&K Civil Services (Classification, Control & Appeal) Rules, 1956. “During the period of suspension, DSP Sunil Singh shall remain attached with the Police Headquarters, J&K,” it added.

On November 10, according to a letter by the Jammu and Kashmir Administrative Service (JKAS) officers to the L-G administration, the police officer along with his personal security officers, allegedly “assaulted, abused, and unlawfully detained Azhar Khan, a JKAS officer.” The JKAS officer serves as Block Development Officer, Nagrota, and as Nodal Officer (Transport) for Assembly Constituency 77 – Nagrota. Another official, Abbas Ali, was also reportedly assaulted during the episode, the officers alleged.

In a rare step, the JKAS officers threatened “mass casual leave in protest against the alleged assault and harassment of the officer”. It alleged that Mr. Khan was allegedly manhandled and later booked in a “false and fabricated FIR.”

“The incident has severely shaken the morale of officers engaged in crucial election responsibilities. Such conduct undermines the dignity and safety of civil officers performing statutory duties and raises serious concerns about institutional protection. In solidarity with their colleague, the officers have resolved to proceed on mass casual leave with immediate effect until strict action is taken against the “erring officer(s)” and mechanisms are put in place to prevent recurrence,” the letter said.

title: AIM@IISc releases dataset and advanced vision models for Indian urban traffic
content:
The AI for Integrated Mobility (AIM@IISc) initiative at the Indian Institute of Science (IISc) has announced the public release of UVH-26, a large-scale traffic image dataset along with a suite of fine-tuned object detection models tailored for Indian urban traffic conditions.

UVH-26 contains 26,646 high-resolution traffic images sourced from Bengaluru’s Safe City project and features 1.8 million bounding-box annotations across 14 India-specific vehicle classes, including two-wheelers, autorickshaws, light commercial vehicles, and buses.

According to a release, the dataset was curated through a nationwide Urban Vision Hackathon that involved more than 560 student volunteers, who contributed to a large crowdsourced annotation effort. High-quality consensus ground truth was generated using Majority Voting and STAPLE algorithms.

Alongside the dataset, AIM@IISc has released six state-of-the-art object detection models based on YOLOv11, DAMO-YOLO, and RT-DETRv2 architectures, fine-tuned specifically for Indian traffic scenes. These models show up to a 31.5% improvement in mAP@50:95 performance compared to COCO-trained baselines, demonstrating the importance of region-specific data for intelligent transportation systems.

The dataset and models have been made available on HuggingFace under open-source licences. Since their release on November 5, 2025, the UVH-26 resources have already recorded more than 1,500 downloads and are currently ranked as the top trending object detection models on the platform, indicating strong global interest in mobility-focused AI research from the Global South, said the release.

AIM@IISc has invited researchers, developers, students, and policymakers to explore and build upon UVH-26 to advance AI-enabled transportation solutions in emerging economies. The initiative focuses on the use of AI, data-driven methods, and digital twin platforms to tackle mobility challenges such as congestion, safety, and urban planning.

The release was made possible with support from the Bengaluru City Police and Bengaluru Traffic Police, who provided access to imagery from the Safe City project. Additional support came from IISc’s ARTPARK, the Kotak IISc AI-ML Centre, Capital One, and outreach partners including ACM India Council and IEEE India Council.

“India has always been data-poor for AI applications, especially in mobility, given the scale and complexity of Indian traffic. UVH-26 is a testament to how crowdsourced efforts by hundreds of engaged students can create high-quality datasets that rival global benchmarks. This shows the power of community-driven AI for solving local challenges. By making these datasets and model openly available, we aim to catalyse research, development and deployment of AI-driven traffic analytics for safer and smarter cities,” said Yogesh Simmhan, Associate Professor at CDS, IISc.

title: Advocate sentenced to 8-year rigorous imprisonment for ramming car into restaurant in Madurai
content:
The Fifth Additional District and Sessions Court in Madurai on Friday sentenced an advocate R. Karmegam to eight year rigorous imprisonment for ramming his sports utility vehicle (SUV) into a restaurant located on the bypass road, here, in 2016 over a dispute with the restaurant owner.

Judge R. Joseph Joy sentenced Karmegam to eight year rigorous imprisonment and imposed a fine of ₹10,000 on the advocate. The court acquitted Karmegam’s wife Nagamani and an associate Muthupillai of all charges.

The case of the prosecution is that there was a dispute between Karmegan and the restaurant owner. On April 23, 2016, Karmegam intentionally rammed his SUV into the restaurant causing damage to the glass doors and the wooden furniture. A few employees of the restaurant had sustained injuries in the incident.

Based on a complaint, the S.S. Colony police had registered a case against Karmegam, Nagamani and Muthupillai.

title: Bus crashes into a bus stop in Stockholm and causes fatalities, police say
content:
A double-decker bus crashed into a bus stop in Stockholm on Friday (November 14, 2025), causing fatalities and injuries, police said.

Police didn’t immediately give details of the number of victims, Swedish news agency TT reported. The cause of the crash wasn’t immediately clear.

Authorities were alerted to the crash at 3:23 p.m. on Friday (November 14, 2025). The bus stop that was rammed was on Valhallavägen, a street in the Swedish capital’s Östermalm district.

Emergency services said the bus was not in service and no passengers were on board, TT reported.

title: Swiggy moves from ORR to Whitefield for ‘better connectivity, bigger space’
content:
Online food and grocery delivery platform Swiggy will reportedly move from Bellandur to Whitefield in a few months.

According to insider sources, the company, which has been housed in Embassy Tech Village, will move to the new location as the contract in the current location has expired, and Whitefield was a preferred location due to metro connectivity.

“Our contract has come to an end. The new office has metro station right next door to it. So, it is going to be more convenient for employees. There is a lot more happening in Whitefield also socially; So, it was a preferred location shared by employees as well,” said the source.

The company refused to make official statements regarding the development.

Turning heads

The news of Swiggy’s move, which has been in Bellandur for six years, was quick to raise eyebrows as the development comes close on the heels of Blackbuck CEO Rajesh Kumar Yabaji announcing that the company would be moving out of ORR due to poor infrastructure.

“ORR (Bellandur) has been our ‘office + home’ for nine years, but it was getting very hard to continue. We have decided to move out. Average commute for my colleagues shot up to 1.5 plus hours one way. Roads are full of potholes and dust, coupled with the lowest intent to get them rectified. Don’t see any of this changing in the next five years,” Mr. Yabaji had written on X.

Bigger facility

However, sources at the Swiggy stressed that the online aggregator is making the move as it is in need of a bigger space and not due to infrastructural woes.

“We are moving to a bigger space with better connectivity,” they said.

The company, which was initially headquartered in Koramangala, currently has a total workforce of 7,431 (as of March 31, 2025), according to its latest annual report.

title: CPI, CPI(M) resolve dispute, LDF unity intact in Thrikkakara
content:
After day-long consultations at various levels of both the Communsit Party of India (Marxist) [CPI(M)] and the Communist Party of India (CPI) on Friday, the dispute between the two parties over the right to contest two wards was amicably settled, averting a threat to the unity of the Left Democratic Front (LDF) in Thrikkakara municipality.

On Thursday, the CPI had unilaterally declared candidates for four wards, accusing the CPI(M) of laying claim to two wards—Sahakarana Road and Health Centre—by encroaching on areas of its influence. It was finally agreed that the CPI would contest the Sahakarana Road ward and relinquish the Health Centre ward to the CPI(M). Additionally, the CPI has been allotted an extra seat, the Infopark ward. Thus, the party will now contest in seven wards compared to six in the previous election.

Talks were held at the State, district and local levels, both over phone and in person, throughout the day before a settlement was reached. With the imbroglio resolved, the Left Democratic Front (LDF) will announce all candidates for the 48 seats of Thrikkakara municipality on Saturday. Apart from the seven seats of the CPI, the other LDF constituents — RJD, NCP,and KC(S) — will contest in a seat each. The CPI(M) will contest in the remaining 38 seats.

The two LDF constituents had been at odds over the two wards, effectively stalling seat-sharing discussions in the municipality, which has traditionally been a United Democratic Front (UDF) stronghold. While the CPI claimed that these wards fell within its sphere of influence, the CPI(M) insisted on contesting in them based on winnability. Although the CPI(M) offered two alternative seats, the CPI argued that it had no viable chance in those wards. In the last election, the CPI had won two of the six seats it had contested in — Athani and Snehanilayam.

The CPI’s argument was that, following delimitation, a majority of votes from the Athani ward—considered its traditional stronghold—had shifted to the Health Centre ward, giving it a legitimate claim. In the case of Sahakarana Road, which absorbed the Mampillyparambu ward following delimitation, the CPI maintained that its entire vote base from the now-defunct ward had been merged into Sahakarana Road, entitling it to field a candidate there.

Even while unilaterally declaring candidates on Thursday, the CPI had left the door open for reconciliation, clarifying that fracturing LDF unity was not its agenda, and that it would revisit its decision if a resolution could be reached.

title: Shaw, Pai praise DKS for ‘rescuing the city’
content:
In a brick-to-bouquet move, Biocon chief Kiran Mazumdar-Shaw has showered praises on Deputy Chief Minister D.K. Shivakumar, terming his leadership key in “rescuing Bengaluru from collapsing under the weight of garbage, debris and potholes.”

“We are finally seeing visible change in cleaner foot paths n asphalted roads across the city. @DKShivakumar your leadership has been key in rescuing our city from collapsing under the weight of garbage debris n pot holes. Please continue to drive this important development. Credit is also due to @GBAChiefComm. Let’s build a worldclass city through collective civic responsibility @BPAofficial,” she wrote on her X handle.

Turn around

A day earlier, Industrialist Mohandas Pai thanked Mr. Shivakumar, Minister of Bengaluru Development, for his “leadership and drive.”

Quoting a post by the Minister who claimed to have finished white topping work on 39 key roads, he wrote on X, “Thank you DCM @DKShivakumar for your leadership and drive in getting this done. Look forward to make Bengaluru a truly global city with great mobility and ease of life for all citizens.”

The turnaround by the corporate leaders comes close on the heels of the GBA Chief Commissioner M. Maheshwar Rao claiming to have completed the filling of 18,000 potholes and after a prolonged war of words that started with an X post by Ms. Shaw criticising the city’s infrastructural issues.

Mr. Shivakumar who initially took a conciliatory tone, however, later criticised Ms. Shaw for ‘tarnishing the image of the State and the country’ by such social media posts.

In what seemed like a show of white flag, Ms. Shaw visited the Minister on the day of Deepavali, where, according to Mr. Shivakumar, ‘they had an engaging discussion on Bengaluru’s growth, innovation, and the path ahead for Karnataka’s growth story.”

The meeting

Mr. Shivakumar held a meeting with both Mr. Pai and Ms. Shaw after Deepavali, joined by Mr. Rao and other GBA officials. After the meeting, Mr. Shivakumar had said, “Entrepreneurs are our brothers and sisters.”

However, he added that they (entrepreneurs) should not “tarnish” the image of Bengaluru. “I have told them that their criticism will make international news. They have given good suggestions for Bengaluru,” he said.

Mr. Shivakumar also noted that the they had included entrepreneurs in advisory committees.

title: Madurai district police stand out in restoring lost mobile phones to owners
content:
Madurai district police have won laurels at State level in recovery of lost mobile phones in the past one year period ending on August 31, 2025.

While the district police have stood first among all districts with the highest recovery rate of 64%, Usilampatti police have bagged the third rank among all police stations in Tamil Nadu taking efforts for recovering the lost mobile phones.

Madurai district police record every complaint of mobile phone missing/lost under community service register (CSR) and make efforts to trace them by registering the mobile phone details in Central Equipment Identity Register (CEIR), a portal developed by Department of Telecommunication.

“However, for those mobile phones that are snatched or robbed, we do not use this procedure,” said Madurai District Superintendent of Police B.K. Arvind.

CEIR that operates based on the international Mobile Equipment Identity (IMEI) of mobile phones would track those phones.

Using the CEIR, the mobile phone lost/missing could be blocked for usage. “However, whenever another SIM card is inserted, the portal would trace it and alert the police,” Mr. Arvind said.

As and when a stolen/missing phone is switched on, the portal would identify it and send an alert to the police.

This portal can trace all the mobile phones irrespective of the mobile service provider across the country.

While technology has made tracking of missing phones easier, the recognition Madurai district police have got is for the human intervention in getting back the phones.

As soon as the portal alerts about tracing of the missing/lost phone along with the new mobile number (based on the new SIM card inserted), the police call the new user to inform him/her about the mobile phone being a lost/stolen property.

“Our men keep talking to them and make them hand it in person or send them to the police. This is where the sincerity in duty of the police makes the difference in early restoration of the lost/missing phone to the owner,” the SP said.

The SP said that tracing and restoring the every second mobile lost is a great achievement. On its part, Usilampatti police station had restored 89% of the lost/missing mobile phones to the owners in the same period.

Mr. Arvind said that value of a lost mobile phone is not just the market cost of the gadget. For, the phones have lot of data stored in it, like photographs, personal details, including bank details. Owners could also have sentimental attachments like it being their first phone or a gift, the SP said.

People only hope for better follow up by police that would help in higher percentage of recovery and restoration of phones to the owners in the coming days.

title: Three arrested for hunting barking deer
content:
Dindigul Forest Officials on Friday arrested three persons for hunting a barking deer (Indian muntjac) in Sirumalai hills in the district. The officials seized the meat and two single barrel country made guns that were used for hunting the deer.

Following a tip off, a team led by District Forest Officer Yogesh Kumar Meena arrested K. Perumal, A. Andisamy and C. Karthik from Thavasimadai. The three accused have been remanded in judicial custody and lodged in Dindigul prison.

title: Conclave on ‘globalising Indian thought’ concludes at IIMK
content:
The three-day Globalising Indian Thought (GIT) Conclave 2025 concluded at the Indian Institute of Management- Kozhikode (IIMK) on Friday.

The conclave that offered powerful reflections on healthcare, gender equity, and India’s evolving global influence was inaugurated by Anil D. Sahasrabuddhe, chairperson of the National Educational Technology Forum, along with Vikas Swarup, writer and former diplomat.

As many as 124 research submissions across academic papers, practice cases, concept notes, and posters were presented at the conclave on the theme of ‘3 Ws’ (Work, Women, and Worldview).

The three-day conclave featured eminent global voices and thought leaders, including Shishir Priyadarshi, president, Chintan Research Foundation, and Lalatiana Accouche, Seychelles High Commissioner to India, among others. The special highlights include a photo exhibition by artist Lalit Verma showcasing the cultural vibrancy of the Purna Mahakumbh Mela as well as expert panels exploring sustainability, work-place equality, and representation in public life.

The Best Paper Award was jointly presented to Priyankari for ‘Renewing temple-centric performing art traditions of Bhārat: sound, rhythm and geometry for contemporary well-being’ and to Vineetha Mathew for ‘Towards a conceptualisation of financial well-being for Indian women: the need for a new scale’.

The conclave concluded with a Bharatanatyam performance by Meenakshi Srinivasan.

title: British Airways operates special flight to celebrate two decades of service on Bengaluru-London route
content:
British Airways which is celebrating 20 years of flight service between Bengaluru and London operated a special anniversary flight from London Heathrow to Bengaluru, served entirely by Indian cabin crew.

The airline said that the special flight touched down early on Friday morning, which paid tribute to the airline’s enduring relationship with India and its commitment to delivering personalised service that resonates with the diverse communities it serves.

Bengaluru members

Among the crew were Bengaluru-based team members who also celebrated 20 years of service with the airline.

“Being part of British Airways for the past 20 years has been an incredible journey and seeing our Bengaluru route grow from its very first flight to what it is today fills me with great pride. I’ve had the privilege of serving thousands of customers whose stories have stayed close to my heart, we have grown with them and their families. Celebrating this milestone feels personal, it is not just about the flights, it is about the connections we have helped create between India and the U.K.,” said British Airways’ global cabin crew team leader, George Muthalaly.

Daily flights

Since launching flights to Bengaluru in 2005, British Airways now operates daily flights from Kempegowda International Airport to London Heathrow, offering seamless access to the airline’s hub and more than 190 onward destinations across 65 countries worldwide.

To celebrate the occasion, the airline has today launched a flash sale for customers booking flights between Bengaluru and London Heathrow. The sale includes up to 20% off fares in World Traveller and World Traveller Plus cabin, offering savings of up to ₹26,000.

title: Victory trophy for Hockey Men’s Junior World Cup arrives in Madurai
content:
The victory trophy for the 14th Hockey Men’s Junior World Cup arrived in Madurai district on Friday.

As Chief Minister M.K. Stalin officially unveiled the victory trophy on November 5, Deputy Chief Minister Udhayanidhi Stalin introduced the tournament mascot ‘Kangeyam’ bull and flagged off the State-wide tour of the world cup victory trophy at Mayor Radhakrishnan Hockey Stadium in Chennai on November 10.

As part of the tour, Madurai district administration accorded a grand welcome to the trophy on Madurai – Sivaganga Road and received it. The welcome ceremony featured various cultural performances, and a parade by over 300 students.

On Saturday, at 9 a.m. the trophy would be kept for public viewing at Meenakshi Sundareswarar Temple. It would then be taken along Kamarajar Salai, Theppakulam, Kuruvikaran Salai, Aavin Junction, and K.K. Nagar before reaching Dr. M.G.R stadium near Race Course.

Various programmes showcasing the Tamil culture and tradition, including folk arts, a parade by the police forces, Silambattam,Oyilattam, and cultural performances by school and college students, would take place.

In the evening, the victory trophy would be formally sent off to Theni district by the district administration.

The general public, students, youth, and athletes were requested by the district administration to participate with their families in this event to showcase Madurai’s cultural richness, hospitality, and passion for sports, thereby enhancing the sporting pride of Tamil Nadu.

title: Coimbatore Vizha takes off with sound, light, vintage cars, and more
content:
The 18th edition of Coimbatore Vizha, an initiative of the Young Indians (Yi) - Coimbatore chapter, took off on Friday with a car rally, light show, and a science and technology festival.

“Coimbatore Vizha gets better every year and celebrates the spirit of the city,” said V. Senthil Balaji, Karur MLA.

The Vizha has events for all age groups of people and in different sectors – arts, environment, industry, education, etc., said District Collector Pavankumar G. Giriyappanavar, at the inauguration of the 11-day Vizha.

Coimbatore is a place that accommodates all those who come here, be it for work or education, said Coimbatore City Police Commissioner A. Saravana Sundar.

Sky Dance, a projection mapping show, will be held in the evenings near the CODISSIA Trade Fair Complex on all the 11 days. It has a specially made 150-feet-long façade that comes alive with multiple colours, lights, motion, and sound telling the story of Coimbatore.

Over 37 industries, hospitals, and institutions are participating in the three-day Science and Technology show, and more than 70 exhibits from schools (including government schools) and colleges are on display.

The vintage and classical car show organised by the Rotary Coimbatore City saw participation of 48 vintage and classic cars.

Students spread awareness on rights and safety through a “Rally of Resilience” and the Parambariya Vizha had classical dance and Carnatic music performances.

title: Man robbed of gold chain after assault in Kumbalagodu
content:
A 47-year-old factory owner was allegedly assaulted and robbed of his 100 grams gold chain by a former employee in the Kumbalagodu Police Station limits on Thursday.

According to the complaint, the victim, Amar Narayana Swamy, who runs a Ganesh idol-manufacturing unit in Kanchanapura, was approached on November 13 by a 23-year-old accused, identified as Jayanth. The accused had briefly worked at Mr. Swamy’s factory in June 2025. Jayanth reportedly told the complainant that a BDA site was available for sale and offered to show it to him.

The two travelled in the complainant’s car to the Sulikere BDA Layout, where Jayanth showed him two vacant plots. While they were returning, the accused, who was seated in the back seat, allegedly lunged forward and tried to snatch the gold chain worn by the complainant. When the victim resisted, Jayanth allegedly attacked him with a knife, injuring his neck, face, shoulder, forehead, and head.

“Bleeding, the complainant got out of the vehicle and attempted to escape by climbing onto the back of a passing mini-lorry. The accused allegedly chased him, pulled him down, stabbed him again in the back, snatched the gold chain, and fled on a motorcycle,” said the police.

The Kumbalagodu Police have registered a case and are on the lookout for the accused.

title: Bihar Assembly elections 2025: BJP quelled discontent to ensure vote transfer among NDA allies
content:
Behind the BJP and the NDA’s stunning victory in the Bihar Assembly election is not just the overwhelming support of women, who came out in large numbers to vote and surpassed men in many seats, but also the hard grind of micromanagement for vote transfer to all allies.

The NDA win has seen the BJP become the single largest party in Bihar, matching its spectacular performance in the 2010 polls, when it had won 91 seats. The Janata Dal (United) had bagged 141 seats then.

The BJP’s long campaign for the Bihar polls began months in advance when senior party leaders such as Union Home Minister Amit Shah and party president J. P. Nadda stressed that all constituents have to be on the same page — organisationally, and on messaging. The message that all allies needed to pull their weight in these polls was an important part of the BJP’s own big tally.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s frequent visits to the State and highlighting the governance model of the NDA, with emphasis on infrastructure and women’s empowerment, as compared to ‘jungle raj’ of non-NDA regimes of the past was the leitmotif of the campaign that the BJP stuck to.

There was also the shadow of the 2024 Lok Sabha results, according to BJP leaders. “After the 2024 Lok Sabha polls, people felt upset that they had not given a full majority to the Narendra Modi government, and that has also been a theme in the subsequent polls in Maharashtra, Haryana and Delhi, where we got big victories,” said Mr. Nadda at the ‘thanksgiving rally’ held in Delhi after the results.

While data shows that the large turnout by women is directly linked to NDA victories, the behind-the-scenes management of sometimes inimical alliance partners and rebel candidates disappointed at not receiving party tickets ensured a smooth transfer of votes across the various constituents of the NDA. This micromanagement, led by Mr. Shah, contributed to this transfer of votes across allies.

For example, while the BJP and the JDU, at the time of writing, had won or were leading in 90 and 83 seats respectively, NDA allies Lok Janshakti Party (RV) was ahead on 19 seats (out of the 28 it contested), the Hindustan Awaam Morcha (HAM) was leading in five (out of six) and the Rashtriya Lok Morcha was winning four seats (out of six). Thus, all constituents of the NDA did well.

According to sources, Mr. Shah, who spent 19 days in the State, held mandal to State-level meetings with workers across the parties for coordination.

Over 100 rebel candidates were in the fray at the beginning of the campaign and could have split the NDA’s vote base had they contested. “Amit Shah ji did not schedule any programme for two to three days and met with as many of the rebel candidates of the alliance as possible. Most of them would only be satisfied if he gave them a hearing, and their anxieties were addressed,” said a BJP leader from Bihar.

The 2025 election also had the shadow of the 2020 polls over it, when LJP fought alone and managed to upset the JD(U)’s chances in at least 32 seats, where the LJP’s vote share was more than the margin of defeat of the JD(U) candidate. Meetings were held between the workers of these parties to get them to pull together and make sure that any bitterness of the past did not get in the way this time around. The BJP’s team of Union Minister Dharmendra Pradhan and Uttar Pradesh Deputy Chief Minister Keshav Prasad Maurya, both considered quintessential organisation men, reached out to NDA workers and leaders.

Amid the big ideas and campaign events, the hard graft of micro-detailing worked in the NDA’s favour.

title: Many residents of Kanakapura Road apartment fall sick; civic body suspects viral diarrhea
content:
Many residents of Prestige Falcon City apartment community on Kanakapura Road have fallen ill over the past few weeks. Many have developed stomach ache, diarrhoea and vomiting.

Avnidhar Hawaldar, a resident, said that multiple members of his family were affected and they had to be administered saline at a nearby nursing home due to weakness and fatigue. "Nearby hospitals are full of residents of our community. Even the hospital on the apartment premises has reported multiple cases," he said.

No outbreak

A medical team from Bengaluru South City Corporation has been camping at the apartment community with a population of over 9,000 from November 12, when they first got an alert.

Kumar M.V., Medical Officer, South City Corporation, camping at the apartment community, said there have been sporadic cases from October 6, recorded at the hospital inside the apartment complex. The hospital on the campus reported a total of 46 gastroenteritis cases between October 6 and November 12. "There are only sporadic cases and there has been no outbreak. We suspect there is a prevalence of viral diarrhoea," he said.

Water contamination?

Mansoor Ali, another resident, said they suspected that there was an infection spreading through the community due to contamination of water sources.

Corporation officials have taken multiple water samples from the inlet, borewells, storage tanks and taps. "We have sent the samples to the Public Health Institute on Thursday and the reports are awaited. As of now there is no confirmation that it is water-borne,” Dr. Kumar said.

Vasant Kumar, president, Prestige Falcon City Residents' Welfare Association, told The Hindu that they had got water samples tested at a private lab and the reports did not find any anamolies in the water samples. "However, we have cleared out all the stored water, got the storage tanks cleaned and disinfected. We have also stopped tanker water from outside for now,” he said.

Further, the corporation officials have instructed dos and don'ts to the community members, including using boiled and cooled water to drink.

title: Develop climate-resilient, high-density cashew varieties: Shobha Karandlaje
content:
Union Minister of State for MSME and Labour and Employment Shobha Karandlaje said here on Friday, November 14, that there is a need to develop climate-resilient, high-density, and high-yielding cashew varieties in the country to increase domestic production.

Speaking at the inaugural session of the three-day Kaju Centennial Summit-2025, organised by the Karnataka Cashew Manufacturers Association (KCMA), the Minister said that cashew processing industries in the country are facing a dearth of raw cashews to process. Hence, domestic production will have to be increased, she added.

She further stated that Vietnam produced 1,200 k.g. of raw cashews per hectare while in India, production stood at 600 k.g. a hectare. India will have to emerge self-reliant in cashew production.

The Minister said that in addition to cashew, India is not self-reliant in the production of edible oil and dal.

Ms. Karandlaje said that 40 lakh people are dependent on cashew processing in India and the industry gives employment to about one lakh women alone.

Vishwaprasanna Tirtha, seer, Udupi Pejawar Mutt, Kota Srinivas Poojary, MP, Udupi-Chikkamagaluru, A. K. Rao, President, KCMA, and Kalbavi Prakash Rao, convener of the summit, were also present.

title: Local body elections decision in Cabinet meeting
content:
A decision and a roadmap for the local body elections is likely to come in the Cabinet meeting to be held on November 17, said Chief Minister A Revanth Reddy.

He said suggestions of the Ministers would be obtained on the local bodies’ elections, and also the legal issues would be discussed on the local body elections. A final decision will be taken after considering all these suggestions and options.

title: Due to heavy winds, fishermen in Ramanathapuram asked not to enter sea
content:
Due to harsh weather in the coastal areas of Ramanathapuram district, the Fisheries Department here on Friday instructed fishermen not to venture into sea for fishing until further announcements.

As strong winds with a speed of 45 to 55 kmph is expected over the Bay of Bengal, the sea is expected to be be very rough.

For those reasons, the department officials, said, the fishing permit passes (token) for mechanised boats would not be issued starting from Friday until a further announcement was made.

They added, mechanised boats anchored at the Rameswaram jetty were instructed to be moored safely and with sufficient spacing between them to prevent damages.

title: NC loses stronghold in J&K; Congress, BJP win two seats each in bypolls to eight Assembly constituencies
content:
Ruling parties lost four of the eight Assembly constituencies across five States and one Union Territory that went to byelection on November 11. The National Conference (NC) suffered a major setback in its stronghold in Jammu and Kashmir, while the Congress registered gains in Rajasthan and Telangana.

It was a surprise outcome in Budgam as the Opposition People’s Democratic Party (PDP) wrested the seat from the NC, marking the party’s first-ever defeat in the central Kashmir stronghold since Assembly elections began in 1957.

PDP candidate Aga Syed Muntazir defeated NC’s Aga Syed Mehmood by 4,478 votes. The seat fell vacant after Chief Minister Omar Abdullah vacated it last year, opting to retain Ganderbal.

The BJP secured a win in Jammu and Kashmir’s Nagrota constituency, where Devyani Rana defeated Jammu and Kashmir National Panthers Party’s Harsh Dev Singh by 24,647 votes. NC’s Shamim Begum lost her deposit, polling just 10,872 votes. The bypoll was necessitated by the death of Ms. Rana’s father and former MLA Devender Singh Rana.

In Mizoram, the Opposition Mizo National Front (MNF) retained the Dampa seat, with R. Lalthangliana defeating Vanlalsailova of the ruling Zoram People’s Movement by 562 votes.

The Congress won two seats and the BJP one more, while the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) and the Jharkhand Mukti Morcha (JMM) also picked up a seat each in the bypolls held in Anta (Rajasthan), Ghatshila (Jharkhand), Jubilee Hills (Telangana), Tarn Taran (Punjab), and Nuapada (Odisha).

In Rajasthan’s Anta, Congress candidate Pramod Jain Bhaya beat BJP’s Morpal Suman by 15,612 votes. The bypoll followed the disqualification of BJP MLA Kanwar Lal Meena after his criminal conviction.

In Telangana, the Congress won the Jubilee Hills seat, where the party’s V. Naveen Yadav defeated Bharat Rashtra Samithi candidate Maganti Sunitha by 24,729 votes. The seat had fallen vacant after the death of BRS MLA Maganti Gopinath.

The BJP registered a big victory in Odisha’s Nuapada, where its candidate Jay Dholakia defeated the Congress’ Ghasi Ram Majhi by 83,748 votes. Mr. Dholakia is the son of former BJD MLA Rajendra Dholakia, whose death led to the bypoll.

The ruling AAP retained Punjab’s Tarn Taran seat with Harmeet Singh Sandhu defeating Shiromani Akali Dal’s (SAD) Sukhwinder Kaur Randhawa by 12,091 votes. The seat fell vacant following the death of AAP MLA Kashmir Singh Sohal.

In Jharkhand’s Ghatshila constituency, JMM’s Soren beat BJP’s Babulal Soren by over 38,500 votes. The byelection was held following the death of JMM MLA Ramdas Soren.

title: Kin of Sivaganga accident victims protest on NH demanding govt. job
content:
Demanding a government job to one of the family members of the three persons who died in a road accident caused by a police vehicle in Sivaganga district on Tuesday (November 11) night, the relatives of the victims staged a protest along Madurai – Tiruchi National Highway near Y. Othakadai junction here on Friday.

The death of the three members of a family — Prasad, 25, a resident of Chittampatti near Melur, his wife Sathya, 20, and two-year-old son Ashwin — on the night shocked the villagers.

As the protest which started on Tuesday night as refusal to accept the body of the three victims spilled onto Wednesday, the relatives blocked the road adjacent to Government Rajaji Hospital in Madurai seeking compensation, a government job to the family and legal action against the allegedly inebriated police personnel who caused the accident.

Though Chief Minister M.K. Stalin announced a solatium of ₹3 lakh each for the deceased family members and ₹1 lakh for the injured woman, Soneswari, the relatives persisted with their protest.

The protest, which was prolonged till Friday, blew up into the agitation to block the NH.

As members of the Viduthalai Chiruthaigal Katchi joined with the protesters on Friday, Nagarathinam, an advocate representing the family, said they were contacted over phone by VCK chief Thol. Thirumavalavan, who requested them to call off the protest.

“He assured us that he would speak to the Chief Minister regarding granting a government job to a family member of the victims. Since he insisted on ending the protest, we listened to him and withdrew the stir,” he added.

Following that, he said, they accepted the bodies of three deceased from the GRH.

title: Upalokayukta flags lapses at two govt. girls’ hostels in Bengaluru
content:
Upalokayukta Justice K.N. Phaneendra, during a surprise inspection on Friday, uncovered lapses and poor living conditions at two Dr. B.R. Ambedkar Post-Matric Girls’ Hostels located at Chikkajala and Kogilu.

At the Chikkajala hostel, Justice Phaneendra found the premises untidy and lacking basic facilities. Students did not have sufficient drinking or usable water, and no solar water or hot water supply was available. The borewell, a key water source, has reportedly remained defunct for the past three years, according to a statement released by Lokayukta. The hostel’s generator has not been operational for nearly the same duration.

Further, several toilets were in poor condition, windows on the first floor were jammed with torn mesh, and newly added floors lacked beds and cots. The inspection also revealed missing amenities such as shoe racks, faulty switchboards, and a first-aid box filled with expired medicines. Doctors were not visiting the hostel as required.

Second hostel

During his visit to the Kogilu girls’ hostel, the Upalokayukta observed similar conditions. The existing water filter was insufficient for students, and no facility had been provided on the upper floors. None of the geysers were functioning, and the hostel lacked access to a library and computer.

In addition, food supplies were found to be unhygienic, grains infested with insects and rotten vegetables being used for cooking. The refrigerator was not working, the water tank had not been cleaned properly, and students faced a daily shortage of food. The warden was also found to be neglecting her duties, and hygiene in the kitchen remained poor. Medicines were not provided to the hostel, and doctors were not making their routine visits.

Justice Phaneendra directed hostel authorities to resolve the major issues within two months, calling the hostels “totally neglected”.

title: Awareness workshop on ‘bio-methanation projects’
content:
The growing importance of bioenergy and the role of research institutions in supporting its development was highlighted during a workshop on ‘Capacity building and awareness generation workshop on organic bio-methanation projects’ held at the CSIR-Indian Institute of Chemical Technology (IICT) here on Friday.

The objective of the workshop was to equip finance professionals and other stakeholders with the necessary knowledge, skills and to create awareness, build capacity, for the promotion of CBG ecosystem by bringing together key stakeholders, entrepreneurs, and government officials on a common platform.

IICT chief scientist A. Gangagni Rao explained how the biogas sector has grown over the years in India, highlighted its rising importance in waste management and clean fuel production, and shared valuable lessons from his own experience working with biogas and CBG systems.

About 212 delegates including representatives from the industry and financial institutions such as SIDBI, UCO Bank, Central Bank of India, Punjab & Sind Bank, Punjab National Bank and Canara Bank and others, took part in the programme. TERI (The Energy and Resources Institute) associate director Nagendra Kumar, IICT director D. Srinivasa Reddy, MNRE (Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (MNRE) scientist Bikash Upadhyay, UNIDO’s (United Nations Industrial Development Organization) Nikhil Khot and others also spoke, said a press release.

title: TNAU disburses ₹64.4 lakh in grants to agri-startups to boost innovation
content:
Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (TNAU) on Friday disbursed grants to tune of ₹ 64.4 lakh under the Central Government’s RKVY-RAFTAAR scheme (Rashtriya Krishi Vikas Yojana - Remunerative Approaches for Agriculture and Allied Sectors Rejuvenation) to incubatees of its Agribusiness Incubation Society- Technology Business Incubator (ABIS-TBI).

The funding for agri-startups, being carried out in TNAU since 2019 under the flagship scheme of the Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers’ Welfare, is meant for strengthening infrastructure in agriculture and allied sectors by building agripreneurship and agri-business ecosystem in the country.

So far, the 131 startups in the university’s TBI have received ₹ 16.04 crore as grants.

R. Thamizh Vendan, acting Vice -Chancellor, TNAU, handed over grant amount of ₹40.80 lakh for 10 SAIP (Start-up Agri-Business Incubation Programme) Cohort IV Grantees as third instalment, and ₹23.60 lakh for 13 AOP (Agripreneurship Orientation Programme) Cohort V Grantees as second instalment.

The initiative, Prof. Thamizh Vendan, said, has paved way supporting innovations to implement new technologies for sustainable and profitable agribusiness.

The disbursed grant will be used by the grantees for the development of products and upscaling of their startups in agri and allied ventures, he said.

title: HC cautions HYDRAA Commissioner against misuse of power
content:
Justice B. Vijaysen Reddy of Telangana High Court on Friday cautioned HYDRAA Commissioner A.V. Ranganath against misuse of the powers conferred on the agency.

Observing that power was accorded to officials for serving people, the judge said the authorities had to remember that the courts have superior power. “…the court has superior power… what we have to do, we will do. Do not make us use such power,” the judge told HYDRAA Commissioner appearing virtually before the bench in a contempt of court case.

The judge remarked that demolitions of structures cannot be taken up without adhering to the procedures established by the law even such buildings came up on lands falling under buffer zones or lake bed areas. He sought to know from where did the HYDRAA secure the power to demolish structures without issuing proper notices to the affected persons. “There should be some order, social order, public order…Follow the rules,” he said.

The judge said that some people buy open plots admeasuring 50 to 100 square yards in good faith to have a roof over their heads and land in litigation for various reasons. Sometimes, the governments regularise structures raised in such plots under land regularisation scheme and building regularisation scheme. “Your people are demolishing them on Saturdays and Sundays without issuing notices. Where will the occupants go suddenly?” the judge asked.

The HYDRAA Commissioner informed the bench that the agency had been acting lawfully in all cases. He said the demolitions were taken up while acting upon complaints received through ‘Praja Vani’ programme of the government.

Commissioner Ranganath submitted that HYDRAA has been acting lawfully, removing tonnes of bio-waste and debris from the Tammidi Kunta lake bed to prevent flooding in Hi-Tech City, Metal Charminar and other areas. He stated that many complaints received through the “Praja Vani” programme necessitated such action.

The petitioner Mohammadi Begum’s counsel contended that the law did not accord any power upon the agency to undertake demolitions without following the principles of natural justice. The contempt case was adjourned to November 27 for next hearing.

title: IIT Madras launches ‘Language and Cognition Lab’ to study India’s linguistic diversity
content:
The Indian Institute of Technology Madras (IIT Madras) has launched the ‘Language and Cognition Laboratory’ (LC-Lab) to study India’s linguistic diversity through an interdisciplinary and technology-driven approach. Established at the Department of Humanities and Social Sciences, this is the first lab in India that systematically engages with the country’s vast linguistic diversity through experimental linguistics. The lab will explore how humans perceive, process, and produce language using advanced experimental methods.

In the long term, it aims to contribute to the development of human-centred and linguistically aware AI systems, ensuring that India’s languages and cultures are represented in emerging technologies. This lab will work closely with the Centre for Responsible AI (CeRAI), IIT Madras to explore the applications of AI methods to language and cognition research

V. Kamakoti, Director, IIT Madras, said, “Linguistics is increasingly moving toward empirical, data-driven inquiry, combining methodologies from the sciences and humanities. India needed a dedicated facility that integrated linguistic theory with modern experimental and computational tools. The Language and Cognition Lab was established to fill this gap—creating a space that connects linguistics, cognitive science, neuroscience, and artificial intelligence, and contributes to the development of socially relevant, linguistically informed technologies.”

The Language and Cognition Laboratory (LC-Lab) will investigate how people process linguistic information by employing techniques such as eye-tracking and reaction-time studies. Its research focuses primarily on Indian languages, offering crucial insights into how grammar, voice, and sentence structure are understood and produced in multilingual contexts. While ongoing projects study grammatical voice and copula constructions, upcoming work will examine dyslexia in Indian children, with the goal of improving educational outcomes and developing linguistically relevant teaching interventions.

Speaking about the lab, its Faculty Coordinator Anindita Sahoo said, “The Language and Cognition laboratory (LC-Lab) is dedicated to advancing interdisciplinary research in language and cognition through the use of technologies that reveal behavioural patterns and enable data-driven understanding of human interaction.”

The LC-Lab’s interdisciplinary framework integrates insights from science, technology, and the humanities to advance both academic research and technological innovation.

In the short term, the LC-Lab will conduct experimental research using eye-tracking technology to validate established linguistic theories in Indian languages. In the long term, it plans to integrate advanced neurocognitive techniques such as Electroencephalography (EEG) and Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS).

These tools will support comprehensive research in language, cognition, and computational modelling, while fostering collaboration with experts in psychology, neuroscience, and artificial intelligence.

The lab is currently supported by IITM Pravartak Technologies Foundation and Aspire Infolab, Hyderabad, which have contributed to its establishment and research infrastructure.

title: Viyyur police’s swift action saves woman’s life
content:
The Viyyur Police averted a tragedy on Friday morning after a young woman from Peringavu made a frantic call to the station, pleading for help as her mother had locked herself in a room and was feared to be attempting suicide.

Assistant sub-inspector Sajeevan received the distressed call while the team was preparing for the morning parade. He immediately alerted inspector K.P. Mithun. On the inspector’s instructions, sub-inspector Jinu Kumar and senior civil police officer Nishi rushed to the location with the station vehicle.

Within minutes, the officers reached the home, where the elderly parents led them to the locked room. The daughter was frantically knocking on the door begging her mother to open it.

The officers quickly broke open the door and rushed in. She was quickly rushed to a nearby hospital.

Doctors placed her in the ICU, and after about three hours confirmed that she was out of danger. They said she survived solely because of the police’s swift response.

(Suicide prevention helpline numbers - Disha Helpline (1056) or Tele Manas (14416).

title: Re-release of Shiva warms Nagarjuna’s relations with ruling Congress
content:
The re-release of 80s iconic film ‘Shiva’ is plugging the gap between Congress ministers and the film hero Akkineni Nagarjuna after the latter faced some embarrassing moments due to unsavoury comments on Nagarjuna’s family issues by a Congress Minister.

Minister for Roads and Buildings and Cinematography Komatireddy Venkata Reddy posted on ‘X’ recalling his experiences of watching the iconomic film earlier an wishing him best on the re-release of the picture.

Mr. Reddy posted on ‘X’ saying ‘Dear @iamnagarjuna garu, Shiva redefined Telugu cinema, showcasing your unmatched intensity, screen presence, and depth as an actor. Continuing ANR garu’s glorious legacy, your commitment to meaningful cinema remains truly inspiring.

‘On the occasion of Shiva’s re-release, my best wishes to you. From the pathbreaking Shiva to divine portrayals in Annamayya, Shirdi Sai, and my favourite Bhakta Ramadasu, your journey continues to influence generations. Wishing Shiva grand success once again.’

Mr. Nagarjuna responded, thanking the Minister for the kind and inspiring words and urged him to watch the film in its 4K digitised version whenever he gets time.

title: Congress blames SIR, ‘vote chori’ after worst performance in Bihar since 2010
content:
The collapse of the mahagathbandhan, the Opposition grand alliance, in the Bihar Assembly election on Friday prompted some Congress leaders to pin the blame on alleged ‘vote chori (theft)’ and the special intensive revision (SIR) of the electoral rolls in the State. The Congress itself is set to record its worst seat tally in the State since 2010.

2025 Bihar Assembly election results | Live updates

Former Rajasthan Chief Minister Ashok Gehlot, who had emerged as the troubleshooter for the Opposition alliance during the seat-sharing talks, accused the Election Commission of India (ECI) of “colluding” with the ruling coalition in Bihar.

Data | ‘Weak link’ Congress grows even weaker in 2025

Mr. Gehlot claimed that pension payments and cash transfers, including ₹10,000 for women under the Mukhyamantri Mahila Rozgar Yojana, continued unabated despite the model code of conduct (MCC) being in force.

‘ECI collusion with NDA’

“The Assembly results are disappointing. It seems to me that the payments of ₹10,000 to women were continuing even when the election campaign was on; such a thing never happens,” he said in Jaipur, recalling how, during the 2023 Rajasthan Assembly election, the distribution of mobile phones for women under a welfare scheme and pension disbursements were stopped as soon as the MCC kicked in.

He noted that smart phone distribution was halted in Rajasthan despite 30% of beneficiaries having already received their devices. Even ongoing social security pensions and schemes like Annapurna were stopped, the Congress leader added. He alleged that the NDA government in Bihar had followed the same model as in Maharashtra, where ₹7,500 was given to women beneficiaries.

“In Bihar, the Election Commission remained a mute spectator. Why did it not stop this? It did not intervene at all. When you do not ensure fair elections, when booth capturing or dishonesty takes place, and the Election Commission takes no action, that is vote theft. There was clear collusion with the ruling party,” Mr. Gehlot alleged.

‘Tilted playing field’

His party colleague and Lok Sabha member from Tamil Nadu, Manickam Tagore, blamed the SIR exercise for the rout.

“When you delete 65 lakh voters — mostly the Opposition’s voters — what do you expect on result day? Democracy cannot survive if the playing field is tilted before the match even begins,” Mr. Tagore said in an X post with the hashtag #VoteChori.

Though Congress leader Rahul Gandhi had not yet commented on Friday’s poll results, he had earlier claimed at a press conference that the same pattern would be followed in Bihar as vote theft “has been now industrialised”.

Complete decimation

But no allegation can take away the reality of the worst Congress performance in the past three Assembly elections: from 27 seats in 2015 and 19 seats in 2020, the party was leading in only six seats at the time of filing this report.

Interactive | Bihar’s deleted voters: by age, reason and gender

The party’s hopes of building momentum for the mahagathbandhan, riding on the popularity of Mr. Gandhi’s Voter Adhikar Yatra which covered 1,300 km across 25 districts in August, were belied. The Congress lost most of the seats that fell along the yatra route, and the defeat of the Bihar Congress chief Rajesh Kumar made the party’s decimation complete.

‘Expel those responsible’

The crushing defeat in Bihar will not only affect the morale of Congress workers in Assam and Kerala, where the party is the main challenger in next year’s Assembly polls, it is also likely to change the dynamics of the INDIA bloc.

Complaining about ticket distribution and party strategy, veteran Congress leader from Bihar Kishore Kumar Jha demanded a probe into the party’s debacle. “Rahul ji should set up a committee to find out who was responsible for the defeat and expel them from the party,” Mr. Jha said.

In an X post, Mumtaz Patel, daughter of the late Ahmed Patel, who had served as political secretary to former Congress president Sonia Gandhi, said the party’s repeated failures were because of “power concentrated in the hands of few who are totally disconnected with ground reality”.

title: Ministers’ intensive ground work delivers for Congress
content:
A meticulously planned and aggressively executed campaign by three senior Ministers, G. Vivek Venkatswamy, Ponnam Prabhakar and Tummala Nageshwar Rao, played a decisive role in securing the Congress’s emphatic victory in the Jubilee Hills Assembly byelection.

Entrusted by Chief Minister A. Revanth Reddy, with the responsibility of turning a traditionally unfavourable constituency in favour of the Congress, the Ministers began working months before the bypoll notification was issued or a candidate was announced.

Despite Jubilee Hills being a seat that Congress had not won since the formation of Telangana, the Ministers launched an early and deep-reaching outreach programme. They coordinated with local leaders, conducted division-wise meetings, and penetrated pockets where the party had historically struggled.

Development works worth hundreds of crores were sanctioned for the constituency, significantly strengthening the government’s connect with residents.

Labour and Employment Minister Vivek Venkatswamy took the lead by addressing numerous colony meetings and targeted interactions with various sections of society. At a time when the BRS appeared to have a head start with the early announcement of its candidate, Mr. Vivek worked to neutralise its initial advantage.

“When we first entered the constituency, BRS had a massive lead on sympathy and other related factors. But within just three months of dedicated work, we managed to wipe out that entire difference,” he told The Hindu. “CM Revanth Reddy entrusted us with the job with immense confidence, and we delivered this victory. CM’s public meetings neutralised all the BRS negative campaign.”

Mr. Vivek described the result as a ‘clear rejection of the BRS leadership and its policies’, pointing out that the party had been losing elections consistently from the Assembly polls to the Lok Sabha elections, the Cantonment bypoll, and now Jubilee Hills. He said the BRS depended excessively on social media narratives while ignoring on-ground realities. “This win is not accidental. We listened to people’s concerns and addressed them.”

Minister Ponnam Prabhakar undertook extensive tours across the constituency, meeting influential individuals and diverse communities to consolidate Congress support. He connected the social agenda of the party with the masses here and energised the cadre.

Agriculture Minister Tummala Nageswar Rao focused specifically on mobilising TDP-leaning voters, a segment seen as critical in the constituency. His efforts were credited with drawing former TDP supporters into the Congress fold, bolstering the party’s prospects further.

title: BJP Councillor stages dharna demanding Dindigul Corporation Council meeting be held this month
content:
BJP Councillor (Ward 14) G. Dhanabalan on Friday staged a dharna demanding that the Dindigul Corporation Council meeting, which was last held in August, be conducted this month. Only if the meeting is held, public grievances could be discussed and redressed, he said.
