In a letter to the Director of Municipal Administration P. Madhusudhan Reddy, he pointed out the Dindigul Corporation Council meeting was last held on August 22. It has been more than two months now since the meeting was held.

Several works pertaining to underground drainage, sanitation, drinking water, storm water drains, and roads were pending. Also, there were several complaints from the public about the condition of roads and other infrastructure. As a result people were put to much hardship. However, certain works were still being carried out in some of the wards without proper discussions being held claiming that the permission for these works had already been granted. There was a revenue loss, he said.

Though the issue was brought to the notice of the officials concerned, no necessary steps were taken to conduct the Corporation Council meeting. The meeting should be conducted every month as several issues were pending which needed to be discussed and redressed, he said.

Following the dharna staged by Mr. Dhanabalan, Dindigul Corporation Commissioner M. Senthil Murugan contacted the BJP Councillor and assured him that the meeting would be held this month. Mr. Dhanabalan called off the protest for now and said that he would stage a dharna again if the council meeting was not held as assured.

title: This is the right time to invest in India and Andhra Pradesh, says Vice-President C.P. Radhakrishnan
content:
Vice-President C.P. Radhakrishnan said India was emerging as an economic powerhouse under the leadership of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, and the Central and State governments were effectively working together for the development of the country and Andhra Pradesh.

Participating as chief guest in the inaugural session of the 30th CII Partnership Summit-2025 here on Friday, Mr. Radhakrishnan said poverty eradication was possible only through wealth creation, and this had been the ultimate goal of the NDA Government alongside peace and stability.

He said reforms like the rationalisation of GST and the emphasis laid on infrastructure creation were tremendously contributing to the nation’s development. He insisted that this was the right time to invest in the country, and in A.P., where Chief Minister N. Chandrababu Naidu was working in a mission mode to put the State back on track after it was badly hit by bifurcation.

The Vice-President said Mr. Naidu was practicing good governance and the policies brought by his government were the best in class. Investors should explore opportunities in the blue economy, agriculture and food processing sectors in A.P., he suggested, wishing the summit a grand success.

Governor S. Abdul Nazeer said Mr. Naidu was shaping Andhra Pradesh as a “future-ready, innovative State” and was impressed by his dedication to making it a prosperous State.

title: V. Sekar, master of 90s family dramas, dies
content:
Director and writer V. Sekar, whose comedy films portrayed middle and lower-middle class lives and aspirations in Tamil cinema, passed away in Chennai on Friday after a brief illness. He was 72.

Mr. Sekar was well-known for capturing the mundane lives of working class and middle-income families in a remarkable manner, casually using comedy to bring progressive ideas into his films.

Mr. Sekar’s films were also self-reflective, often highlighting how men tend to exploit women, even within so-called progressive settings.

Some of his most well-known films are Varavu Ettana Selavu Pathana, starring Nasser, Vadivelu, and Radhika; and Kaalam Maari Pochu – both superhit family dramas.

His other notable works are Naan Pudicha Maapillai, Porantha Veeda Puguntha Veeda, Naan Petha Magane, Viralukketha Veekkam, and Koodi Vazhnthal Kodi Nanmai.

title: Nehru’s contribution for building modern India immense, says B. Ramanath Rai
content:
Former minister B. Ramanath Rai on Friday, November 14, said the contribution of former Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru in building modern India through economic, social, and political reforms have been immense.

Mr. Rai was speaking after offering floral tributes to Nehru’s statue on the occasion of his 136th birth anniversary at Nehru Maidan along with party leaders and workers.

The former Minister said the major infrastructure in Dakshina Kannada, including the airport, the New Mangalore Port, bridges, national highways, and so on, were the results of then Member of Parliament U. Srinivas Mallya’s efforts. Nevertheless, they were granted under the leadership of Nehru, he noted.

The administration, therefore, aptly named the ground in the central part of the city after Nehru. Yet, the Bharatiya Janata Party and the Sangh Parivar call it Kendra Maidan, he lamented, saying that they were not true patriots.

Dakshina Kannada District Congress Committee President K. Harish Kumar said Nehru laid the foundation stone for modern India through the Five-Year Plans. During the 17 years when he was the Prime Minister, the country witnessed massive development, including construction of dams, public sector industries, institutes of higher education, and much more. If India is the fourth-largest economy in the world at present, it is because of Nehru, he said.

MLC Ivan D’Souza, former MLA J.R. Lobo, leaders Padmaraj R. Poojary, Shalet Pinto, Vishwas Kumar Das, and others were present.

title: ONGC seeks locals’ support to repair gutted pipeline
content:
Oil and Natural Gas Corporation (Kakinada offshore asset) Executive Director Prabhal Sen Gupta sought the support of the local communities in Kakinada district (Andhra Pradesh) and Yanam in Puducherry Union Territory for the repair of the gas pipeline damaged in a major fire incident that took place on August 22, 2025.

In the early hours of August 22, 2025, a major fire broke out after natural gas leaked from an ONGC pipeline while it was being supplied through the 23-km pipeline from an offshore rig in the Bay of Bengal to the onshore plant on Dariyala Tippa island in Yanam.

In a high-level meeting attended by officials from Kakinada district, Yanam authorities and public representatives on Friday, Mr. Prabhal Sen Gupta said “We have already prepared the ground to begin the pipeline repair work,”while appealing for support from the local communities to complete the task.

Compensation: Meanwhile, the Central Marine Fisheries Research Institute (CMFRI) is studying the environmental damage and impact of the fire accident on the marine life in Yanam and adjoining coastal belts including the Kakinada coast. On the impact of the fire accident on the marine life, Kakinada City MLA Vanamadi Venkateswara Rao said that the marine resources, primarily fish species, were affected by the fire accident.

Responding to the queries by the public representatives including Mummudivaram MLA Datla Subba Raju and former Yanam minister Malladi Krishna Rao, Kakinada District Collector S. Shan Mohan said that talks would be held with ONGC-Kakinada representatives to compensate the fisherfolk who suffered losses due to poor fish catch near the Dariyala Tippa island. Yanam Regional Administrator Ankit Kumar and other officials were present.

title: Railway officials inspect Rameswaram railway station construction works
content:
Southern Railway Additional General Manager Vipin Kumar inspected the ongoing development works at the Rameswaram railway station and the new Pamban railway bridge here on Friday.

Speaking to press, he informed that the construction works of the Rameswaram railway station would be completed by the end of March, 2026.

“As the development and construction works at the Rameswaram railway station is 75% complete, the entire project is expected to be completed by the end of March,” he added.

He noted that as the Railway Board was currently considering the launch of the Vande Bharat Express service to Rameswaram, the Vande Bharat train service would soon be launched from Rameswaram.

Speaking of the new Pamban railway bridge, Mr. Kumar said that it was satisfactory and the vertical lift span at the centre of the bridge was functioning well.

However, he said, the railway department was paying extra attention on the vertical lift span to prevent any technical glitches in the future.

L.N. Rao, Additional Divisional Railway Manager, Madurai Division, K.G. Gnanasekhar, Deputy Chief Engineer (Construction) officials from Madurai Division and the Construction Organization, Southern Railway were present during the inspection.

title: Karayi Chandrasekharan to contest in Thalassery civic polls amid pending murder case
content:
Communist Party of India (Marxist) [CPI(M)] leader Karayi Chandrasekharan, an accused in the murder of National Development Front (NDF) activist Muhammad Fazal, has been fielded as the party’s candidate in the upcoming Thalassery municipal elections. Mr. Chandrasekharan, who is facing conspiracy charges in the case, will contest from the Chelakkara ward.

A former chairperson of the municipality, he had stepped down from the post in 2015 due to bail conditions that restricted his entry into the district. The CPI(M) is aiming to bring him back as the chairperson if the party retains its hold. Mr. Chandrasekharan, a senior leader and CPI(M) area committee member, remains influential in Thalassery, where the Left expects to maintain its long standing dominance over the municipality.

The number of wards has risen from 52 to 53 this election. The Left Democratic Front has completed seat allocation across all wards, with the CPI(M) contesting in 46 seats and the CPI in five. One seat each has been allotted to the Nationalist Congress Party (NCP) and Indian National League (INL).

Seat sharing discussions within the United democratic Front (UDF) is nearing completion. The new ward, Guards, as become a point contention between the Congress and the Indian Union Muslim League (IUML), with both citing organisational presence in the adjoining areas. In the remaining wards, the current understanding is that the Congress will contest in 35 wards and the IUML in 17. The UDF currently holds seven seats in the municipality- the Congress in three and the IUML in four seats.

The National Democratic Alliance is expected to announce its candidates soon. Thalassery remains the Bharatiya Janata Party’s (BJP) strongest base in Kannur district in terms of council representation and the party is looking to improve its tally. However, recent controversies involving its leaders, including alleged involvement of BJP leader K. Lijesh in the murder of CPI(M) worker K. Haridas in Punnol, have weakened its position. Internal strains persist, with the RSS distancing itself from electoral activities and having publicly disowned the accused in theHaridas murder case.

title: State moves HC against Governor’s notifications on VC appointment in CU
content:
The State government has submitted a plea before the Kerala High Court seeking to quash notifications issued by the Governor, in his capacity as Chancellor of the University of Calicut, inviting applications to the post of Vice-Chancellor of the university.

It also challenged a recent notification that constituted a search-cum-selection committee to appoint a VC. The State contended that the constitution of the committee was not as per university statutes and UGC norms. As per the norms, members of search-cum-selection committee must not be connected in any manner with the university and its affiliated colleges. This had not been adhered to, it said.

The petition was adjourned for hearing to Monday, at the request of the Chancellor.

title: Internal conflict, fight over CM post, delayed campaign take a toll on INDIA
content:
Poor performance of the Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance (INDIA) bloc in the Bihar Assembly election has raised serious concerns over the leadership of the alliance.

The delay in its campaign, the internal conflict over seat distribution, and rigidity over the chief ministerial candidate are some of the major issues that did not allow Mahagathbandhan (grand alliance) to take off.

Though its top leaders such as Tejashwi Yadav and Rahul Gandhi tried to show a united front in public, the infighting within the alliance impacted its cohesiveness. Selection of candidates and seat distribution at the eleventh hour, when the last date of the nomination was near, led to distraction among the voters.

The RJD being rigid about Tejashwi Yadav as the Chief Ministerial candidate also cost the alliance dear. The tug of war between the RJD and the Congress over the CM face had become so intense that the All India Congress Committee (AICC) senior observer for the Bihar Assembly election, Ashok Gehlot, had to fly to Patna to meet Rashtriya Janata Dal (RJD) chief Lalu Prasad and his son Tejashwi Yadav.

This particular reason delayed the election campaign. Only after Mr. Yadav was named the CM candidate on October 23, did he start his election campaign.

Mr. Yadav got only 17 days to campaign and in this short period, he could devote only less time to every public meeting that he addressed. Initially, he started with 10 to 12 public meetings daily, but as days progressed, he had to address nearly 18 public meetings to cover all 243 Assembly segments.

The way Mr. Yadav was adamant on being the CM nominee, Vikassheel Insaan Party (VIP) chief Mukesh Sahani insisted on being the Deputy CM candidate, which again spoiled their image among the public.

Allegations against the Congress over the “sale” of ticket, as well as the party’s decision to drop candidates who won the last election, did not go down well with the electorate.

Mr. Yadav who was heading the INDIA bloc made several election promises, including government job to one member of every family – seen by many as impractical.

During the entire campaign of the RJD and the Congress, attack on Special Intensive Revision (SIR) and vote chori (vote theft) was the central theme, which did not work on the ground. Not only this, the friendly fight within the alliance in 12 Assembly seats led to division of votes.

For the last one decade, the RJD was the single largest party, winning 75 seats in the last Assembly election. This time, the RJD fielded 143 candidates, the maximum among the INDIA bloc, but fared miserably.

The worst performance was by the VIP, which could not open an account. Mr. Sahani was given 15 seats in the alliance.

Similarly, the Congress was given 62 seats, of which it won six seats. The performance of all three Left parties in Bihar was equally poor with the Communist Party of India (Marxist-Leninist) (Liberation) winning two seats out of the 20 seats it contested. The CPI(M) won one seat.

title: CPI’s Kochi Deputy Mayor resigns from party, slams candidate selection process
content:
K.A. Ansiya, Deputy Mayor of the outgoing Kochi Corporation council and mandalam secretary of the CPI’s women’s wing, Mahila Sangham, announced her resignation from the party here on Friday.

In a surprise move, Ms. Ansiya made the announcement at a press conference, accusing the party of being reduced to a few individuals. She alleged that the candidate for the sixth ward was decided unilaterally, ignoring the names of hard working members of the Mahila Sangham.

“I have immense love for the CPI, which is corruption-free. The party allowed me to function independently without making unfair demands. But the party being reduced to a few individuals will leave it rootless in the Kochi mandalam and deny rightful opportunities to more women,” Ms. Ansiya said.

‘Not party member’

She further alleged that the candidate whose name topped the list of probables and was eventually selected for the ward was not a party member and had no association with the Mahila Sangham. She claimed that the district committee disregarded the sentiments of the Kochi mandalam committee.

Later, the mandalam committee issued a statement dismissing Ms. Ansiya’s allegations as baseless. It saidthe list of candidates with three names was finalised based on the majority decision of the mandalam committee and forwarded to the district committee, which approved the candidacy of P.H. Anila, whose name was first on the list.

“The mandalam committee approved the list of candidates in the most democratic manner. The same protocol was followed when Ms. Ansiya was made the candidate five years ago. At that time, she was not even a party member, yet the party made her the Deputy Mayor. Her latest statement, after enjoying the perks of being the Deputy Mayor for five years, betrays her disappointment over the failure to protect her vested interests,” alleged Abdul Jaleel, secretary of the mandalam committee.

title: ‘Mission is to bring back children to classrooms’
content:
The primary mission is to identify school dropouts and child labourers, bring them back to classrooms, and ensure their protection and rehabilitation, said Syed Ziyauddin, Secretary, District Legal Services Authority (DLSA), Guntur, while inaugurating a workshop held on the occasion of Children’s Day on Friday (November 14, 2025).

The programme was organised as part of the National Legal Services Authority’s (NALSA) calendar activities, following directions from the National and State Legal Services Authorities. Officials from the Labour Department, panel lawyers, para-legal volunteers, Child Welfare Police Officers, District Education authorities, Women and Child Welfare Department, members of the Child Welfare Committee (CWC), CRAFT organisation representatives, and several NGOs participated.

Ziyauddin emphasised that safeguarding children requires coordinated efforts across Education, Labour, Police, and Welfare Departments. A joint action plan would be implemented to trace dropouts through household visits, with para-legal volunteers and panel lawyers assisting families with legal and documentation support. He added that DLSA, along with the Labour Department, Police, and CWC, will conduct surprise raids to rescue child workers and ensure immediate care, rehabilitation, and education for every rescued child.

Speakers including B. Koteswara Rao (ALO-II), Vasanthi (Legal-cum-Probation Officer), Madhu Babu (Deputy Chief Legal Aid Defence Counsel), and panel advocate Katta Kalidas highlighted the significance of Children’s Day. On this occasion, CRAFT released a poster on child rights under the supervision of the DLSA Secretary, reiterating the need to build a society free of child labour and child marriages.

title: Telangana mulls pension scheme for all employees with PFRDA support: official
content:
Telangana government plans to introduce a pension scheme for all its employees with support from the Pension Fund Regulatory and Development Authority (PFRDA), a senior official of the State government told a conclave on National Pension System (NPS) here on Friday.

“Standardising pension schemes for all government employees is the need of the hour,” Special Chief Secretary Jayesh Ranjan said. He urged industry players to continue innovating and introduce new products and services for the underserved.

The senior official, addressing the programme organised by PFRDA in association with KFintech, said many people remain reluctant to discuss retirement planning. With India’s large population and its demographic dividend, he the need is to prepare for the ageing population that is projected to rise by 10% in the next decade.

Telangana has a well-structured pension framework for government and organised-sector employees. “But what about people in the unorganised sector?” he asked. In this backdrop, gig and platform workers in Telangana are set to receive social protection under the Telangana Gig and Platform Workers (Registration, Social Security and Welfare) Act, 2025, which is expected to be tabled in the next Assembly session, Mr. Ranjan said.

In a release, the organisers said the conclave sought to enhance corporate participation in the NPS and explore how technology can help expand pension access across the country, especially to underserved sections.

PFRDA Chairperson S. Ramann said people generally avoid conversations about retirement savings, especially pensions. “Many remain unaware of financial planning, wealth creation and financial instruments. Our mandate has always been — grow rich before you grow old,” he said, emphasising the need for technology-driven financial inclusion.

India has a workforce of more than 55 crore of which 10 crore are in the organised sector. “This presents a massive opportunity for pension products. With ₹3,000 a month and a moderate 2–3% annual increase in contribution, one can expect a return of about 9.2% CAGR,” he said.

title: Two killed, two injured in road accident in Lingsugur
content:
A motorcycle rider and a pillion rider of another motorcycle died and two more, including the pillion rider of the other motorcycle, suffered injuries after their motorcycles collided on the outskirts of Lingsugur town in Raichur district on Friday.

The deceased have been identified as 18-year-old Preetam, a native of Lingsugur town, and 37-year-old Siddayyaswamy, a native of Yaradona village.

An injured Anand and Sanjay, residents of Lingsugur town, have been referred to a hospital in Bagalkot.

Preetam died on the spot, while Siddayyaswamy died on his way to hospital in Bagalkot.

The incident happened when rider Preetam, with his pillion rider Sanjay, took a right turn ramming the other motorcycle in which Anand and Siddayyaswamy were travelling.

The Lingsugur Police have registered a case. Investigation is on.

title: Vibrant rally, meeting mark Children’s Day fete in Thiruvananthapuram
content:
A colourful rally and a public meeting at Kanakakkunnu Palace marked the Children’s Day celebrations organised by the Kerala State Council for Child Welfare here on Friday.

Hundreds of schoolchildren took part in the rally that was a mirror of the State’s rich culture. The rally was flagged off by council general secretary G.L. Arun Gopi at University Stadium.

Children in roller skates, Mounted Police personnel, along with ‘children’s prime minister’ Durga Jishnu, ‘president’ Aradhana Praveen, ‘speaker’ Angel S., Prayag M. and Nivedya A.L. who spoke at the public meeting, were in an open jeep in the front of the rally that concluded at Kanakakkunnu.

Durga Jishnu inaugurated the public meeting. Angel S. delivered the keynote address, presided over by Aradhana Praveen. Devanand of Christ Nagar school sang the welcome song.

Minister for Women and Child Development Veena George, singer Vaikom Vijayalakshmi and V. Joy, MLA, attended the function.

Ms. Vijayalakshmi rendered some of her favourite songs to loud applause.

Ms. George released the Children’s Day stamp by handing it over to Mr. Joy. A painting by Vygha V.K. of Government Ganapat Vocational Higher Secondary School, Feroke, Kozhikode, was selected for the Children’s Day stamp for 2025-26.

title: A.P. showcases investment potential, local products at CII Partnership Summit
content:
The State government leveraged the CII Partnership Summit to showcase its investment opportunities while promoting local products such as Araku Coffee, textiles, handlooms, crafts, and tourism. Delegates from various countries and States who attended the summit were given a glimpse of these highlights.

A special Andhra Pradesh Pavilion was inaugurated by IT Minister Nara Lokesh at the summit’s main venue in Hall No. 4. He was accompanied by Union Civil Aviation Minister K. Ram Mohan Naidu, Industries Minister T.G. Bharat, and other officials.

The sprawling pavilion featured government departments highlighting their initiatives and investment opportunities. Each department provided access to digital dashboards that enabled delegates to view available land parcels across the State, ongoing projects, and other key information along with maps. For the first time, AI-powered robots assisted visitors—underscoring the State’s focus on technology and innovation. A large-scale model of the Amaravati capital city was also on display.

In Hall No. 1, the government set up a series of well-designed stalls representing different departments and initiatives. The Girijan Cooperative Corporation (GCC) showcased Araku Valley Coffee, highlighting its journey from tribal growers to global consumers. Lepakshi featured traditional wooden toys and handicrafts, reflecting the State’s artisanal heritage.

The contributions of the State’s handloom weavers were showcased through an impressive collection of 52 unique weaves from across Andhra Pradesh. Each weave reflected the craftsmanship, cultural identity, and textile traditions of its region. A dedicated stall explained the objectives of the government’s P4 initiative. Stalls by the Food Processing Society and the AP Skill Development and Training Department (APSSDC) highlighted efforts to strengthen agriculture and enhance youth employability through skill development programmes.

Prof. Bertram Lohmüller from Germany said he has been collaborating closely with the Andhra Pradesh government and described its support as commendable.

Mr. Patil, an entrepreneur from New Delhi, noted that the State has been effectively engaging and attracting delegates at the summit. He praised the ease and speed with which necessary approvals are being granted, often within a few weeks, calling it “remarkable.”

title: Three books released in Shivamogga
content:
A book written by H.S. Sreemathi, a scholar in women’s studies, and two books authored by K.V. Narayana, a linguist, were released in a programme organised by Bahumukhi, a literary forum, in Shivamogga on Thursday.

Streevadi Sahitya Vimarshe Mattu Kannada Sahitya Sandarbha, written by Ms. Sreemathi, and Kannada Nuri Rachane and Hosa Odugarigagi Kuvempu, written by Mr. Narayana, were released on the occasion.

Ms. Sreemathi, speaking on the occasion, said questioning patriarchy should not be construed as questioning men; instead, it was a way of understanding the dynamics of patriarchy. “At some stage in the evolution process, males dominated over women for reasons specific to that time. We need to understand why the dynamics never changed afterwards, though men and women are equal in every sense,” she said.

Her book, the author stated, was an attempt to find answers to her questions on feminist criticism. “Feminist literary criticism is not merely a discussion on literature. Instead, it is an academic activity that exposes the reality that literary texts, as products of the system, justify and reinforce patriarchal thinking and aspirations,” she opined.

K.V. Narayana said the thoughts he was proposing on the structure of Kannada language in his book Kannada Nudi Rachane, were totally different from what had already been discussed so far. Besides that, he used different terminology to analyse the language structure. He used new terms for words like – vakya (sentence), vyakarana (grammar) – while placing his arguments on the language through the concept of explanatory adequacy, in his work, he elaborated.

His other book on Kuvempu’s speeches and essays was an attempt to understand the writer with respect to the time of his writing and the present.

Prof. Rajendra Chenni, retired professor of English, released the books. Prof. Sabita Bannadi, Prof. Meti Mallikarjuna, and V.L. Narasimhamurthy, writer and critic, spoke on the books released. B.R. Ravikanthe Gowda, IGP (Eastern Range), was present at the programme.

title: Woman’s mortal remains exhumed for murder investigation
content:
The mortal remains of a woman from Kanjapalli junction at Annur in Coimbatore were exhumed on Thursday as part of an investigation into her murder.

The police said that the mortal remains of V. Mayilathal, 70, of Kanjapalli junction were exhumed from a graveyard in the locality in the presence of a tahsildar and the police.

A team of four forensic surgeons from the Coimbatore Medical College Hospital, performed the post-mortem examination at the spot. Scientific team of the Coimbatore district police was also present. Samples from the mortal remains were collected for forensic analysis, the police said.

According to the police, Mayilathal was murdered by her grandson’s wife Joy Metilda, 27, and her paramour V. Nagesh, 25, of Mindigal village in Chintamani taluk of Chikkaballapura district in Karnataka, on April 5 this year.

Metilda had invited Nagesh to her residence on the night of April 5 when her husband was away. They murdered Mayilathal after she spotted them in a private moment. After Mayilathal was murdered, Metilda orchestrated it as a natural death and buried the body in a graveyard at Kanjapalli, said the police.

Metilda and Nagesh later attempted to eliminate the former’s husband by smothering him with pillows at the house on the night of October 23. The man survived the attempt and lodged a complaint with the police, leading to the arrest of Metilda and Nagesh. During questioning, the two accused confessed to the police about Mayilathal’s murder.

The investigation team led by Annur Inspector K. Selvan interrogated the two accused in custody recently, following which Mayilathal’s mortal remains were exhumed on Thursday. Further investigation is on.

title: District Collectors asked to assess cotton yield to make CCI revise per acre procurement
content:
Minister for Agriculture Tummala Nageswara Rao has requested the representatives of ginning mills not to create any problems to farmers in the matter for cotton procurement with an assurance that the State government would take their problems to the notice of the Cotton Corporation of India (CCI).

He made the plea in the wake of ginning mills’ decision to go on a strike from November 17 in support of their problems. He instructed the Secretary (Agriculture) to talk to the representatives of ginning mills again to ensure that the farming community did not face any problem in the sale of their produce.

Further, he asked the Secretary (Agriculture) to instruct the District Collectors to take up district-wise level field-level assessment of cotton yield. The Minister stated that the ginning mills have decided to go on strike protesting the CCI guidelines on procurement and they would cause huge losses.

At a time when the farming community were put to hardship by nature with untimely and excessive rains impacting the quality of their produce, the norm of accepting only 7 quintals of cotton per acre with minimum support price had pushed them into more troubles. After the rains, the farming community was feeling happy with bright sun helping reduce the moisture content in cotton and were hoping that the produce would give them good income.

However, the 7 quintals per acre norm of the CCI had pushed them into trouble again. The State government had written thrice to the CCI and Union Textiles Minister over the 7 quintals per acre procurement norm with a plea to allow at least 11 quintals per acre, but there was no response so far. Following the State’s request the Ministry of Textiles asked Telangana to assess the cotton yield to arrive at the district-wise average yield.

title: Sabarimala gold theft case: ED approaches HC for FIR details
content:
The Enforcement Directorate (ED) has approached the Kerala High Court for documents related to the alleged misappropriation of gold extracted from the Dwarapalakas idols and the door frames that lead to the Sreekovil of the Sabarimala Ayyappa temple.

Information available indicate the commission of serious offences under the Indian Penal Code and the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1988, which are listed as “scheduled offences” under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA).

The modus operandi shows that valuable temple property was illicitly diverted and its proceeds converted for personal gain, thereby giving rise to ‘proceeds of crime’ as defined under Section 2(1)(u) of the PMLA, it said in its plea.

The ED submitted that although it approached the Judicial First Class Magistrate Court, Ranni, in October seeking certified copies of the FIR and other details, its request was turned down, citing the sensitive nature of the case and by stating that the court was monitoring the case that was being probed by the SIT.

Being the sole authority competent to investigate money laundering activities linked to scheduled offences, the ED is duty bound to initiate inquiry under the said Act to trace, identify, and attach the proceeds of crime arising from the above criminal acts, it said.

The plea was posted for hearing on Monday.

title: Call for cultivation of coffee in Sampaje, Karike, Peraje, Chembu regions of Kodag
content:
With coffee enjoying a huge global demand, Coffee Board member T. Kishore Kumar emphasised the need for the cultivation of coffee alongside other crops in Sampaje, Karike, Peraje and Chembu regions of Kodagu district.

Farmers of Sampaje, Karike, Peraje, and Chembu regions, who mostly cultivate arecanut, rubber, and pepper, should consider taking up cultivation of coffee also alongside the existing crops, suggested Mr. Kishore Kumar while addressing the 72nd All India Co-operative Week held at Peraje Primary Agricultural Co-operative Soceity premises on Friday.

The 72nd All India Co-operative Week, organised jointly by Karnataka State Co-operative Federation, Kodagu District Co-operative Union, Kodagu District Co-operative Central Bank, and Co-operation Department at Peraju in Kodagu district, focused on promoting digitisation to enhance efficiency, accountability and transparency.

Mr. Kishore Kumar pointed out that the government was encouraging coffee cultivation by extending subsidies and incentives for the crop. India produces 3.60 lakh metric tonnes of coffee annually, of which 2.30 lakh metric tonnes are exported while the remaining is traded domestically, he said.

Karnataka accounts for about 60% to 65% of India’s annual coffee production, with Kodagu district alone contributing 30%-35% while the adjoining Chikmagaluru and Hassan districts contribute 25%-30%. Kerala, Tamil Nadu, and Andhra Pradesh together account for another 20%-30%, while the North Eastern States contributed about 10%-15%, he explained.

India earns about ₹15,000 crore in foreign exchange from coffee production, and the target is to reach ₹50,000 crore by 2047. He said the farmers can achieve this by reaching a production target of 7 lakh metric tonnes.

He emphasised that farmers should use drip irrigation and other methodologies to achieve high production at low cost.

With Karnataka’s coffee enjoying a huge demand, Mr. Kishore Kumar said there was a need to strengthen the co-operative sector so that loan facilities can be provided to the farmers and the economy can be strengthened.

Kodagu District Co-operative Central Bank President K P Ganapathy said there were a total of 288 co-operative societies operating in Kodagu district. Leaders of Kodagu district had established co-operatives for coffee, cardamom, honey and oranges.

Farmers receive easy loan facilities through co-operatives and must make proper use of them, he said while adding that the Co-operative Week provides an opportunity to discuss the strengths and shortcomings of the co-operative sector so that steps can be taken in the right direction.

During the co-operative week, a free health check-up camp was held. A market fair was also organized by members of Sanjeevini group, who sold vegetables and other items.

title: Police arrest accused on the run for 18 years
content:
After being on the run for 18 years, a key accused in a 2007 pesticide fraud case has been arrested by the Kalaburagi District Police.

Based on a complaint lodged by an Agriculture Department official stating that a three-member gang from Beed district in Maharashtra was illegally transporting pesticides to Motakpalli village in Sedam taluk and selling them causing losses to farmers and the State government, a case was registered by the Mudhol Police.

The police booked the three, Sophan Shesharao Tonde, Narayan and Siris, in September 2007 and filed a charge-sheet in March 2008.

While Narayan and Siris later appeared before court, Sophan Tonde, the prime accused, never attended any hearing. In 2016, the court declared the case as long pending.

Acting on the directions of Superintendent of Police Addur Srinivasalu, Additional Superintendent of Police Mahesh Meghannavar and Deputy Superintendent of Police Sangamanath Hiremath, a special team led by Mudhol Police Inspector Daulat N. Kuri intensified efforts to locate the absconding accused.

For the last four months, the team carried out surveillance across multiple locations in Maharashtra, constantly tracking Sophan Tonde’s movements and finally arrested him on Thursday in Chopanwadi village of Ambajogai taluk in Beed district.

Mr. Srinivasalu praised the team for the hard work and consistent efforts in arresting the long-absconding accused.

title: Digital Citizen Summit: Speakers flag deep barriers keeping women out of digital world
content:
Deep-rooted cultural barriers, male-dominated access points, and absence of safe, women-centric digital spaces were among the key concerns highlighted by speakers at the Digital Citizen Summit 2025 at T-Hub in Hyderabad on Friday. Speakers said that without women-led, community-driven networks, digital inclusion will remain uneven and exclusionary across South Asia.

Gayani Perera, project manager at Foundation.lk, a not-for-profit organisation based in Sri Lanka, spoke about how fear, surveillance and cyberbullying continue to keep women away from online spaces. Her organisation’s ‘Hitavathi’ centres, around 30 now operating across Sri Lanka, provide safe environments where women can learn, work and navigate the internet without judgement or intimidation. These spaces that work as help centres as well as e-learning platforms, have helped women rebuild confidence, acquire new skills and overcome long-held apprehensions about using technology, she said.

Hyderabad-based academic Sarbani Banerjee Belur said that connectivity projects often fail women because they overlook who actually ends up using digital access points. In many rural areas, she said, the spaces created for “community access” are quickly monopolised by young and older men, leaving women excluded, especially those who do not own mobile phones.

Mahima Sonal, working with Soochnapreneur - rural entrepreneurship-based project initiated by Digital Empowerment Foundation (DEF), from Utrakhand shared how community centres have transformed women’s livelihoods by helping them upskill, learn basic computing and take traditional handicraft work online. She said women engage more openly when guided by another woman, making female leadership critical for digital empowerment in rural areas.

Audience from Sri Lanka highlighted the “dual burden” that restricts women’s access to technology - domestic responsibilities combined with cultural conditioning that confines them to household roles.

Another member stressed the need for platforms where women can speak freely about issues including harassment, emotional distress and discrimination. “This initiative cannot just prevent instances of suicides in Sri Lankan women but can also help improve the emotional health of women,” the speaker said.

The session closed with a call to boost women in leadership roles in digital initiatives and to build networks that prioritise confidence, connection and equitable participation beyond profit-driven platform structures.

title: 'Cancer atlas' planned to map cancer burden across regions in A.P.
content:
A “Cancer Atlas” will soon be prepared for Andhra Pradesh, based on the cancer case registrations from all regions of the State, announced cancer specialist and advisor to the A.P. government Dr. Nori Dattatreyudu on Friday.

Chairing the fifth Advisory Meeting on Cancer Disease Burden at the Health and Family Welfare Department headquarters in Mangalagiri, Dr. Dattatreyudu said: “This atlas will be created using ground-level data, and will help in planning preventive strategies, raising public awareness and improving medical infrastructure. It will soon be submitted to Chief Minister N. Chandrababu Naidu and Health Minister Satya Kumar Yadav.”

Data from the government and private hospitals and from the Non-Communicable Diseases Control and Prevention Programme (NCD 4.0) screenings will be consolidated to prepare the atlas. Information from patients treated under the Dr. NTR Vaidya Seva Trust will provide a clearer picture of the regional cancer trends, he added.

He noted that organisations like Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) publish estimates based only on sample data, but the ongoing State-level data collection would produce reliable, ground-level statistics. He advised officials to ensure that there are no delays in referring screened individuals for further tests and insisted that details of treatment, wherever taken, should be recorded by the health staff.

He emphasised creating awareness about preventive oncology units in teaching hospitals and ensuring that patients coming from villages were given priority in these units through the “green channel”.

High case load in urban areas

CEO of Dr. NTR Vaidya Seva Trust Dinesh Kumar informed that cancer cases were predominantly higher in urban areas. Since the trust’s inception (2006–07), 3,29,183 cancer patients had received treatment under it, with the government spending ₹4,616 crore. Detailed reports are being prepared using these patient records, he said.

Director of Secondary Health K. Chakradhar Babu said nine day-care chemotherapy centres were currently operating in district hospitals, with patient numbers rising and more such centres would be established.

Health Commissioner Veerapandian, who joined the meeting virtually, said that the department would soon hold a special conference with private oncologists and that it was committed to implementing the suggestions given of Dr. Dattatreyudu.

Progress under NCD 4.0

NCD Programme Joint Director Shyamala said under NCD 4.0, 45.68 lakh oral cancer screenings had been conducted, breast and cervical cancer screenings for women were ongoing and individuals needing re-examination were being referred to PHC doctors, who then direct them to Preventive Oncology Units if necessary.

title: ‘Friends of Elephants’ teams to be formed in Tenkasi district to safely send invading animals back into forest
content:
The Tenkasi Forest Division has proposed to form ‘Friends of Elephants’ teams to avert human – wild animal conflict and the invasion of wild animals, especially elephants, into the farms close to the reserve forests of the Western Ghats.

According to District Forest Officer R. Raj Mohan, the ‘Friends of Elephants’ will be created with active community participation with each group having four members – a forest department member, a farmer and two wildlife enthusiasts from the local area having comprehensive knowledge about wildlife. Each team will be deployed in the areas where the wild animals, especially the elephants, frequently invade into the cultivable lands to damage standing crops.

These teams will be in touch with the Village Forest Committees and managed by the Forest Range Officer concerned. The team members, who will raise drum call alerts or raise noise to chase the elephants safely back into the forest and alert the farmers, will be paid incentives.

“The prime responsibility of these teams is to chase the crop-raiding elephants back into the forest unharmed,” Dr. Raj Mohan said.

Services of these teams will also be utilised for controlling forest fire, the DFO said.

title: Water to 18-canal suspended; farmers in Usilampatti upset
content:
Following the suspension of water from the Vaigai dam to the 18-canal project, which reached the tanks in Usilampatti in Madurai district, the farmers’ in the belt have expressed concern and demanded the government to immediately resume on Friday.

The Vaigai dam, which has a maximum storage level of 71 feet, would release the surplus water into the 18-canal on reaching its maximum level or whenever the water level crossed 70 feet. Depending on the forecast and the inflow into the reservoir, the WRD officials discharged the water.

Every year, the water from the dam would be released for the old ayacutdars of Ramanathapuram, Sivaganga and Madurai district. Similarly, water for irrigation and for drinking purposes, the water would be released. The surplus water from the reservoir would be released into the 58-canal as it would provide water for irrigation in the Usilampatti and surrounding habitations.

On October 29, the water was released in the 18-canal. However, it was suspended yesterday (Nov 14). “We are upset as the water was released only for 17 days, farmers said and expressed concern. The T.N. government should release water as and when the storage level crossed the 67 feet mark and not stick to the rule of discharging the surplus water for us....” they said.

The farmers’ associations in Usilampatti block fought for many decades and got the 18-canal project. Under such circumstances, only when the canal received water, the farmers’ would benefit. Such suspension in the midway would be of no use to the ryots as 150 cusecs of water discharged was insufficient. Hence, the T.N. government should issue an order to the effect that water shall be released in the 18-canal as and when the storage level reached 67 feet, they added.

title: Children’s Day: Mysuru Zoo, Dasara expo offer free entry to children
content:
Hundreds of children thronged the Mysuru Zoo and the Dasara Exhibition Grounds on Friday as both venues offered free entry to mark Children’s Day.

Many students arrived in their school uniforms, accompanied by teachers, taking advantage of the zoo’s free entry for children till noon. Long queues were seen in front of the zoo, whose gates opened around 8.30 a.m.

Excitement was evident on the children’s faces as they moved around the enclosures, observing various animals and birds housed in the zoo. The free entry was restricted to children below 12 years of age. Zoo offers free entry to children every year to mark the day.

As in previous years, the Dasara Exhibition Grounds also offered free entry on the occasion. After their zoo visit, many children headed to the exhibition, where they were welcomed with chocolates and flowers. Snacks and oranges were also distributed to mark the celebrations.

Some games at the exhibition were made free for children as part of the special arrangements.

title: Bihar election results: A women-powered victory for Nitish Kumar
content:
Two posters tell the story of Bihar’s 2025 elections for Chief Minister Nitish Kumar and his party, the Janata Dal (United). The first — “25 se 30, phir se Nitish (From 2025 to 2030, it is Nitish’s government again)” — appeared in May, long before the campaign gathered steam. The second — “Tiger Abhi Zinda Hai (Tiger is still alive)” — was erected a day before the results were declared.

Also read | Women’s vote, governance record and alliance cohesion drive NDA victory

The first one was an assertion as well as a reflection of the JD(U)’s anxiety. There were reports of Mr. Kumar’s declining mental acuity. There was also speculation that he will be replaced, with the BJP promoting its nominee instead. The poster with Mr. Kumar, in a blue Nehru jacket, placed against a yellow background with the slogan inscribed in black, was to underline Mr. Kumar as the undisputed Chief Minister. However, Mr. Kumar’s administration needed a little more than just rhetoric.

It was around this time that the seeds for the Mukhyamantri Mahila Rozgar Yojana were sown. In his first term, Mr. Kumar began a network of women self-help groups under the World Bank-aided Bihar Rural Livelihoods Project (BRLP), locally known as Jeevika. This network has seen Mr. Kumar through various ups and downs.

His administration decided to tap into this network once again. A one-time ₹10,000 financial aid was extended to 1.21 crore beneficiaries associated with Jeevika. It cost ₹12,100 crore, which is roughly 4% of Bihar’s annual budget.

Careful consolidation of women voters

The administration looked at various schemes extending financial aid to women, including Maharashtra’s Ladki Bahin Yojana, a monthly payout scheme which is straining the State’s finances. It was a deliberate decision, according to top JD(U) leaders, to opt for extending an one-time financial assistance instead of monthly payouts.

The scheme was rolled out on September 26 by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, and the election schedule was announced by the Election Commission of India (EC) on October 6.

The gamble paid off. The scheme consolidated women voters across caste lines, delivering anticipated dividends for the JD(U) and the NDA. The JD(U) was the only party to report a significant rise in vote share — from 15.39% in 2020 to 19.03%. The BJP’s share rose only marginally, from 19.46% to 20.42%. This marks Mr. Kumar’s second-best performance after 2010, when the JD(U) won 115 of 141 seats contested. As per the provisional voter turnout data released by the EC, 2.51 crore women voted in this election.

The table below shows the number of seats/districts with various shares of women voters in the 2025 Bihar Assembly Elections.

(Scroll right to see the full table)

Women-centric schemes

“It would be simplistic to credit the Mukhyamantri Mahila Rozgar Yojana alone for the JD(U)’s performance. People voted for Nitish Kumar’s experience, clean image, good governance, law and order, and progress,” said JD(U) national spokesperson K.C. Tyagi. Mr. Tyagi pointed out various women-centric schemes of the Nitish Kumar government. “Kumar has had a generational connection with women. In 2006, he first gave reservation to women representatives in panchayat and municipal bodies; in 2007, he gave 35% reservation to women in the Bihar Police. His government pays for stationary and uniforms for girl children. The decision to impose prohibition also came directly from the women,” he added.

On October 12, six days after the election schedule was announced, the NDA finalised its seat-sharing formula. For the first time since Mr. Kumar aligned with the BJP in the mid-1990s, both parties contested an equal number of seats — 101 each.

From then on, the narrative shifted. Reports emerged of Mr. Kumar reprimanding close aides for undermining party interests, some of which played out publicly at rallies. He also pressured the BJP to make the Lok Janshakti Party (Ram Vilas) return four to five seats allocated to it but claimed by the JD(U) — signalling that Mr. Kumar was still firmly in control.

A day before the results, the JD(U)’s Patna office unveiled the poster reading “Tiger Abhi Zinda Hai.” Sponsored by a party leader, it carried the clutter typical of election posters — still its assertion was vindicated.

title: Plea to open combined Collectorate building in Tenkasi for public utility
content:
The Madurai Bench of the Madras High Court on Friday ordered notice to the State on a public interest litigation petition that sought a direction to the government to take necessary steps to open the Tenkasi Collectorate for public utility.

A Division Bench of Justices Anita Sumanth and C. Kumarappan was hearing a petition filed by Rama Udayasuriyan of Avudaiyanoor in Tenkasi district. The petitioner sought a direction to the authorities to open the Collectorate and make it fully functional.

Considering the long standing demand of the people of Tenkasi, he said, Tenkasi district was formed in 2019 by bifurcating Tirunelveli district with the Headquarters at Tenkasi. Since government offices were functioning in rental buildings in the newly formed district, the State government proposed to construct a combined Collectorate building with space for all offices.

Accordingly, the State government sanctioned ₹119 crore for the construction of the combined Collectorate building in 2020. The construction work was entrusted to the Public Works Department. The construction work commenced in 2021 and 90% work was completed.

Under these circumstances, S.P. Muthuraman filed a petition before the High Court in 2022 complaining about violation of building and environmental norms. The court, after hearing the parties, found that the construction of the Collectorate building commenced before obtaining the necessary environmental clearances.

Considering the larger public interest, the court in 2022 directed the Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board to expeditiously dispose of the application submitted by the PWD for environmental clearances.

However, TNPCB did not honour the order of the court. PWD, who is duty bound to urge TNPCB to comply with the order, also did not take any efforts. The building is now abandoned. The authorities have caused a huge financial loss to the State’s exchequer. The authorities remained idle and were not taking necessary steps to get the environmental clearance and open the building for public utility, he complained. The court posted the matter for hearing to December 17.

title: VOC Port records 3.94 million tonnes cargo handling in October 2025
content:
V. O. Chidambaranar (VOC) Port handled 3.94 million tonnes of cargo during October 2025, which includes 75,110 TEUs of containers, registering a 10.94% and 20.83% increase respectively.

During the same period last year, the port handled only 3.55 million tonnes and 62,158 TEUs.

In the current financial year until October, the port has handled 25.23 million tonnes of cargo, including 5,03,204 TEUs of containers, representing a 2.71% growth in overall cargo traffic and an 8.44% increase in container traffic.

The port’s performance is further highlighted by the rise in ship calls, with 1,064 vessels handled up to October 2025 as against 1,004 vessels during the corresponding period of the previous year. In addition to the growth in cargo and container handling, the container vessels average Turnaround Time (TRT) improved from 20.16 hours to 19.20 hours, among the best performer ports across India.

Commenting on the achievement, Susanta Kumar Purohit, IRSEE, Chairperson, stated that the sustained growth across all sectors reflects the port’s strong performance, enhanced efficiency and customer-centric approach. He emphasised that the port will continue to focus on infrastructure augmentation, digital transformation and green initiatives to further strengthen its position as a key driver of maritime trade and economic development in the region.

title: Cyberabad police arrest four in nationwide crackdown, initiate refund of nearly ₹22 lakh
content:
The cybercrime wing of the Cyberabad police arrested four suspects operating different financial rackets across multiple States after detecting three cases between November 6 and 11.

Officers said three arrests were linked to trading scams, while one involved a smishing (SMS phishing) operation. Five mobile phones, a smartwatch, SIM cards and other digital devices were seized during the raids.

Police also secured 42 refund orders in 26 cases, amounting to ₹21,98,753, which will be returned to victims following court directions.

Among the major cases was the cheating of a private employee who lost ₹21,93,300 in a fake trading scam run through Telegram and WhatsApp groups. The victim was approached by a woman identifying herself as Ben Sasha, who lured him into using a fraudulent trading app and encouraged him to make trial trades that showed artificially inflated profits. Once he gained confidence, scammers guided him to deposit money into bank accounts they claimed were linked to a foreign exchange trading platform.

The victim initially received two small withdrawals of ₹5,000, which were used to build trust. He was then persuaded to invest larger amounts and was shown fictitious profits running into crores. When he attempted to withdraw funds, he was pressured to pay a series of charges, including a 30% tax, security deposit and conversion fee. Later, he was told his CIBIL score was inadequate and was asked to transfer an additional ₹15 lakh. When he questioned these demands, the suspects deleted his trading account and chat history, leaving him with a virtual balance that never existed.

Investigators confirmed he had transferred ₹21,93,300 from his bank accounts into several beneficiary accounts. A transaction of ₹90,000 led officers to two suspects, identified as Thummaluru Sudhakar Reddy and Thummaluru Raghunatha Reddy, who allegedly provided bank accounts used in the scam. They were arrested based on technical evidence and field verification.

Cyberabad police urged people not to trust unverified investment groups on WhatsApp or Telegram, and to avoid downloading trading apps shared by unknown individuals. Officers advised citizens to verify platforms on SEBI’s website and report suspicious activity immediately to 1930 or the national cybercrime portal.

title: Govt. committed to transforming TG into hub of scientific progress: Bhatti
content:
The government is committed to transforming the State into a hub of scientific progress, said Deputy Chief Minister Mallu Bhatti Vikramarka at the Vijnana Darshini meeting held at Ravindra Bharathi on Friday.

Speaking as the chief guest at the 80th Scientific Temperament celebrations, he emphasised that Chief Minister A. Revanth Reddy’s administration is dedicated to nurturing scientific thinking across the State. The government aims to develop Telangana as a “laboratory for scientific development”, he said, noting that all Cabinet ministers are well educated and focused on ensuring the State competes globally in innovation and growth.

He credited India’s scientific foundations to Jawaharlal Nehru, stating that the nation’s current position would have been unimaginable without Nehru’s leadership as the first Prime Minister.

Reflecting on India’s early challenges after Independence, he highlighted Nehru’s focus on agriculture, industry, and mixed economic policies, along with his encouragement of scientific research through institutions like IITs, the UGC, and national laboratories. This vision, he said, laid the groundwork for India’s democratic stability and technological advancement.

“In the early 1980s, if I wanted to make a phone call, I had to go to Abids, book a trunk call, and wait for hours. Today, we are connected to the entire world through a mobile phone in our palm. This is the power of scientific progress,” he said. “If during disasters people are only told to light lamps or clap hands, this country would have gone astray,” he commented.

He noted that because of Nehru’s visionary policies, a peaceful transition of power was possible, after elections every five years. But, he remarked that societies become cursed when they are governed by people without vision.

Mr. Vikramarka outlined the ongoing initiatives such as the establishment of Young India Integrated Residential Schools in each Assembly constituency and the upgrading of ITIs into Advanced Technology Centres.

He added that the upcoming Skill University will further strengthen scientific temperament in Telangana’s emerging Future City. He encouraged educational institutions to launch science exhibitions and assured them full support from government.

Nehru’s ideals of democracy and scientific progress remain the guiding force for India’s future, he said.

title: HACKKSHETRA 2.0 launched at VVCE in Mysuru
content:
Rajneesh Sharma, centre head, Incture Technologies, Bengaluru, on Friday, urged engineering students to come up with innovations tailored for India’s unique needs.

Speaking after inaugurating HACKKSHETRA 2.0, a 24-hour national-level hackathon organised by the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Vidyavardhaka College of Engineering (VVCE), Mr. Sharma, while sharing experiences from his Himalayan treks, described how his visits to remote villages realised the urgent need for technology-driven solutions, especially in healthcare.

He encouraged students to explore opportunities in sectors such as agriculture, water management, and household automation—ranging from smart irrigation systems to sensor-based indoor plant care. “India still needs a tremendous amount of innovations. The possibilities are vast, and your ideas can truly shape the country’s future,” he added.

Hanumantrao Kulkarni, Senior Manager, Learning and Development, Incture Technologies, highlighted that the world today requires both thinkers and doers. “AI bridges the gap between ideation and execution, enabling everyone to become both,” he said.

Addressing the gathering, principal B. Sadashive Gowda said hackathons play a vital role in enhancing students’ creativity, problem-solving ability, and logical thinking—skills that industries expect but seldom taught directly.

He spoke about India’s rise in global innovation rankings and stressed the need for the country to transition from a service-based economy to a product-driven one. “Innovative young minds like yours can lead this transformation by converting ideas into impactful products,” he said.

He also mentioned that next month VVCE will be hosting the national-level Smart India Hackathon.

This year, more than 400 teams from engineering colleges across the state registered for the hackathon, out of which 65 teams were shortlisted. With the All India Council for Technical Education (AICTE) declaring 2025 as the Year of Artificial Intelligence, the event aims to push students to create AI-driven solutions in agriculture, education, healthcare, and IoT. Expert jury members from various industries will evaluate the projects, and winners will receive cash awards.

Gundappa Gowda, president, Vidyavardhaka Sangha; Shobha Shankar, vice-principal; Pooja M. R., professor and head, CSE; and others were present.

title: Sugarcane farmers end strike in Mudhol after Minister, leaders hold talks
content:
Following a meeting in Bagalkot on Friday with factory managements and district in-charge Minister R.B. Thimmapur, sugarcane farmers ended their two-week-long strike for higher prices in Mudhol.

This comes a day after an incident of sabotage where several tractor trolleys were set on fire in front of the Godavari Bio-refineries sugar factory in Sameerwadi of Bagalkot district.

Farmers dropped their demand for ₹3,500 per tonne of sugarcane and agreed to settle for the government-fixed price of ₹3,300 per tonne, to be paid in three instalments. They, however, demanded that the factories settle old dues of around ₹20 crore, to sugarcane growers in four days.

They also demanded that all bills be settled in two weeks from procurement.

Mr. Thimmapur announced in Bagalkot on Friday that the meeting was successful and that the agitation has been withdrawn.

The protest continued as several rounds of meetings held by Mr. Thimmapur, Deputy Commissioner Sangappa and others failed.

On Thursday, as per initial estimates, 100 loads of sugarcane crop, 20 tractor trolleys and four tractors suffered damage.

Farmers leaders thanked the Minister and the police for their cooperation during the protest in Mudhol. They apologized to Additional Superintendent of Police Mahanteshwar Jiddi who suffered injuries during the protest and has been admitted to hospital for treatment.

title: NSA Doval invites Bangladesh counterpart to Colombo Security Conclave in Delhi
content:
In a bid to broaden security dialogue amidst continued tension with Bangladesh, National Security Adviser Ajit Doval will host Bangladesh interim government’s National Security Adviser Khalilur Rahman next week. An announcement from the Press Office of the Chief Adviser of Bangladesh said on Friday that, upon invitation from Mr. Doval, Mr. Rahman will lead the Bangladesh delegation at the Colombo Security Conclave to be held during November 19-20 in New Delhi.

“His participation at the Colombo Security Conclave in New Delhi is in continuation of the Interim Government’s efforts to foster mutually beneficial regional cooperation,” the Chief Adviser’s Press Wing said, announcing Mr. Rahman’s first visit to India since he took charge as NSA on April 9, 2025. Mr. Rahman earlier served as the Chief Adviser’s High Representative for the Rohingya Issue.

“The Interim Government emphasizes regional cooperation as a priority and has actively participated in meetings of various regional bodies,” the Press Office said. Mr. Rahman has been a proponent of extending humanitarian assistance to the people of Myanmar’s Rakhine province and has championed the ‘humanitarian corridor’ to support civilians in the conflict-affected region.

In recent months, Mr. Rahman has emerged as a key diplomat for the interim government of Bangladesh and has often represented the country in exchanges with counterparts and partners in the United States, Qatar, China, and other nations.

title: Naidu links Bihar mandate to demand for development, stresses reforms at finance summit
content:
Hailing the NDA’s landslide victory in Bihar, Chief Minister N. Chandrababu Naidu said the mandate reflected the people’s aspiration for development, welfare and good governance.

Mr. Naidu participated as the chief guest at the Andhra Pradesh Reimagining Public Finance Summit held at a private hotel in Visakhapatnam on Friday, on the sidelines of the ongoing CII Partnership Summit. Stressing the importance of delivering welfare schemes, he said: “I had satisfied my people by extending welfare schemes. Today, you have seen the Bihar election results. The NDA won 209 seats — something unprecedented in Bihar. It indicates that people want development, empowerment, welfare and good governance. With this comes stability, and stability will lead to further progress in welfare.”

Organised by the State Finance Department in collaboration with Elets Technomedia, the two-day summit aims to build a forward-looking framework for fiscal innovation, sustainable capital mobilisation, PPP-led development and institutional transformation.

Mr. Naidu underscored the need to adopt reforms that pave the way for public welfare and said that his government’s policy decisions have resulted in development and benefits for poor and middle-class people. He said policies must be adapted to changing circumstances, citing Hyderabad as an example of development achieved through policy reforms. The reforms in the power sector introduced in 1999, he noted, strengthened the sector, and Telangana continues to reap the benefits.

Further, he said the State government would open escrow accounts for industrial incentives and extend sovereign guarantees to investors.

Mr. Naidu said he has envisioned a transformative roadmap for the State through Swarna Andhra 2047. Recalling how he was often described as a leader ahead of his time, he said his early decision to champion Information Technology — treating IT as a public-policy priority when few recognised its potential — laid strong digital, knowledge and power-sector foundations that continue to benefit the State today.

title: Digital Citizen Summit: AI reshaping work, governance and public life
content:
A workshop titled “Let’s Build Our Commons AI: Public and Just”, held at the 7th Digital Citizen Summit in T-Hub, examined how Artificial Intelligence is reshaping work, governance and public life, and argued for AI to be treated as a shared public resource rather than a private monopoly.

The session was organised by Commons Collective and led by digital journalist Roshna Arafa Ali, Rajasekhar P, operations, Ottocomm, and researcher Gaya Hadiya, with Siddhartha Malempati, directing council general, Commons Collective, moderating the discussion.

The speakers said AI’s rapid spread into professional, political and personal spaces had collided with long-existing workplace systems already stacked against employees. Roshna argued that job losses blamed on AI were often the result of employers using the technology as a convenient justification to hire fewer people, cut costs and avoid providing benefits.

“Mid-level roles such as database administrators, IT specialists and data analysts, were among those most vulnerable to AI driven restructuring,” she said, and added that workplaces were far from ideal even before AI arrived.

“Many industries had long normalised unhealthy competition, overwork and a reluctance to collectively demand safer conditions. Within this context, AI has become an attractive tool for companies wanting to replace labour that requires rest and rights with machines that require neither.” This strain, she noted, was already pushing women and marginalised communities further away from formal employment.

The workshop also highlighted the hidden labour that keeps AI systems functioning, from large scale data extraction that takes place without genuine consent to poorly paid content labelling and maintenance work. Gaya Hadiya described this as a form of undervalued and often invisible labour that sustains the technology while benefiting only a narrow set of corporate owners.

The discussion moved to emerging ethical concerns, including companies exploring the use of AI as workplace or student counsellors. Panelists questioned whether an AI funded by an employer would ever advise an employee to confront overwork, form a collective or demand better conditions. “Instead such systems may simply push individuals to cope better so that productivity remains uninterrupted,” said Rajashekar.

“Human intelligence is relational, emotional and grounded in live experience, and cannot be reduced to pattern prediction,” he said.

The session also examined questions of governance and accountability. “These resources are inherently public and should not be enclosed by private entities. Governance must identify who sets the purpose and limits of AI systems and who should be held responsible when these systems cause harm,” he added.

The workshop closed by urging broader public engagement with AI governance. Speakers said discussions on ethics and regulation cannot remain confined to engineers or industry professionals, since the consequences of AI extend far beyond the technology sector. They called for collective participation and transparent rule making to ensure that AI serves society at large, not just those who control its infrastructure.

title: Indian military heritage festival 2025 begins; Minister stresses need to preserve military legacy
content:
The third edition of the Indian Military Heritage Festival began on Friday (November 14, 2025), with Minister of State for Defence Sanjay Seth underscoring the importance of preserving and learning from India’s military past.

“Our history is our heritage, and we must preserve it in books and learn from it to further strengthen our military might,” Mr. Seth said at the inaugural session of the two-day event (November 14 and 15). “This festival gives us an opportunity to connect with our glorious military traditions and heroic tales and inspire us for the future.”

Addressing the gathering, Mr. Seth said that understanding India’s military history is not just a matter of pride but a way to build a stronger foundation for self-reliance and national security.

Emphasising the need for a resilient domestic defence ecosystem, he noted that increasing participation from industry and young innovators reflects the nation’s collective resolve to boost long-term strategic capability and expand global defence engagement.

During the event, the Minister released several key publications, including Shukra Niti: Statecraft and Warfare, Honours and Awards of the Indian Armed Forces, and a volume marking 75 years of India’s peacekeeping efforts.

The festival features panel discussions, exhibitions, and interactive sessions aimed at enhancing public understanding of India’s military heritage and linking it to contemporary national security priorities.

title: Rainwater harvesting awareness rally taken out
content:
A few hundred school children participated in the water harvesting awareness rally organised here by the TWAD Board on Friday.

After District Collector A. K. Kamal Kishore flagged off the rally at the District Collectorate, the students reached the ICE Government Boys’ Higher Secondary School via new bus stand.

The rallyists carried rainwater harvesting awareness placards and distributed awareness pamphlets.

title: Kerala local body polls projected to generate over 6,700 tonnes of waste
content:
The State Election Commission, which is making a hard pitch for ‘green’ local body elections in 2025, says the polls are likely to generate about 6,711 tonnes of non-biodegradable waste. This would include around 1,800 tonnes of banners and hoardings, 1,400 tonnes of flags and festoons, 1,826 tonnes of plastic bottles, and 1,685 tonnes of disposable cups, plates and banned plastic sachets and products.

The projection, part of a ‘Handbook on Green Local Body Elections 2025’ released by State Election Commissioner A. Shajahan here on Friday, is based on the assumption that the 2025 edition of the elections would have 1,17,880 candidates in 23,576 wards in 1199 local bodies. The commission is also planning to have 33,746 polling stations, which would adhere to green protocol as per the panel’s guidelines.

Releasing the book here, Mr. Shajahan said the message for the upcoming elections is, ‘Vote by protecting the earth.’ The book, which deals with various aspects of the green protocol for elections, has been prepared by the commission with the assistance of the Local Self-Governments department and the Suchitwa Mission.

Election campaign materials should be made of eco-friendly materials such as cotton cloth or materials that can be recycled, the commission said. The commission has also urged the candidates to use digital options and eco-friendly materials such as bamboo, grass mats, coconut palm fronds and cane as far as possible for their campaigns.

Flags and festoons should be made of cloth or paper. Garlands made of plastic also should be avoided, the commission has told political parties and the candidates.

title: MoUs worth ₹3.49 lakh crore reached on Day-1 of CII Partnership Summit in Visakhapatnam
content:
A flurry of major investment commitments made by some Singapore-based and Indian companies at the two-day CII Partnership Summit-2025 that commenced here on Friday gave a big boost to Andhra Pradesh’s industrial landscape.

It has been announced that investments amounting to ₹3,49,476 crore have been tied up with 40 companies in diverse sectors on Day-1 of the event.

The biggest ones among them are an agreement by the Reliance Industries Limited (RIL) to set up a 1- Gigawatt Artificial Intelligence (AI) Data Centre and a 6 GWp solar power project to power it, and to build a greenfield integrated food park in the parched Rayalaseema region.

According to an official release, the RIL Data Centre is going to be a fully modular, future-ready facility designed to host the world’s most advanced GPUs, TPUs, and Al processors, and it will operate as a twin to the company’s Gigawatt-scale Al Data Centre in Jamnagar, Gujarat, together forming one of Asia’s strongest Al infrastructure networks.

The supporting solar project will double the State’s current ground-mounted solar capacity, contributing to over 30% of its renewable energy.

In another significant move, the Government of AP inked pacts with the Singapore government and a few companies in the areas of urban governance, real-time data collection and monitoring, digital governance transformation, sustainable development, and for operating flights between Vijayawada and Singapore thrice a week, in the presence of Singapore Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law K. Shanmugam and Minister of State for Foreign Affairs Gan Siow Huang.

Mr. Shanmugam said the Singapore Government would see to it that the MoUs took tangible shape at the earliest by placing them before the Joint Implementation Steering Committee.

ONO Keiichi, Ambassador of Japan to India and Bhutan, said Japan was keen on investing in the steel manufacturing sector, wherein ArcelorMittal-Nippon Steel had already firmed up construction of a mega steel plant project in Anakapalli district.

Adani Ports & SEZ Limited MD Karan Adani expressed resolve to scale up the company’s investments in AP from the present ₹40,000 crore to over ₹1 lakh crore in 10 years, mostly in data centers, seaports, and cement manufacturing.

​GMR Group Chairman Grandhi Mallikarjuna Rao said construction of the Bhogapuram International Airport (BIA) in Vizianagaram district would be completed by June 2026, which was six months ahead of the committed schedule, and announced the development of an integrated aerospace ecosystem in the State, including a MRO facility at the BIA.

​Bharat Forge Joint MD Amit Kalyani expressed interest to invest in building a shipbuilding complex at Visakhapatnam, citing its infrastructure and logistical advantages, and in defence manufacturing.

title: Restoration of flood damaged Authoor bridge begins at an outlay of ₹4.50 crore
content:
The National Highways (NH) department has begun preparatory works to restore the Authoor new bridge at an estimated cost of around ₹4.50 crore. The bridge was damaged during the 2023 floods.

Built in 2014, the central span of the bridge across the Tamirabharani river connecting Mukkani and North Authoor was severely damaged, making the structure unsafe for vehicular traffic. Before the damage, the new bridge was used by vehicles approaching Thoothukudi, while the old bridge was used by the vehicles heading towards Tiruchendur.

Since the damage was reported, the old bridge has been used as a two way route, leading to congestion during peak hours and festival days. Almost after two years the restoration work has begun at the new bridge, for which the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways has allocated ₹4.77 crore for the project.

A few months ago, the officials from the NH department said that experts from IIT-Madras were involved in preparing restoration plans for the bridge, and the project would commence after the government approval.

Speaking about the project, an engineer from the NH said that the 260 metre bridge has 14 spans and crumbling damages were reported in two piers in the central portion, leading to a cave-in of the structure.

Explaining that the bridge has been constructed in a pier model, he noted that the NH department has been undertaking restoration measures based on the recommendations of an expert team from IIT-Madras. He added that the team has recommended the stabilisation of sunken pillars along with all the pillar and elevation of dented decks.

“Although ₹4.77 crore has been allocated for the project, after the deduction of GST and other service costs, the bridge will be constructed at an outlay of around ₹4.50 crore. The work is expected to be completed in nine months, with full-fledged work beginning next week” he said.

title: Ex-TTD Trust Board chairman Bhumana demands CBI probe into Satish Kumar’s death
content:
Former Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD) Trust Board chairman Bhumana Karunakar Reddy on Friday (November 14, 2025) demanded a CBI probe under the supervision of the Supreme Court into the suspicious death of former TTD Assistant Vigilance and Security Officer (AVSO) Satish Kumar.

Speaking to media persons in Tirupati on Friday, Mr. Karunakar Reddy said Mr. Satish Kumar was relentlessly harassed, threatened, and mentally tortured by the investigating agency on the name of investigation in the Parakamani theft case, ultimately driving him to suicide.
