title: Assam Minister's 'Bihar approves Gobi farming' shocker after NDA landslide
content:
After NDA's landslide win in Bihar, Assam Minister Ashok Singhal shared a photo of cauliflower field with the caption, "Bihar approves Gobi farming." The photo, many social media users believed, infamously refers to the "cauliflower burial case" or the Logain massacre, a brutal incident that occurred during the 1989 Bhagalpur communal riots in Bihar.

Over 100 Muslims were killed, their bodies buried in a field with cauliflower saplings planted over them to hide the evidence.

advertisement

Since then, images of cauliflowers have often been used to evoke the Logain massacre. Recently, in March 2025, amid the Nagpur violence, some right-wing social media handles shared images of cauliflowers. In May 2025, Karnataka BJP's official account on X posted a meme celebrating the killing of Maoists in Chhattisgarh, which also carried the cauliflower reference.

The Assam Minister's post left social media users in disbelief over the sheer reference to the brutal massacre. One user, giving context, wrote, “Context: The image of a cauliflower field posted by BJP's Assam minister has been used by Hindu extremists to glorify the mass killing of Muslims in Bhagalpur in 1989, with cauliflowers planted on the burial site to hide evidence.”

One user commented, “No way this coming from a cabinet minister of Assam.” Another wrote, “Is this an official handle bcoz no way they just said that.” A third comment read, “What?? Really? I thought this is a parody account.”

WHAT HAPPENED IN LOGAN

The violence began on 24 October 1989 and continued for two months, engulfing Bhagalpur city and 250 surrounding villages. Over 1,000 people were killed, around 900 of them Muslims, and another 50,000 were displaced. It was the worst instance of Hindu-Muslim violence in independent India at the time.

At the village of Logain, 116 Muslims were reportedly killed by a 4,000-strong mob. Their bodies were buried and covered with cauliflower and cabbage saplings to conceal the deaths. AK Singh, IAS, then Bhagalpur’s special ADM (law and order), was the officer who uncovered the gruesome crime nearly 25 days after the bodies had been buried.

Rooted in rising tensions around the Ram Janmabhoomi movement, it was one of independent India’s deadliest episodes of communal violence. As the VHP’s Ramshila processions moved through Bhagalpur to collect bricks for the proposed Ram temple in Ayodhya, the district was already rife with incendiary rumours alleging the killing of Hindu students. Political and criminal rivalries further sharpened the atmosphere.

advertisement

The immediate trigger came on 24 October, when a massive Ramshila procession reached the Muslim-dominated Tatarpur area. While an earlier procession had passed peacefully, the second one saw provocative slogans. As officials attempted to negotiate a route, crude bombs were thrown from the nearby Muslim high school, injuring policemen. Police firing followed, killing two people, and the procession quickly turned into a mob that targeted Muslim shops. Retaliatory violence escalated across Bhagalpur, with attacks, arson and killings multiplying over the next days.

Entire localities were ravaged. Massacres unfolded in full public view: 18 Muslims, including 11 children, were butchered inside Bhagalpur’s Nayabazar; 61 bodies were recovered from a pond in Chandheri; and in Logain, 116 Muslims were murdered.

The official toll recorded 1,070 dead, thousands displaced, and widespread destruction of homes, looms and places of worship. Subsequent commissions blamed police inaction and political failures, while decades of trials, acquittals, sporadic convictions and delayed compensation left survivors alleging that justice was neither swift nor complete.

- Ends

title: Kidnappings, rapes, guns: Bihar jungle raj stories flood X after RJD poll rout
content:
It has been nearly two decades since Lalu Prasad Yadav's rule in Bihar ended in 2005. An entire generation of voters, including Gen Z, has not seen Lalu or his RJD in power. Yet, stories of alleged lawlessness and kidnappings during his regime live on. As the NDA again swept to power in the assembly elections, the 'jungle raj' taint against the RJD remains unchanged, and it seems, his son, Tejashwi, is having to bear its brunt.

advertisement

On Friday, as the NDA secured an emphatic victory, routing the RJD-led Mahagathbandhan, several natives from Bihar, mostly 90s kids, flooded social media with their personal memories of Lalu raj. Those who grew up during the turbulent 1990s recounted how lawlessness and the threat of kidnappings shaped their childhoods.

'HAD TO LEAVE HOME AT AGE OF 15'

Another section, who left Bihar years ago, recounted how their families sent them to boarding schools to escape the deteriorating civic order in Lalu Prasad's Bihar.

"Lalu Yadav was the reason why me and countless people like me had to leave home even before the age of 15, first for education and then for jobs. Those who left Bihar grew up while staying away from their parents. Even during festivals, many times we had to stay alone in some hostel," a social media user with the username EngiNerd tweeted.

He pointed out that such was the damage Lalu did to Bihar that even after 20 years of anti-incumbency against Nitish, people were coming out in record numbers to prevent the return of the RJD chief and his son.

"This man can't destroy the happiness of two generations of people and have his son become a chief minister and enjoy his family moments. Massive loss of Lalu Yadav in this election is a personal victory for me," he further said.

Another user, Ashish Bhutada, recalled seeing people casually roaming around with guns on Bihar streets in 1993 when he went there from Maharashtra.

Another alleged that rapes were common during Lalu's reign. "It has been left unreported due to fear of lynching by RJD's goons. I am glad that Lalu is alive to see this," the user, Saral Nahar, said.

THE ORIGINS OF 'JUNGLE RAJ'

'Jungle raj' became a part of Bihar's political lexicon in 1997 after a judge of the Patna High Court remarked while hearing a petition on poor civic conditions in Patna.

"It is worse than the jungle raj and there is no regard to court directions and public interest," the court had said. Since then, the term has stuck to the RJD, and the opposition has revived it in subsequent elections to corner Lalu and his party.

advertisement

One of the most gruesome incidents during Lalu's regime was the killing of around 60 members of the Dalit community by an upper caste group in 1997 in Jehanabad.

The 'jungle raj' term has come to haunt Lalu and his family on several occassions, following his name cropping up in the fodder scam cases and the land-for-jobs scandal.

This year, NDA leaders and Prime Minister Narendra Modi used the narrative to full effect, referring to Tejashwi as "jungle raj ka yuvraj" to attack the RJD over lawlessness as well as dynastic politics.

Several Bihar natives also summed up the compromises their families made to ensure their children's safety during Lalu's tenure.

"Thousands of 90s kids who had to live away from their parents in boarding schools just to avoid getting kidnapped, thousands who had to forfeit their ancestral land as a bribe to get a clerical job, millions who studied hard under a lantern or a petromax to somehow escape the jungle raj," another user tweeted.

"All of them, across the world, doing well, now looking at their phone screens and the numbers, and smiling. This is victory," he further said.

advertisement

Another user, Savitha Rao, narrated how her friend from Bihar was put in a boarding school at the age of 6.

"He would say that when he went home, his dad's men would come to the station to pick him up. And they would have rifles... Later, I realised those with means were forced to do it to protect their lives," Rao tweeted.

Another recounted how he was directed to stay put at the railway station at night despite his train arriving on time.

"I remember being instructed to stay put at the railway station near the RPF post till sunrise. This being the case, when my house was in the same town. I had to stay at the station for 3 hours before my father came to pick me up," he said.

It seems, despite 20 years since the end of RJD rule, the people of Bihar have not yet come out of the fear of Lalu Prasad Yadav's 'jungle raj', which is clearly evident from the decisive mandate against the party. It is this distress among the people of Bihar that the NDA pounced on to secure a two-thirds majority.

- Ends

Published By: Abhishek De Published On: Nov 14, 2025

title: Bihar has made clear people are not with those out on bail: PM after NDA's win
content:

title: Tagore wanted just two stanzas of Vande Mataram, Gandhi compared chant to Allahu Akbar
content:
Weeks after the launch of the collaborative Non Cooperation-Khilafat movement in 1920, MK Gandhi (later called the Mahatma) was touring Madras (now Chennai). The slogans that greeted him left him discomfited. Having led the freedom struggle for a few years by then, Gandhi felt the disconnect. He said that despite talks of Hindu-Muslim unity, cries of "Vande Mataram" and "Allahu Akbar" were hurled by both communities during riots to assert dominance. It only revealed how divided the nation-to-be was, he said.

advertisement

The Vande Mataram slogan, inspired by Bankim Chandra Chatterjee's poem, had long been a rallying cry of the nationalists and an ode to the motherland, faced opposition from Muslims, including some in the Congress and the Muslim League. The opposition stemmed from the community's perception of the slogan being idolatrous and anti-Muslim owing to its use in Chatterjee's Anand Math, a fictional novel portraying Hindu monks rising against Muslim rulers of Bengal.

Despite the opposition, some of which lingers to this day, the Congress leadership of Gandhi, Jawaharlal Nehru, and Rajendra Prasad chose to make Vande Mataram, India's national song, given its immense significance as the soul of the freedom struggle. Only two stanzas of Vande Mataram were adopted. In fact, the original version of Vande Mataram, written in 1875, had only two stanzas, but was later expanded to six stanzas by Chatterjee and included in Anand Math in 1882.

VANDE MATARAM'S CRUCIAL SEVERED WAS INJUSTICE; SEEDS OF INDIA'S DIVISON SOWN IN 1937: MODI

Fast-forward to 2025. Prime Minister Narendra Modi said last week that "crucial" verses from "Vande Mataram" were removed in 1937, and the song being "broken and torn into pieces" had "sown the seeds of the country's division".

"The spirit of Vande Mataram illuminated the entire nation during the freedom struggle. But unfortunately, in 1937, crucial verses of Vande Mataram, a part of its soul, were severed. Vande Mataram was broken; it was torn into pieces. This division of Vande Mataram also sowed the seeds of division of the country. It's a great mantra of nation building. Why was this injustice done to it?" Modi asked, while speaking at an event to celebrate 150 years of Vande Mataram, India's National Song.

BJP spokesperson CR Kesavan accused the Congress of "deliberately distorting" Vande Mataram, claiming stanzas hailing Goddess Durga were removed in 1937 to appease communal sensitivities.

But contrary to the BJP's claim, Vande Mataram, despite being the soul of India's freedom struggle, was also considered "idolatrous" by certain sections of Muslims in British India, and they fiercely opposed the poem's adaptation as the National Song.

In the 1920s and 1930s, when religious identities hardened and politics grew more exclusionary, the push for adoption of the song by the Congress only deepened the divisiveness. The use of Vande Mataram as a slogan to provoke turned it from a symbol of national pride into a point of contention, noted historian Sabyasachi Bhattacharya in his 2003 book, Vande Mataram, The Biography Of A Song.

advertisement

"The song that united also divided," Bhattacharya wrote. He underlined how, even before the song's adoption in 1937, there were communal frictions over the slogan. The slogan of Vande Mataram was used to irk Muslims during communal tensions, just like Muslims hurled "Allahu Akbar". And all this started in the first decade of the 20th century, decades before the Congress adopted it in 1937.

The decision by the Congress to limit the national song Vande Mataram to only its first two stanzas was not a secret abridgement. It was a deliberate, openly recorded resolution made in response to objections raised by Muslim leaders. Moreover, Rabindranath Tagore himself endorsed the shorter version, on the Congress' request.

So, what made Gandhi compare both the slogans—Vande Mataram and Allahu Akbar—and why did Tagore recommend the adoption of the first two paragraphs of the poem for the National Song? What was in the part that was left out?

advertisement

THE STORY OF VANDE MATARAM; ORIGINS OF THE FIRST TWO STANZAS

The story of Vande Mataram began on November 7, 1875, during the Hindu festival of Akshaya Navami. Bankim Chandra Chatterjee, then a bureaucrat and now Bengal's Sahitya Samrat, penned its first lines. Drawing from the Shakti tradition, he imagined the motherland as a living goddess, akin to Durga or Jagaddhatri, the sustainer of the universe.

"Vande Mataram, sujalam suphalam...," Bankim Chandra painted the rivers and fields of Bengal as sacred in his words. He turned nature all around him into the Bharat Mata herself.

When first published in Bangadarshan in 1875, the poem had just two lyrical stanzas.

It simply saluted the mother, saying, "I bow to thee, Mother, rich in waters, waves, forests; seven million voices are your praise." It was less a war cry than a song of love for the land, written in the famine-stricken 1870s when colonial rule's cruelty was becoming obvious.

"These two stanzas describe in tender language the beauty of the motherland and the abundance of her gifts... The song was never sung as a challenge to any group or community in India and was never considered as such or as offending the sentiments of any community," Jawaharlal Nehru later said.

advertisement

Over time, Chatterjee expanded it to six stanzas. He introduced divine imagery, fire, and the sword. The mother became a goddess with a hundred arms and blazing lamps, ready to smite the enemy.

"Thou art Goddess Durga, Lady and Queen, With her hands that strike and her swords of sheen, Thou art Goddess Kamala (Lakshmi), lotus-throned, And Goddess Vani (Saraswati), bestower of wisdom known, pure and perfect without peer, Mother lend thine ear," the fifth stanza or the fourth verse said.

The tone shifted to resistance, inspired by the 18th-century Sannyasi Rebellion (1763-1800). It was an uprising of Hindu ascetics against the British and the local Muslim rulers during Bengal's famine years.

HOW VANDE MATARAM BECAME THE ANTHEM OF FREEDOM STRUGGLE

Between 1880 and 1882, Vande Mataram appeared in Bankim Chandra's magazine Bangadarshan before becoming part of Chatterjee's novel Ananda Math (1882). Initially, the poem didn't receive any criticism.

But by the 1905 Swadeshi Movement, it had turned into the heartbeat of defiance. The British banned it in some areas in Bengal. But the people sang it louder. It was first performed as a chorus at the 1886 Congress session by Hem Chandra Bandyopadhyay, and soon, the whole nation knew its rhythm.

advertisement

Later in 1896, it was recited by Rabindranath Tagore at that year's annual Congress Session. The biplabis (revolutionaries of Bengal's freedom movement) saw Vande Mataram as their battle cry against colonial rule.

By the mid 1910s, Vande Mataram had evolved into an unofficial anthem for many freedom fighters in India. Nationalist and sage Sri Aurobindo (born Aurobindo Ghosh) called it "the mantra of the new religion of patriotism".

"Rabindranath Tagore sang it while leading nationalist protest processions and Aurobindo Ghosh hailed as the rishi of nationalism. By the 1920s,the song, widely translated into many Indian languages by Subrahmanya Bharati and others, was acquiring the status of a national anthem," wrote Sabyasachi Bhattacharya.

By then, numerous societies, publications, and political groups had borrowed the name Vande Mataram, with Congress sessions and public speeches often beginning and ending with it.

However, some frictions surfaced early on over the slogan of Vande Mataram.

"In November 1906, in the Barisal district of East Bengal (now Bangladesh), disturbances broke out when some Hindu processionists shouted Vande Mataram while passing a Muhammadan mosque, despite protests from the Muhammadans engaged in prayer inside," wrote Bhattacharya.

However, things started changing from the 1930s onwards.

WHY MUSLIMS OPPOSED VANDE MATARAM DURING FREEDOM STRUGGLE?

The popularity and expansion of the poem made way for controversy too. The goddess imagery alienated Muslims, and the song finding a place in Bankim Chandra's Ananda Math, a novel that spoke of sanyasi revolt against Muslim zamindars, made it sound less national and more sectarian.

In 1923, when Mohammad Ali Jauhar assumed the Congress presidency, he walked out of the meeting as soon as Vande Mataram was sung.

"Through the 1930s and 1940s, the Muslim League persisted in their opposition to the song while the Hindu communal enthusiasm in its favour increased proportionately," wrote Bhattacharya.

"The change came about largely because, by the 1940s, the slogan and the song offended many Muslims. It was indeed used as a rallying cry by Hindus in communal riots. In fact, the slogan had been transformed in the intervening years between 1915 and 1947 into a communal war cry," added Bhattacharya.

In the political sphere, while Muslims within the Congress began to express mild opposition and even started skipping some meetings and sessions, the fiercest resistance came from the Muslim League, led by Muhammad Ali Jinnah, along with certain sections of the press.

In the 1930s and 40s, the Hindu-Muslim fissure widened because of fiercely contested elections, recurring communal riots, and incidents of bloodshed. All of it created a climate of mistrust and fear. In this charged atmosphere, even cultural symbols like the song Vande Mataram became flashpoints.

Jinnah's opposition to Vande Mataram was uncompromising and high-priority. In his negotiation agenda with Jawaharlal Nehru in 1938, he placed it as the second most important issue. The same year, Jinnah said that the Congress had made it "a hymn to spread hatred for Muslims".

Gandhi tried to calm the waters, writing in Young India that while he cherished the song, it must not be imposed.

HOW RABINDRANATH TAGORE SEPARATED TWO STANZAS OF VANDE MATARAM

The Congress faced Muslim League pressure, and the issue came to a head.

Subhas Chandra Bose wanted the full song. Nehru, as Congress president, feared alienating Muslims. "It does seem that this [the novel's] background is likely to irritate the Muslims," Nehru wrote to Bose in a 1937 letter.

Nehru then turned to Tagore, who had once sung the song himself at the 1896 Congress session. Tagore advised that only the first two stanzas be used.

Tagore noted that he could easily separate the first two stanzas from the rest of the song. For him, the gentle devotion and the celebration of the land's beauty and blessings in these opening lines held a unique charm, according to Tagore's biographer Prabhat Kumar Mukhopadhyay.

"I freely concede that the whole of Bankim's Vande Mataram poem, read together with its context, is liable to be interpreted in ways that might wound Moslem's susceptibility, but a national song, though derived from it, which has spontaneously come to consist only of the first two stanzas of the original poem, need not remind us every time of the whole of it, much less of the story with which it was accidentally associated. It has acquired a separate individuality and an inspiring significance of its own in which I see nothing to offend any sect or community," Tagore wrote back to Nehru in October 1937.

WHEN CONGRESS ADOPTED VANDE MATARAM AS NATIONAL SONG

Soon, the Congress Working Committee met in Calcutta between October 26 and November 1, with Gandhi, Nehru, Patel, Bose, Azad, and Prasad. The first two stanzas of Vande Mataram were adopted as the National Song of India, and it was decided that it would be sung at national gatherings.

"It is obvious that great songs and anthems cannot be produced to order. They come when genius wills it, and even when they come they have to seek the suffrage of the people. The recognition of a national anthem must wait till such a song has proved its worth by its excellence and popularity and the sentiment that gathers..." Nehru wrote in the resolution he drafted.

After Independence in 1950, the Constituent Assembly gave that version its place alongside Jana Gana Mana as India's National Song. Today, its two stanzas are sung in schools, at events, and in stadiums, with the AR Rahman version sneaking in. The full version survives in the book, cultural spaces, with its soul intact.

However, almost a century later, Vande Mataram, while it glows as a hymn of unity, it still triggers a very small section. For some people, its full form is a slogan of pride. Others see a divide. Truth lies in between. Its soul isn't in how many stanzas we sing, but in how we mean them.

- Ends

title: Congress set for a split, says PM Modi after NDA's Bihar landslide
content:
Following the NDA’s landslide victory in Bihar, Prime Minister Narendra Modi, addressing BJP workers at the party headquarters in Delhi, made a bold prediction of an imminent split within the Congress. He also issued a warning to the party’s alliance partners, forecasting political upheaval within the Grand Old Party due to growing dissatisfaction among its members.

Highlighting Congress’s repeated electoral failures since 2024, Prime Minister Modi questioned its ability to secure even 100 seats across six states. He further pointed out that Congress had not managed to win a single election in six states since 2024. He argued these results reflected a broader issue within the party and signalled unrest among its members, suggesting Congress’s trajectory was unsustainable for its coalition partners.

advertisement

"Today, the Congress has become MMC - Muslim League Maoist Congress and the entire agenda of the Congress now revolves around this, and therefore, within the Congress as well, a separate faction is emerging that is uncomfortable with this negative politics. I think that there could be another major split in the Congress," he said.

He referenced discontent within Congress, attributing it to the party’s leadership. Modi refrained from naming Rahul Gandhi directly, but indicated that internal disagreements had led to dissatisfaction and weakened the party’s cohesion.

Accusing the Congress of divisive politics, Prime Minister Modi claimed that the party lacked a positive agenda for the country. He expressed concern that it was promoting interests not aligned with national development, distancing itself further from mainstream discourse and even from its own coalition partners.

"Even Congress’s allies are beginning to understand that Congress is drowning everyone in its negative politics. That is why, during the Bihar elections, I said that the ‘naamdaar’ of the Congress is practising to drown himself and others in the Bihar elections by taking a dip in the pond," he said.

He described Congress as a “parasite” and warned its alliance partners to be cautious. Modi stated, “I had earlier warned Congress’s allies from this very stage that Congress has become a liability. It is a parasite party that wants to make a comeback by swallowing the vote banks of its allies. That is why even its partners need to be cautious of Congress.”

Modi also predicted that conflicts between Congress and its partners, such as the RJD, would become more visible after their defeat in Bihar. He alleged that Congress had insulted both him and the Election Commission during the campaign, accusing the party of undermining the electoral process.

After the NDA’s win, Modi described the result as a mandate for pro-people and pro-development politics. He asserted that the victory demonstrated public endorsement for the NDA’s governance record and its focus on economic advancement.

title: Revanth Reddy wins big, breaching the BRS citadel in Jubilee Hills
content:
It is still a month before Lionel Messi sets foot in Hyderabad, but football is already in the air. Football enthusiast and a player of some skill, Revanth Reddy, demonstrated on Friday, how to score a political goal.

After three successive electoral defeats in the Jubilee Hills assembly constituency - 2014, 2018 and 2023 - the Congress managed to storm the goalpost in the by-election whose result was announced on Friday.

advertisement

In the assembly elections in December 2023, the Congress failed to open its account in the 24 urban seats in the capital city Hyderabad. Now it has made a dent in the BRS citadel by winning two seats in bypolls - Secunderabad Cantonment last year and Jubilee Hills now.

What made the victory doubly sweet, a la Hyderabadi delicacy double ka meetha, was the margin. The late BRS MLA Maganti Gopinath, whose demise caused the bypoll, had won by over 16,000 votes both in 2023 and 2018, but Congress candidate Naveen Yadav's margin this time was over 24,000 votes. Proof that a significant part of the electorate had deserted the BRS car.

Not that the BRS, led by its Working President, KT Rama Rao, did not put up a good fight. It did. KTR's roadshows packed a punch, with several LED screens highlighting the promises made by the Congress in 2023 which it claimed have not been fulfilled so far. While it alleges distribution of money by the Congress as a factor that tilted the scales in favour of the ruling party, it still does not cover up for the strategic mistakes the BRS made in its election campaign.

The first mistake was the choice of candidate. The BRS banked heavily on the sympathy vote for Maganti Sunitha, Gopinath's widow. But its own cadre was unhappy with her candidature and conceded that the sympathy factor was not at play.

The second chink in the BRS election armour was the sheer mismatch in strength. The Congress deployed its entire cabinet, including newly minted minister Mohammed Azharuddin, into the campaign. The chief minister led from the front, almost as if he was on the stump.

Ministers were allocated specific areas and this microplanning has paid the Congress rich dividends. On the other hand, KTR was the lone warrior for the BRS.

Former minister and cousin Harish Rao suffered a bereavement and was missing from the campaign. What also hurt the BRS’s chances was the radio silence from party supremo K Chandrasekhar Rao. By not even making a digital media appeal for his candidate, KCR sent the message that Jubilee Hills voters were not worth his time and that the party's performance did not matter. Missing in action was bad optics.

From the Congress point of view, the win showed that the Telangana unit of the party, for all the talk of being a divided house, can also work like a cohesive team with the captain leading from the front. 2025 for the Congress, was 2023 revisited and that would gladden the party.

advertisement

Mistake number three was to misread the Muslim mind. No sooner did Azhar take the oath as Minority Welfare Minister in the Telangana government that the BRS labelled him a “temporary minister”. Even though Azhar is seen as a celebrity Muslim, the community did not appreciate anyone else lampooning him.

Secondly, the BRS believed that the MIM would not transfer its votes to the Congress candidate. The result showed that the MIM delivered on its word and while the Congress leadership in Delhi is anathema to Asaduddin Owaisi, the Hyderabad MP enjoys a good working relationship with Revanth Reddy.

For the MIM, it was also about the messaging. A BRS win would have led to the conclusion that the MIM has little control over the Muslim voters in Hyderabad and that would have been political suicide.

Mistake number four was the nature of the messaging. The BRS mocked the Congress welfare schemes, as it pitched its track record of having converted Hyderabad into a glitzy investment destination against it.

The problem was that the Congress knew its target audience better. A large part of the Jubilee Hills electorate consists of slums where sops like issuing ration cards and supplying fine rice to over 2 lakh beneficiaries, obviously mattered more. The Congress focused on its positives, banking on a vote of gratitude.

advertisement

Mistake number five was the BRS attack on HYDRAA, the Telangana government's ambitious drive to clear encroachments and reclaim the water bodies, in order to prevent flooding in Hyderabad.

The opposition party believed that voters would give the aggressive demolition of encroachments the thumbs down. Jubilee Hills, through its vote, showed that the people do not want their homes to go underwater every monsoon. The verdict means that HYDRAA would now be emboldened to spread its tentacles further.

While the BRS can officially say that bypolls tend to favour the ruling party, there is no denying the fact that its anti-Revanth Reddy narrative failed to find many takers.

But the BRS is not the only one that is in mourning. The results are bad news for the BJP as well, finishing a poor third. Jubilee Hills is part of the Secunderabad Lok Sabha constituency which is represented by Union Coal minister G Kishen Reddy and therefore, this humiliating defeat will be seen as a reflection on him as well.

The verdict will now work like a tonic for the Congress ahead of the local body elections in rural Telangana and the municipal elections in Hyderabad. Five years ago, the Congress got single digit seats out of 150 wards in the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation elections with the BRS and BJP dominating the show. Expect a realignment of political forces and behind-the-scenes adjustments to prevent the Congress from doing a Lionel Messi to them.

title: Viral: UP rape survivor pushes past cops, runs to senior officer to plead her case
content:
A gang-rape survivor in Uttar Pradesh’s Bulandshahr defied attempts by police to stop her and personally met the Deputy Inspector General (DIG) of Police, urging strict action against her rapists.

A video of the dramatic encounter went viral on social media, drawing widespread attention.

According to reports, the survivor was initially prevented from meeting the DIG by both male and female officers at the police station. Undeterred, she managed to slip past them and directly approached the senior officer to demand justice.

advertisement

After she intercepted the vehicle of the senior cop, the officer stepped out of the car and gave her an opportunity to narrate her ordeal.

"Sir, six people brutally raped me sometime back," the woman said. "Have they been put into jai?" the DIG asked. "Four of them have been jailed, two are absconding", she replied.

"I approached the police, but my pleas fell on deaf ears and no concrete action has been taken," a video showed the woman as saying to the senior police official. "Call the CO (circle officer) here", the DIG said.

The senior cop then instructed concerned officials to help her out and do what is required in the case. "They often chase my brother to thrash him too," the survivor further claimed.

DIG assured that all others accused would be arrested soon and sent to jail, ensuring the woman of justice.

The woman was allegedly gang-raped by six men a few days ago. Police have arrested four of the accused and remanded them to jail, while two remain at large. During her meeting with the DIG, the victim appealed for the immediate arrest of the remaining suspects.

The DIG assured her that efforts were underway to apprehend all absconding accused and that they would be brought to justice soon. Authorities have reportedly intensified the search for the fugitives.

title: Omar Abdullah's big loss of face, party loses seat he vacated after state polls
content:
In a jolt to the Farooq Abdullah-led National Conference (JKNC), the party has suffered a defeat in both the seats it contested in the Jammu and Kashmir bypoll, after the Election Commission announced the results on Friday. The party could not retain the Budgam seat and also finished third in Nagrota.

The party lost in Budgam, the seat National Conference leader and J&K Chief Minister Omar Abdullah vacated in the 2024 elections after he also won the Ganderbal seat. Aga Syed Muntazir Mehdi, a candidate from former chief minister Mehbooba Mufti's People's Democratic Party (PDP) won the Budgam seat with 21,576 votes.

advertisement

NC candidate Aga Syed Mahmood Al-Mosvai finished second behind Mehdi with 17,098 votes, trailing the PDP candidate by 4,478 votes.

Sources told India Today that National Conference MP from Srinagar, Aga Ruhulla, stayed away from campaigning due to differences with Omar Abdullah, which may have contributed to the party's poor showing in the Assembly constituency.

Omar Abdullah vacating the seat for Ganderbal in 2024 had necessitated the by-election. With this, the PDP's tally in the J&K Legislative Assembly has now reached 4.

It is also being seen as a moral victory for Mehbooba Mufti's party as the seat was won by a stalwart National Conference leader like Omar Abdullah in the 2024 Assembly elections.

Political pandits are also analysing the NC's loss in Budgam as a verdict by the people of the constituency, keeping in mind the one-year performance of the Omar Abdullah government since returning to power.

The National Conference also finished a distant third in the Nagrota bypoll, with party candidate Shamim Begum settling for 10,872 votes, which was 31,478 votes behind the eventual winner, BJP's Devyani Rana. She had 42,350 votes cast in her favour.

Jammu & Kashmir National Panthers Party (India)'s Hars Dev Singh finished second with 17,703 votes.

The BJP managed to retain the Nagrota Assembly seat in the bypoll which was necessitated by the death of sitting MLA Devender Singh Rana in October 2024.

Political experts suggest theBJP has reinforced its dominance in Jammu Division by retaining the Nagrota seat, as 30-year-old Devyani Rana won a by-election by a commanding margin of over 24,600 votes.

A graduate of the University of California in economics, she steps into the political arena carrying forward the legacy of her late father Devender Singh Rana—a seasoned BJP legislator from Nagrota.

advertisement

The results dealt a blow to the National Conference, whose candidate finished a distant third, signalling that the BJP’s tally in the J&K Assembly has climbed back to 29 and its stronghold in the region remains intact.

title: Bill to end H-1B visa programme soon, says Republican Congresswoman
content:
Days after Donald Trump defended the H-1B visa programme, Republican Congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene said she was introducing a bill to end "the mass replacement of American workers by aggressively phasing out the H1B programme". Actions against the H-1B programme bode ill for Indian professionals, who are the biggest beneficiary of the temporary work visa. The H-1B is also used as a pathway to American citizenship, through the Green Card route.

advertisement

Marjorie Taylor Greene, the GOP leader, accused US firms of abusing the programme to undermine the benefits for American workers.

"Big Tech, AI giants, hospitals, and industries across the board have abused the H-1B system to cut out our own people," she said in a post on X on Thursday (US time).

"Americans are the most talented people in the world, and I have full faith in the American people. I serve Americans only, and I will ALWAYS put Americans first," she added.

She said the bill proposes ending the H-1B programme and prioritising American workers in sectors such as technology, healthcare, engineering, and manufacturing.

"My bill ELIMINATES the corrupt H-1B program and puts AMERICANS FIRST again in tech, healthcare, engineering, manufacturing, and every industry that keeps this country running!! If we want the next generation to have the American Dream, we must stop replacing them and start investing in them," she said in the post.

"Greene's bill offers one "exemption" for 10,000 visas to be issued per year for medical professionals like doctors and nurses, Greene said. That exemption will be phased out after 10 years, she added.

Greene noted, however, that even the 10,000-per-year cap would be phased out over a decade to provide time to develop a domestic pipeline of American doctors and physicians.

Greene further said that the bill will also "take away the pathway to citizenship, forcing visa holders to return home when their visa expires.

The programme is used by US firms, especially in tech, to import talent, more than 70% of whom are Indian.

DONALD TRUMP'S RARE SHOW OF SUPPORT FOR H-1B VISAS

The development follows Trump's statement in which he defended the need for the H-1B program during a Fox News interview, stating in part that the US does not possess adequate domestic talent for certain positions in tech and defence.

During the interview, Trump was asked whether his administration would prioritise the H-1B visa programme over fears that it could suppress wages for American workers.

"I agree, but you do also have to bring in talent," he replied.

When the interviewer interjected and said, "We have plenty of talented workers," the President quickly shot back, "No, you don't."

advertisement

"You don't have certain talents. People have to learn. You can’t take people off an unemployment line and say, 'I'm going to put you into a factory where we're going to make missiles'," he added.

The bill, if introduced, will add to ongoing congressional and public debates regarding the future of the H-1B program and broader immigration reform efforts, Newsweek reported.

title: Bihar rocked today, makhana kheer in every home tonight: PM in victory speech
content:
Amid loud cheers and chants in BJP's national headquarters in Delhi, Prime Minister Narendra Modi celebrated the resounding victory of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) in Bihar. Referring to Bihar's traditional makhana-kheer (lotus pudding) recipe, Modi noted that today every family in the state would celebrate NDA's victory with 200+ (till the time the article was updated) seats with the traditional dessert item.

advertisement

In his victory speech, the PM hailed the landslide majority as the victory of the developmental politics orchestrated by both Janata Dal (United) chief Nitish Kumar and the Central government. He also took a sharp jibe at the Mahagathbandhan over its abysmal performance in Bihar.

TOP QUOTES FROM PM'S SPEECH

Bihar has once again shown that lies lose, people's trust wins. Bihar has made it clear that people will not support those who are out on bail.

When I used to speak about Jungle Raj and Katta Sarkar in the Bihar elections, the RJD party raised no objections. But it hurt the people of Congress. Today, I want to reiterate that Katta Sarkar will never return to Bihar.

Some parties in Bihar had created the appeasement formula of MY. But today's victory has given a new positive MY formula, and that is Mahila and Youth.

Today, the Congress has become the MMC- Muslim League Maoist Congress and the entire agenda of the Congress now revolves around this, and therefore, within the Congress as well, a separate faction is emerging that is uncomfortable with this negative politics.

Ganga flows through Bihar and reaches Bengal. Bihar has also paved the way for the BJP's victory in Bengal. I also congratulate the brothers and sisters of Bengal. Now, together with you, the BJP will uproot jungle raj from West Bengal as well.

title: Flash on, laalten gone: Union Minister recreates PM's viral call after NDA win
content:
After the NDA secured a decisive win in the Bihar elections on Friday, Union Minister Mansukh Mandaviya celebrated the victory with a symbolic gesture of switching on his phone’s flashlight.

The moment wasn’t random. At an election rally in Bihar’s Samastipur last month, Prime Minister Narendra Modi had launched a sharp attack on the Rashtriya Janata Dal (RJD), whose symbol is the lantern, declaring that the state no longer needs “lanterns and their allies” in an era defined by digital light and connectivity.

advertisement

Addressing the crowd, Modi had also urged supporters to turn on their mobile flashlights. On Friday, Mandaviya brought that imagery to life.

Two pictures showed him and several colleagues inside a train compartment, holding up their phone flashlights in celebration after the NDA’s emphatic win in Bihar.

“Flash ON, laalten Gone,” read the caption of the post.

The Bihar assembly elections proved bruising for the opposition. Tejashwi Yadav’s RJD - the single-largest party in the previous Assembly - collapsed under the NDA wave, losing more than half its seats.

The Congress faltered yet again, reinforcing its position as the Mahagathbandhan’s weakest link. Prashant Kishor’s Jan Suraaj Party, once billed as a potential disruptor, ended the day farsh par, making no electoral impact.

title: How an NDA's superstar is hiding in plain sight
content:
A year after registering a 100% strike rate in the 2024 Lok Sabha election, the NDA's Hindustani Awam Morcha (HAM), led by Union Minister Jitan Ram Manjhi, has emerged as a key asset for the alliance. Out of the six seats the HAM contested, it seems poised to win five of them in Bihar's southwestern Magadh region. Known to have a strong backing of the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes, the HAM played a crucial role in consolidating these votes for the NDA, especially in the reserved seats.

advertisement

With the NDA sweeping Bihar, the spotlight is on its heavyweights, like, the BJP, JDU and LJP. But cutting through the noise, Jitan Ram Manjhi's HAM has quietly punched above its weight, winning five of six seats.

The HAM's influence is reflected in the NDA's overall tally, which drew support from a wide range of voters. The HAM's impressive strike rate turned out to be the icing on the cake for the alliance, helping it sweep the 243-member assembly with a decisive performance.

The HAM demanded a minimum of 15 seats, while reports suggest the BJP was not ready to accept Manjhi's demand. Given HAM's vote base and targeted influence, the BJP could not afford to go to the polls without the HAM. Finally, the HAM was allotted six seats, all of them reserved for the Scheduled Castes. The Ham, as of 6.45 PM, is leading in four seats and has won one.

The HAM's value lies not just in its modest seat tally but in its impressive strike rate, the efficiency with which it converted seats into wins.

This metric underscores the HAM's role in consolidating the SC vote, a crucial segment of Bihar's population. It helped the NDA broaden its social base beyond the so-called upper castes, the EBCs and the non-Yadav OBCs.

Additionally, HAM's track record, combined with its influence in caste politics, makes the small party, formed in 2015 after Manjhi parted ways with the JD(U), a key ally in the alliance.

To understand HAM's significance more, we have to consider its electoral track record.

In the 2015 Bihar assembly elections, HAM contested 21 seats and secured just one victory. Manjhi won at Imamganj. It was a tough debut, with the Mahagathbandhan (JDU-RJD-Congress combine) sweeping 178 seats.

The turning point came in 2017 when Nitish Kumar realigned with the BJP, pulling the NDA back to power in Bihar.

HAM HELPED NDA CROSS MAJORITY MARK IN 2020 ASSEMBLY POLLS

HAM joined the fold, aligning its politics with the NDA's broader outreach. This paid dividends in the 2020 Assembly polls, where HAM contested seven seats and won four. It was a strike rate of nearly 57%.

advertisement

These victories, including Manjhi's from the party's stronghold Imamganj, provided the NDA with a razor-thin majority of 125 seats in the 243-member house. Without the HAM's haul, the coalition might have fallen short, especially as the JD(U) and BJP secured 43 and 74 seats respectively.

The HAM's wins helped Nitish Kumar from the government, with Manjhi's son Santosh Kumar Suman joining the Cabinet as a minister. It was a nod to the party stabilising its influence.

HAM'S LOK SABHA STRIKE RATE AND MANJHI'S CABINET BERTH

This strike-rate prowess continued into the 2024 Lok Sabha polls. In the 2024 elections, Manjhi contested from Gaya under the NDA banner and won decisively, vacating his assembly seat for a by-poll victory by his daughter-in-law, Deepa Manjhi.

Appointed Union Minister for Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises, Manjhi's elevation highlighted the BJP's trust in HAM as a formidable leader of the oppressed. It also helped counter the Opposition attacks on social justice.

Cut to 2025, and seat-sharing talks revealed the HAM's leverage. Manjhi demanded at least 15 seats. However, the BJP pursued its ally, and Manjhi was given six seats to contest in the high-stakes polls.

Though the Union Minister did not shy away from expressing his dissatisfaction with the seat-sharing formula repeatedly, saying that it had "weakened" the morale of party workers, he reiterated his commitment to help the NDA retain power in the state.

advertisement

However, the BJP never reacted to Manjhi's dissatisfaction. For the NDA, ignoring the HAM risked ceding SC support.

The HAM again proved its mettle as the party emerged victorious in five of the six seats it contested in the 243-member Assembly.

In short, the NDA sees the HAM as a partner whose efficiency and winnability provide the bloc with a strategic strike value. Rather than contesting large numbers, HAM helped complement the larger partners by anchoring sections of the electorate otherwise harder to mobilise.

- Ends

title: Farsh par is fantastic for Prashant Kishor
content:
The poll strategist Prashant Kishor predicted it right—his Jan Suraaj would either be "arsh par" (at the zenith) or "farsh par" (biting the dust). There would be no mid-point for his party. As the results of the Bihar Assembly election pour in, revealing that the Jan Suraaj even failed to open its account, the politician Prashant Kishor shouldn't make a hasty retreat as he promised to. Farsh (floor) is the best place for PK and his Jan Suraaj to be on right now.

advertisement

The fable of Icarus reveals what happens when one tries to fly too close to the Sun. The sky, dominated by hawks, is no place for a fledgling party. The floor is where Jan Suraaj should be. Stay grounded, stay connected, and stay invested.

Decades ago, Kanshi Ram, one of India's political icons and founder of the Bahujan Samaj Party, gave a masterplan for aspirants like PK. The first election is to lose, the second to cause defeats, and the third to emerge victorious, Ram suggested.

For three years, Prashant Kishor has been on the road in Bihar. He launched a 3,000-km Jan Suraaj padayatra, on October 2, 2022 from Champaran, where his idol MK Gandhi kicked off the Satyagrah in 1917.

This isn't the time to withdraw, but to build on what has been achieved. Everyone in Bihar now knows of Prashant Kishor and his Jan Suraaj—and that's no mean achievement. For decades, Bihar has been the battlefield of veterans, largely witnessing a two-cornered fight.

One might use the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) example to try and prove Kanshi Ram wrong and suggest that a debutant can score big, but Delhi—small and mostly urban—is hardly an example of the electoral maze called India.

Analysts have noted that Prashant Kishor's Jan Suraaj, which secured third or fourth positions in dozens of Bihar Assembly seats, might have eaten into the RJD's votes.

Both RJD and Jan Suraaj campaigned on similar themes, such as unemployment, migration, brain drain from the state, and replacing Nitish Kumar, who has been the CM for over two decades.

Voting in Bihar has calcified along caste lines. It is there that Prashant Kishor, with issues of employment, migration and the subjugation of Biharis, managed to make a mark in the minds of voters.

"If the JD(U) gets above 25 seats in the upcoming Assembly Elections, I will leave politics. Even if JD(U) wins more than 25 seats and a Jan Suraj government is formed, I still won't back down," Prashant Kishor told media outlets in October.

Though PK is the butt of jokes and memes today, no one can hold the politician Prashant Kishor hostage to his words. He should neither retreat nor blame the people's mandate.

advertisement

"Abraham Lincoln famously said elections belong to the people and it's their decision. They decided to turn their back on the fire; if they get burned, they will just have to sit with the blisters," Jan Suraaj spokesperson Anukriti told India Today TV.

Whatever said, today's the day for PK to lick his wounds. Take the jibes his way. Being with politicians through the years, he is all too familiar with what comes after election losses.

After he has drowned his sorrows in dry Bihar, what PK should instead focus on is what he has gained. He dared to bet his years of respect, money and career on a schoolbag, in a state that still votes for the lantern. He brought a new narrative to the state and spoke to the youth of hope in Bihar. The crowd behind PK was organic, not the usual paid audience we often see in political rallies. Like AAP convenor Arvind Kejriwal retreated to Chandigarh after the Delhi debacle, PK must stay in Bihar.

Jan Suraaj is now counted among 'Others' in the voting tally. The four in 'Others' have 13.5% of the vote share, which translates to 35 lakh votes. Only the final tally will confirm the votes won by Jan Suraaj. But it is safe to say lakhs stood in queues and trusted Prashant Kishor's party with their precious votes. Prashant Kishor has lakhs of those hopes to build on. He might find himself farsh par, but that's a fantastic beginning.

- Ends

title: A mocking Yashwant Sinha gets Bihar results bang on
content:
Social media is abuzz with an X post that former BJP leader and Union Minister Yashwant Sinha tweeted on November 11, three days ahead of the Bihar Assembly election results. Laced with sarcasm, the post turned out to be a prophecy for the high-voltage elections in India's one of the most politically crucial states.

The 88-year-old Sinha, whose barbs at the ruling dispensation often draw eyeballs, accidentally outdid even psephologists and political analysts by foretelling Bihar's electoral fate, that too, with precision.

advertisement

He tweeted from his X handle on November 11: "The exit polls of Bihar assembly polls are all wrong. My survey shows that NDA is winning at least 200 seats and Mahagathbandhan is being wiped out. I am not responsible if my prediction proves woefully wrong on the 14th of November."

The sarcasm turned out to be an oracle on November 14. The NDA actually won over 200 seats in a 243-member House, and it was a complete washout for the Mahagathbandhan, which was down by over 80 seats compared to the previous Assembly polls in Bihar.

Yashwant Sinha, who served as the Minister of External Affairs from July 2002 to May 2004 in the Atal Bihari Vajpayee government, parted ways with the BJP in April 2018. He became a critic of the Modi government and the BJP, and contested the Presidential election as the opposition candidate in 2022.

Yashwant Sinha's sarcastic post came after exit polls predicted a return of the NDA in Bihar. Shared on November 11, nine exit polls projected that the NDA was set to win more than 147 seats. The Mahagathbandhan, the pollsters said, was likely to secure around 90 seats.

Sinha's tweet went viral by the afternoon on Friday, with reactions pouring in on the sarcastic prediction.

Founder of ad and marketing agency, Abhishek Asthana, who goes by the name Gabbar with over 1.5 million followers on X, said, "Congrats sir for the accurate prediction."

Another user, Gelson Luz, said from his verified account, "These predictions are like my Aunt Mabel's famous chilli: always a bit too optimistic on the heat. History shows us that political fortunes can turn quicker than a startled cat. It's best to just wait for the official tally, don't you think?"

The tweet is now viral with nearly a million views.

Sinha, who is from Patna, was a bureaucrat for over two decades before he plunged into politics with the Janata Party in 1984.

A seasoned parliamentarian, he served multiple terms in the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha. He also had two stints as Finance Minister under Chandra Shekhar in 1990-91 and later under Atal Bihari Vajpayee from 1998-2002.

He was also the External Affairs Minister from 2002 to 2004, exiting the BJP in 2018. After his failed bid for the President's post in 2022 as an Opposition candidate, Sinha has largely stayed out of public focus. But his sarcastic post, which boomeranged during the Bihar Assembly polls, has once again brought him back into the spotlight.

- Ends

Published By: Anand Singh Published On: Nov 14, 2025

title: De De Pyaar De 2 review: Bumpy but breezy Bollywood rom-com that does the job
content:
It's been a while since Hindi cinema delivered a genuinely engaging romantic comedy, which is exactly why 'De De Pyaar De 2' arrives with the weight of high anticipation. The Ajay Devgn-Rakul Preet Singh starrer brings back the familiar 'fight in love and fight for love' trope, but adds a new layer to its age-defying romance -- this time with a louder, more colourful commercial pulse.

advertisement

The story is simple, almost comfortably so. The film opens with a quick recap of how Ashish (Devgn) and Aisha (Rakul) fell in love despite their significant age gap, and how they fought to make their relationship work. 'De De Pyaar De 2' picks up from there, shifting the battleground to Aisha's family home -- an expansive, modern household that prides itself on being "open-minded and progressive," yet struggles to digest that their future son-in-law is just a few years younger than the family patriarch.

Aisha and Ashish now have a new challenge: seeking approval from her progressive-but-not-really parents. "Acceptance is a process," Aisha declares in a monologue. But if Bollywood romances have taught us anything, it's that nothing ever goes as planned for the lovers on screen.

Director Anshul Sharma keeps the tone breezy, funny, quirky, dramatic, and vibrant. The film retains the glossy charm of the first instalment, and that's where a lot of its appeal lies. But its biggest hiccup is also its most unavoidable one: the awkward casting.

Jaaved Jaaferi and Meezan Jafri bring energy and humour, but R Madhavan, despite his undeniable acting chops, feels oddly misplaced. Maybe it's because we're simply not ready to see Maddy playing the father of a 20-something girl. His scenes with Rakul, especially the one where he lifts and twirls her in a song meant to evoke emotional resonance, lean more awkward than teary.

As for Ajay and Rakul, the chemistry still isn't crackling, but it works well enough to sell the story. There are no intimate moments here, but both play their parts with conviction -- he as the intense, brooding partner, and she as the bubbly, determined young woman refusing to let her father map out her life.

Meezan, meanwhile, is the delightful surprise package. Stylish, confident, and a natural on the dance floor, he lights up the screen, especially in the film's most enjoyable song sequence with his father. There's still room for him to grow as an actor, but he's undeniably charismatic.

Rakul is charming and effortless in lighter moments, but falters during the emotionally heavy scenes. Her big breakdown in front of her mother (Gautami Kapoor) unintentionally echoes reality-TV dramatics -- think Tanya Mittal from 'Bigg Boss 19' -- who might've actually pulled it off better.

advertisement

Ishita Dutta and Gautami add warmth and grounding to the narrative.

Despite its bumps, 'De De Pyaar De 2' remains consistently entertaining. You'll laugh, roll your eyes, and might even find yourself unexpectedly invested in the last-act twist. It doesn't reinvent the rom-com wheel, but it keeps it spinning with enough charm.

It's perfectly crowd-pleasing, and comfortably familiar -- never extraordinary, but never dull either. It's the kind of movie you watch knowing exactly what you'll get, and you get precisely that. 'De De Pyaar De 2' is comfortable. Watch it if you like rom-coms, and want to give Bollywood a chance.

- Ends

3 out of 5 stars to 'De De Pyaar De 2'

title: XUV 700 loses control on Delhi-Mumbai Expressway, plunges into ditch; 5 dead
content:
CCTV footage has captured the moment a speeding XUV700 veered off the Delhi-Mumbai Expressway before falling into a ditch near the Mahi river, resulting in the deaths of five people, including a 15-year-old boy and a 60-year-old man.

The accident occurred around 7 am on Friday near Bhimpura village. The vehicle, registered as MHO3 EL 1388, was travelling from Delhi towards Gujarat when the driver reportedly lost control.

advertisement

The car broke through the expressway railing and plunged into the ditch below. The impact caused extensive damage, with the front portion and roof of the vehicle torn apart. Parts of the bumper and number plate were found some distance away from the crash site.

Police said the occupants were residents of Ahmedabad and Mumbai. The deceased have been identified as Ghulam Rasool, 70, son of Ishaq Choudhary of Kurla, Mumbai; Khalis, son of Ghulam Rasool Choudhary of Vadodara; Abdul Ghulam, son of Danish Choudhary of Kurla, Mumbai; Danish, 15, son of Usman Choudhary of Kurla, Mumbai; and Durgesh Prasad, 35.

Local residents assisted police in retrieving the bodies from the vehicle. The remains have been sent to Dr. Lakshmi Narayan Pandey Government Medical College in Ratlam, where post-mortem examinations will be conducted once the victims' families arrive. Police have initiated an investigation into the cause of the crash

title: Why Chirag Paswan is NDA's Ravindra Jadeja
content:
By Friday noon, as the Bihar Assembly election trends trickled in, social media was on fire. That's because the NDA looked headed for a landslide victory, and Chirag Paswan's LJP(RV) playing his part in style. Such was Chirag's performance, some even jumped the gun to declare that he had outshone his father, the late Ram Vilas Paswan. Just like Ravindra Jadeja, who decimates the opposition with his fiery strike rate, Chirag Paswan has dazzled as the finisher in the NDA camp.

advertisement

Chirag's LJP (RV) was given 29 seats with the bigger partners, the BJP and the JD(U) contesting 101 seats each. With the opening line-up doing their job like Rohit Sharma and Virat Kohli would have, it was for Chirag's party to see that the victory was sealed. And Chirag did that in style.

After scoring a perfect 5/5 in the 2024 Lok Sabha polls, PM Narendra Modi's self-proclaimed "Hanuman" is now scripting a big moment. The LJP(RV) is leading in 23 of 29 seats it contested. It is not a 100% strike rate like in the Lok Sabha polls, but a big haul that has stunned many. As of 12.45 PM, the LJP (RV), with more than 5% vote share, is leading in several seats in Magadh, Seemanchal and Patliputra regions.

And the story is that the LJP(RV)'s surge has been powered by voters of the BJP, the JD(U) and the smaller allies. It is the consolidation the NDA must have expected. Chirag's party has returned the favour, too, in terms of vote transfer.

At the micro level, this is the LJP(RV)'s most explosive showing yet. It's a stunning jump from the 2020 Bihar Assembly election, when it went solo and won just a single seat. In the 2020 Bihar Assembly elections, the LJP(RV) fielded candidates in 137 seats and Chirag Paswan's fierce, anti-Nitish campaign ended up slicing into the JD(U)'s votes, dragging Nitish Kumar's tally down from 71 seats in 2015 to just 43. Much of this setback was widely seen as the result of LJP(RV)'s vote-cutting impact.

Now, with the LJP(RV) contesting firmly within the NDA in 2025, the Chirag Paswan–led party not only delivered a strong result of its own but, thanks to a smooth vote transfer, also helped lift the Nitish-led JD(U)'s tally and boosted the NDA's overall count.

In a way, Chirag truly became the "Hanuman" he once claimed to be.

With this Bihar win, Chirag's stock in the NDA is only going to climb. And it's bound to reshape the coalition's internal equations in Bihar, especially given the long-running friction between the LJP(RV) and the JDU.

Now, it is time for Chirag Paswan to celebrate just like Ravindra Jadeja does—raise the bat and sword-swish.

title: French Embassy fires back at Trump using viral pic of Louvre jewels heist 'detective'
content:
The Embassy of France in the United States used the viral image of the “detective” from the Louvre heist as it responded to comments made by US President Donald Trump about France.

During a Fox News interview, Trump defended the presence of Chinese students at American universities, saying he believed it was “good to have outside countries.”

Host Laura Ingraham pushed back, claiming Chinese nationals “spy on us” and “steal our intellectual property.” In response, Trump asked her, “Do you think the French are better?”

advertisement

"Yeah,” Ingraham said as Trump disagreed, saying: "I'm not so sure. We've had a lot of problems with the French."

This particular snippet from Trump’s interview went viral after journalist Kaitlan Collins shared the clip on X. But it was the French Embassy that delivered the sharpest comeback, using the now-famous “detective” image to mock Trump’s remarks.

“Come on, we've got WAY BETTER spies than China,” it said. The post featured a picture of the “detective” – a sharply dressed man who made headlines during the coverage of the crown jewels theft at the Louvre.

Come on, we've got WAY BETTER spies than China https://t.co/QjLAt6spGR pic.twitter.com/r13kOMC9XU— Embassy of France in the U.S. (@franceintheus) November 13, 2025

The man - seen in a three-piece suit, gold waistcoat and fedora, holding an umbrella like a cane – had sparked speculation online, with many joking that he was the lead investigator or even a disguised suspect.

However, according to Associated Press photographer Thibault Camus, who took the picture, the man was merely a passerby.

“He appeared in front of me, I saw him, I took the photo,” Camus told AP, adding that the sharply dressed stranger “had nothing to do with the investigation” and left shortly after walking into the frame.

The photograph was taken soon after thieves raided Paris's Louvre museum in broad daylight last month, taking just seven minutes to grab some of France's priceless crown jewels.

title: Not property or stocks, can investing in luxury be the next big move for India's middle class?
content:
If you asked your grandparents about investment, their answers would likely come down to two things: property and gold. Your grandmother might fondly tell you how she used to buy gold jewellery with the money she saved from the monthly ration budget. "The prices weren't so high back then," she'd remind you with a smile.

For our parents' generation, the idea of investment widened a little. Fixed deposits, stocks, and mutual funds entered the picture, and we've all heard those stories of how they bought shares in one company 15 years ago that are now worth a fortune.

advertisement

But for the younger generation, the canvas is expanding even further. With global brands entering India and luxury becoming more accessible, a new question is emerging: can luxury itself be the next big investment for the Indian middle class?

The big shift

"Luxury items can be a good investment," says Garvit Goyal, a NISM-certified finance content creator. He feels that this shift is primarily happening because the current generation is blending lifestyle with finance.

"We want our money to reflect our personality, not just sit in a fixed deposit. For older generations, investing was about security, but now it is about self-expression," Goyal tells India Today.

So, owning a Rolex or a pair of limited-edition Jordans isn't just a flex, it's culture, status, and also profit.

In India, the idea of luxury as an investment is gaining quiet momentum, adds CA Anamika Rana, a finance content creator.

"For India's middle class, this trend is still emerging but not unrealistic. With better access to resale platforms, owning one or two quality luxury items can now be part of a diversified investment approach, but with caution. These items are illiquid, depend heavily on brand demand, condition, and authenticity, and don't generate regular income like mutual funds or FDs. So they should form a small, passion-driven portion of your portfolio, not the core."

Meanwhile, Abhishek Kumar, a SEBI-registered adviser and founder of SahajMoney, feels that luxury items are becoming alternative investments as there is a rising class of people in India who have high disposable income and who view luxury goods as alternative stores of value. With more money to spend and a taste for new experiences, the younger generation is redefining what investment means | Photo: Pexels/Andrea Piacquadio

Is it realistic, though?

Kumar tells us that the rising middle class in India, earning less than Rs 20 lakh per annum, is becoming a major buyer of luxury purchases, but most are financing these purchases through EMIs and credit card schemes rather than cash payments.

advertisement

"Many buyers are stretching their finances to appear wealthy rather than genuinely investing, driven by social media and marketing exploitation of insecurities. One needs to distinguish between consumption and investment, as most of these purchases depreciate rather than appreciate with time."

Further, according to Goyal, investing in luxury is possible but only if you play it smart.

"For the middle class, it doesn't have to be a Rolex or a Hermes bag. It can simply mean limited-edition sneakers or watches in the category one can afford."

It is crucial to understand that luxury markets work on scarcity and hype. So, you have to stay updated on which brands have resale demand and how to verify authenticity.

Understanding luxury

Not all luxury items grow in value in a similar way.

Timeless pieces with classic designs usually appreciate because their appeal never fades, and their scarcity is real.

Trendy items lose value quickly once the hype dies down.

Limited-edition collectables, however, can see substantial appreciation if held over the long term; their rarity and story often make them truly special.

So, when it comes to luxury investments, it's not just about economics, it's about emotion, heritage, and exclusivity. That's why not all luxury goods behave the same financially.

advertisement

Think of Rolex, Hermes Birkin, Cartier, and Patek Philippe, brands built on legacy, craftsmanship, and limited supply. While they are expensive, they are also steady and reliable in the long run.

On the other hand, trend-driven pieces like Balenciaga sneakers, Gucci belts, and Prada bucket hats often skyrocket in popularity but lose their charm and value just as fast.

So, which is the most popular category?

"Oh, this has to be luxury watches," shares Goyal, adding that Rolex, Patek Philippe, and Audemars Piguet are signature status brands.

Watches appreciate because they are produced in limited quantities and are always in demand across the world. A Rolex Daytona, which retailed for around Rs 10 lakh a few years ago, now resells for Rs 25–30 lakh or more, depending on condition and rarity.

Let's not miss the handbag craze

While this market is still at an early stage, it can grow significantly in the near future as aspiration now meets investment.

"Globally, handbags, especially Hermes, Chanel, and Louis Vuitton, have proven to outperform traditional assets at times," Goyal tells us.

For example, the Hermes Birkin Index showed an average annual return of 14 per cent, better than gold or the US Index over certain decades.

advertisement

Handbags have a timeless appeal as they never go out of fashion. Plus, women, as per Goyal, are increasingly viewing luxury as part of financial empowerment. But it's still a niche market, so returns and buyers can vary depending on brand and style.

"Personally, I invest in rare luxury handbags," shares Rana, adding that it is more from a want perspective than a need perspective.

"I only buy them after securing my basics — emergency fund, mutual funds, insurance, and other traditional investments. That's the golden rule." Luxury handbags are becoming symbols of financial empowerment for women | Photo: Pexels/Godisable Jacob

Can the middle class participate?

The middle class can invest in luxury but not like the rich do. Goyal says, "You cannot buy a Rs 25 lakh Rolex just for investment. A lot more goes behind it. Hence, start small. Start with entry-level designer watches, bags, and sneakers that you can afford."

advertisement Research like an investor, not as a shopper of luxury pieces.

Track resale prices, learn which models hold value, and verify authenticity through official resale platforms.

Also, remember that these are not as liquid as stocks. They should be part of your high-risk portfolio, where you allocate a maximum of 10–15 per cent.

Goyal warns that luxury investing won't make you rich overnight. Some assets might appreciate 10–20 per cent yearly; others might stagnate or drop. So, view it as diversification, not a guaranteed money machine.

Adding to this, Kumar suggests:

Invest only in timeless pieces from heritage brands with a proven resale value and avoid trendy items that lose relevance quickly.

Maintain items in pristine condition through proper storage and care as condition has a major impact on resale value.

Be prepared for a long-term commitment of 10–15 years to see meaningful appreciation.

Avoid EMIs unless you can comfortably repay them without strain.

But where will the money come from?

Banks won't hand out loans for Birkins and Rolexes, but you can play smart. Use low-interest plans to buy a limited-edition, resale-worthy item, suggests Goyal. If the interest cost is less than the expected appreciation, it's worth playing the game.

Or, the best way is to save up enough over months or years so that you can afford to buy it.

"Only allocate 5–10 per cent of your surplus income to such passion-based investments. Enjoy them, hold them long-term, and never compromise your financial security for a label," Rana further shares.

The way ahead

In a viral video, actor Ameesha Patel is heard saying that in Japan, a Hermes Birkin bag can be used as collateral for a bank loan. It surely makes one wonder if something like this can work in India in the coming years.

"I believe yes, but not immediately and not widely," says Goyal. "For a bank to accept a Birkin or similar bag as collateral, there needs to be a widely recognised valuation method, clear authenticity, and proper rules and regulations. Without that, the risk is too high for lenders."

Also, although luxury resale is growing, the standardisation of such valuations and market liquidity are still underdeveloped. "It might be a possibility in the future, but not for at least the next 5 to 10 years."

- Ends

title: OnePlus 15 review in 9 points: Big performance, bigger battery, but is it enough?
content:
The OnePlus 15 is one of those rare flagships that looks straightforward at first glance but turns unexpectedly interesting the more time you spend with it. On the outside, it seems like OnePlus is playing it safe this year with a cleaner design, a bigger battery, and a familiar software experience. But dig a little deeper and you will notice some features that quietly change the way the phone behaves. Some decisions make complete sense, others feel surprisingly restrained, and a few are just bold enough to make you wonder what OnePlus is really aiming for. So, is the OnePlus 15 the best flagship buy in 2025? Well, that totally depends on your perspective and needs. But, we have summarised our detailed OnePlus 15 review in 9 points to help make your buying decision easier.

advertisement

OnePlus has hiked the price of the OnePlus 15 by Rs 3,000, when we compare it with the OnePlus 13. But, the initial launch offers let you buy the device at the price of its predecessor. You will be able to buy it at Rs 79,999 via Amazon and other official channels. Now that the price part is out of our way, let's talk about the OnePlus 15's design, gaming performance, display, camera experience and more in 9 points.

OnePlus 15 review in 9 points

1. A cleaner, more grounded design approach this year

OnePlus drops its signature circular camera module in favour of a neat square island for a modern look. The phone has flat frames, a classy matte finish, and a violet tone that looks premium without shouting for attention. It is slimmer at 8.1mm despite packing a massive battery, which speaks to the internal design effort. However, removing the Alert Slider, one of the brand’s most loved hardware features, feels like a step backwards, and the Plus Key doesn’t offer the same instinctive convenience. It is useful but OnePlus fans would likely take sometime to get used to it.

2. Slimmer body, bigger battery

The 7,300mAh battery is the biggest strength of the OnePlus 15. Fitting this cell into a slimmer frame than last year’s model is genuinely impressive. In the hand, the device feels far lighter than its battery capacity suggests, thanks to solid weight distribution. Also, OnePlus has managed to offer the device almost at the weight of the OnePlus 13. The downside is that the slimmer frame, paired with the powerful chipset, means the phone does get warm when pushed hard, something which I noted clearly in the stress tests.

3. Snapdragon 8 Elite Gen 5, excellent numbers on paper

Speaking of which, benchmark results are strong and place the OnePlus 15 strongly in the flagship territory. In our testing, Geekbench multi-core scores touched 9,629, and AnTuTu offered 3.6 million score. These figures confirm the phone can handle everything from heavy apps to high-end gaming. It is a powerhouse because no flagship has scored such a high score on Antutu. The chipset isn’t the absolute thermal champion, but for general usage, it’s more than enough. The peak performance is there, but it’s the sustained performance where some limitations show up.

4. Gaming performance is smooth, but thermals can flare up

advertisement

OxygenOS 16 feels clean, fast, and responsive, the kind of software experience OnePlus has always been appreciated for. App switching is instant, animations look fluid, and gaming is consistently stable. But under repeated heavy tasks, the phone crosses 50°C and loses around 10 percent charge in a 10-minute AnTuTu loop. This isn’t a daily use scenario, but it still shows that the thermal envelope isn’t perfect. In everyday use, the phone behaves brilliantly and it is only during stress bursts that the stability dips.

During my usage, Genshin Impact ran on "High" graphics with 30fps by default and I got a smooth experience without over-taxing the hardware. However, switching to higher (60fps) frame rate required me to lower the graphics setting. The same stands for BGMI too, but you get a top-notch gaming performance when you enable High Performance mode in the Settings. Benchmark tests like 3DMark Wild Life Extreme showed 82 per cent stability, indicating that the GPU doesn’t throttle aggressively under sustained load. On the downside, during very long and demanding sessions of about 1.5 to 2 hours, the phone does warm up, which eventually impact frame rate stability.

advertisement

5. 1.5K AMOLED display is sharp, bright, and fluid but not the best

The 6.7-inch AMOLED display offers excellent brightness and a super-smooth 165Hz refresh rate. Although, in our test, the device's panel never reached 165Hz and it mostly stayed on 120Hz or 30Hz. But, I have to say colours are well-tuned, viewing angles are strong, and HDR content looks great. That said, OnePlus moving from QHD+ resolution screen to a 1.5K panel will disappoint users who expect the absolute best display at this price. similarly, the local brightness has been improved, but the peak brightness for HDR video streaming has also dropped by 900nits. Even though the difference isn’t as noticeable in real-world use, on paper, this feels like a compromise to achieve better battery life and efficiency.

6. Battery life is genuinely industry-leading

The OnePlus 15’s endurance is one of the best I have tested this year. Over 15 hours of continuous use in Balanced mode is exceptional, and many users will comfortably get 1.5 days depending on usage. But, keep in mind that some short binge watching sessions and a few hours of gaming drops the battery levels much faster on High Performance mode. So, you could be required to charge after almost 10 hours. The 120W fast charger tops the phone up in around 25 minutes, which reduces charging anxiety drastically. This is the area where OnePlus clearly focused its energy and it pays off. No complaint here.

advertisement

7. Cameras deliver reliable results, but don’t push boundaries

The main camera produces crisp, balanced shots with realistic skin tones, plenty of details and pleasing colours in daylight. Low-light performance is decent but not on the level of big camera-centric brands. The telephoto performance is where it feels like the phone could have done better because zoom photos lack the clarity and details expected in this price bracket. The camera system is reliable for everyday use, but it isn’t the standout upgrade some were hoping for. It is good, but not exceptional.

8. Software is clean, but the UI experience could feel repetitive

OxygenOS 16 retains its clean look, which many users like. Navigation is smooth, and there isn’t a lot of bloatware. But the UI now feels more iOS-like than uniquely OnePlus-like. Users who have been following the brand for years may feel the identity fading slightly. The Plus Key also doesn’t feel as natural as the Alert Slider it replaces. Still, overall stability and polish remain strengths.

advertisement

9. A mature flagship that focuses on dependability, not disruption

The OnePlus 15 doesn’t chase breakthroughs or experimental features. It settles comfortably into a rhythm of offering strong performance, excellent battery life, a clean design, rapid charging, and everyday reliability. Its weaknesses? noticeable thermals under extreme stress, decent telephoto performance, the 1.5K display choice, and the removal of the Alert Slider keep it from feeling truly bold. But it’s clear that OnePlus played it safe by prioritising balance and stability over risks.

For many users, this will be exactly what they want. For enthusiasts expecting a big leap, it may feel a bit too safe. Overall, the OnePlus 15 feels like a well-rounded flagship phone and power users will likely love it.

- Ends
