title: Prashant Kishor's Jan Suraaj scores zero on Bihar debut
content:
Prashant Kishor’s much-hyped political debut with the Jan Suraaj Party (JSP) appears to have largely fallen flat in the high-stakes Bihar Assembly elections. Current counting trends show the party struggling to make any impact, remaining without a seat, while the NDA takes a massive lead.

Positioned as a revolutionary third alternative to the ruling National Democratic Alliance (NDA) and the opposition Mahagathbandhan, the JSP initially led in two constituencies before sliding back to zero, closely aligning with the near-unanimous predictions of major exit polls.

advertisement

Despite fielding candidates in almost all assembly seats and running a year-long, intensive grassroots campaign, including the popular Jan Suraaj Padyatra, the party has been unable to convert its momentum into substantial electoral gains. In its debut electoral fight, the JSP contested 238 seats and, so far, has managed to secure third place in several constituencies.

Click here to track live coverage of Bihar Assembly election

Most exit polls had forecasted a near-total rout for the party. Axis My India projected around 4 per cent of the vote share but no seats, while Matrize estimated 0–2 seats and Dainik Bhaskar predicted 0-3. Other agencies, including Chanakya Strategies, P-Marq, JVC, People’s Insight, and People’s Pulse, similarly did not expect JSP to cross the single-digit mark.

However, analysts note that JSP could emerge as a decisive factor in closely contested seats, potentially diverting significant anti-incumbency votes, particularly among young voters.

Many observers also credit the party with influencing the political discourse. Prashant Kishor’s relentless focus on core issues, unemployment, migration, education, and healthcare, helped shape much of the poll narrative, compelling major alliances to address these concerns more directly in their campaigns.

title: Watch how India's Chandrayaan-3 was pulled by the Moon. It will happen again
content:
In an intriguing development this November 2025, Chandrayaan-3's Propulsion Module (PM), originally launched in July 2023 by Isro, naturally drifted back into the Moon’s gravitational sphere after orbiting in a complex Earth-Moon system for over two years.

Not an intentional manoeuvre, this return showcases the chaotic dance of celestial mechanics influenced by Earth, the Moon, and gravitational forces at play.

In early September 2025, asteroid tracking data revealed that Chandrayaan-3’s service module would encounter the Moon twice in early November. This was confirmed when the PM entered the Moon's Sphere of Influence (SOI) on November 4, as confirmed by Isro.

WATCH CHANDRAYAAN-3 PULLED BY THE MOON

CHANDRAYAAN-3 was last reported by https://t.co/jPw7NGPQYB on 2025-06-27. In September it became obvious from asteroid tracking data that the service module would encounter the Moon in early November twice. pic.twitter.com/A3sV3sBU3B — Scott Tilley (@coastal8049) November 14, 2025

The first lunar flyby occurred on November 6 at a distance of 3,740 kilometers from the lunar surface, followed by a second close encounter on November 11 at 4,537 kilometers away.

This unexpected lunar rendezvous is a consequence of the natural three-body problem dynamics, the gravitational interplay between Earth, the Moon, and the spacecraft, which caused Chandrayaan-3’s PM orbit to drift and be captured briefly by the Moon’s gravity.

Isro engineers continue monitoring the spacecraft’s trajectory carefully as it navigates this complex gravitational environment.

CHANDRAYAAN-3 WILL RETURN TO THE MOON AGAIN

Amateur astronomer Scott Tilley, known for tracking space debris and satellites, analysed the PM’s future and suggested the possibility of another lunar encounter around April 2026.

Beyond that, the spacecraft’s orbit may become unstable, potentially sending it into a solar orbit or leading to impact scenarios with either the Moon or Earth, demonstrating the unpredictable nature of objects in deep space around multiple gravitational bodies.

The Chandrayaan-3 PM originally carried the Lander and Rover to the Moon, supporting a historic soft landing and lunar surface exploration in August 2023. Following mission completion, the PM was repositioned into a high-altitude Earth orbit to test extended operations and collect valuable scientific data.

This ongoing story of Chandrayaan-3’s service module highlights the intricacies of orbital mechanics in multi-body systems and underscores the challenges of long-term space operations.

It also provides invaluable insights for future lunar and interplanetary missions in managing spacecraft trajectories in chaotic gravitational environments.

title: Multiple blasts planned till Jan 26: Defence analyst on 'white-coat' terror module
content:
In an exclusive conversation, Defence Analyst Major Gen DC Katoch (Retd) termed the recent arrests of doctors and professionals linked to a terror plot as part of a pan-India “White Coat Terror Nexus”, a covert network operating far beyond Jammu and Kashmir.

Maj Gen Katoch said the conspiracy carried the hallmarks of a “classic regime change operation,” strategically planned between December and January, coinciding with the scheduled visit of Russian President Vladimir Putin to India. According to him, multiple blasts were planned until 26 January. “This was not a standalone act of terror but a coordinated plan with geopolitical motives,” he said.

advertisement

He identified Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) as the central organisation behind the plot, asserting that the operational trail from propaganda posters in Kashmir to the procurement of explosives linked directly to Pakistan’s military establishment and government. “The signature is clearly that of Jaish,” he said.

The retired Major General said the network consisted of sleeper cells embedded across India for years, including individuals radicalised locally and sent abroad for training. He described the arrests as the outcome of “one of India’s most successful counter-intelligence operations,” adding that the scale of devastation planned was “massive.”

According to him, the motive behind the plot was revenge for Operation Sindoor, which significantly weakened terror networks in the region. He suggested that Pakistan’s proximity to the US may have emboldened such attempts. “They wanted to avenge their losses,” he said.

Calling the conspiracy “an act of war,” Major Gen Katoch said Prime Minister Narendra Modi has made it clear that the perpetrators will not be spared. “The response will be of India’s choosing in time, scale, and manner. Operation Sindoor continues,” he concluded.

title: At least 6 dead as bus crashes into stop in Stockholm
content:
Several people were killed and injured when a bus hit a bus stop in central Stockholm on Friday, Swedish police said, adding that they had no information pointing to it being an attack.

There were six casualties in the incident, a spokesperson for Stockholm's rescue services said, without giving the numbers of those killed or those injured. The spokesperson said there were no passengers on the bus at the time.

advertisement

"It is being investigated as involuntary manslaughter. The bus driver has been arrested but that is routine in such an incident," a police spokesperson said, adding they had no information pointing to it being an attack.

Police said they would not comment on the number, gender or ages of those killed or injured.

Police, rescue services and ambulances were working at the scene, police said.

A picture on daily Aftonbladet's website showed emergency services at the site, surrounding a blue double-decker bus, with debris scattered around the vehicle.

The incident occurred near the Royal Institute of Technology university, police said.

"We do not yet know the cause of this, but right now my thoughts are foremost with those who have been affected and their families," said Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson in a post on X.

title: Could one statement push Japan and China towards war over Taiwan?
content:
A single parliamentary remark in Tokyo has triggered one of the most dangerous diplomatic crises between Japan and China in years, with Taiwan sitting squarely in the crossfire and both nations refusing to back down.

The explosion began when Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi answered a seemingly routine question in parliament last Friday. Asked what Chinese actions against Taiwan could trigger Japan's right to collective self-defence, her response was unequivocal: battleships, force, or any military operation around Taiwan could constitute a survival-threatening situation for Japan under its 2015 security law, potentially allowing Japanese troops to enter the conflict.

advertisement

Beijing's reaction was immediate and furious. China's foreign ministry branded her comments "egregious" and "gross interference". But the crisis escalated dramatically when Xue Jian, China's consul general in Osaka, reshared news of her remarks with a chilling threat: "the dirty head that sticks itself in must be cut off". Though Xue deleted the post, the damage was done.

Japan filed strong protests. China demanded Takaichi retract her statement. She refused, insisting her words reflected Japan's traditional position. China responded by warning that Japan was "playing with fire" and issued an open threat: if Japan "dares to meddle" in the Taiwan situation, it would be considered an "act of aggression".

On Thursday, Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Sun Weidong summoned Japan's ambassador, calling Takaichi's comments "extremely wrong and dangerous". His warning was stark: all consequences would be borne by Japan. Chinese state media threatened Japan would "suffer a crushing defeat" if it intervened militarily.

Japan has held its ground, reaffirming its One-China principle whilst refusing to disavow Takaichi's remarks. This subtle but significant shift acknowledges Taiwan's direct link to Japan's security, a position Beijing considers unacceptable.

With military tensions already high, Chinese jets entering Taiwan's air defence zone almost daily, and both sides digging in deeper, the question is no longer whether this crisis will escalate, but how far either side is willing to go before diplomatic warnings become something far more dangerous.

- Ends

title: In Your Dreams review: Netflix serves up a warm, dreamy, feel-good story
content:
Get ready for the adventure of a nighttime in Stevie and Elliot’s dreams. Netflix’s ‘In Your Dreams’ presents a conventional animated story that gives you warmth, comfort, and feel-good moments without eating up a lot of your time, patience, or tissues. “Same, same but different” was the feeling while watching this template animated film, which is about a twelve-year-old girl’s efforts to fix her family’s problems by literally trying to make her dream come true.

advertisement

Stevie is a simple girl with a happy life—loving parents, cute dreams, and an annoying younger brother, Elliot. Over the years, the happy family moments become scarce, the brother grows older and more annoying, the parents distance themselves from each other, and Stevie’s happy family isn’t happy anymore. While the family is on the verge of splitting up, Stevie and Elliot come across a mysterious book about the Sandman.

Through this book, they gain access to live their dreams, with the catch that if they find the Sandman, who holds the power to make their dream come true, they could save their family from falling apart. What follows is the adventure of a nighttime, where breakfast cereals and lost toys come to life, beds turn into horses, nightmares turn into curses, and Stevie and Elliot are in a race against time to keep the family united.

‘In Your Dreams’, directed by Alex Woo and Erik Benson, presents a simple animated film about the love children have for their parents and the extent they can go to in order to keep their family together and live happily like before. The story, written by Stanley Moore along with the directors, is about a family coming together to save each other from getting lost in their own worlds—some in their dreams and some in reality.

“Short and sweet” is the best way to sum up this film. It may not leave a lasting impact, but it is a breezy watch that brings a few smiles, gives you the feels, makes you love Elliot, and then parts ways—nothing more, nothing less. The film touches on sensitive themes like a child’s emotional state in a breaking family, the mental pressure that comes with it, and how retreating into delusion can feel safer than facing reality. Yet, the presentation is sugar-coated enough to keep anything from feeling triggering, making it an easy and enjoyable 90-minute watch (75–80 minutes without the credit roll).

And the problem? The film looks good, but it never shakes off the feeling that you’ve seen all of this before. The animation style, the world-building, the emotional beats—they echo Pixar and Universal so closely that ‘In Your Dreams’ struggles to form an identity of its own. It plays things safe, relies on familiar formulas, and avoids taking creative risks, resulting in a film that is pleasant enough but hardly memorable.

advertisement

The music is one of the film’s clear wins. Tracks like The Eurythmics’ “Sweet Dreams” and the two Sandman numbers—a cover of the 1954 Chordettes classic and a sample from Metallica’s iconic track—are used smartly. They tap into the parents’ nostalgia while still landing well with younger viewers, creating a soundtrack that feels familiar, fun, and well-placed within the dreamscape.

In the end, ‘In Your Dreams’ is a harmless, feel-good watch–it’s warm, visually pleasant, and sprinkled with enough heart to keep you engaged, even if it never breaks new ground. For anyone hoping for something fresh or inventive, it may feel too familiar. But as a simple bedtime-style adventure about love, loss, and holding a family together, it lands softly—and that’s enough.

- Ends

title: Wrestling body lifts suspension of Olympic medallist Aman Sehrawat for missing weight
content:
The Wrestling Federation of India (WFI) on Friday lifted the suspensions of Olympic medallist Aman Sehrawat and junior grappler Neha Sangwan, who were barred for turning up overweight at major international championships earlier this year.

The development means that both the wrestlers will be able to enter the auction for the upcoming edition of the Pro Wrestling League (PWL).

Paris Games bronze winner Aman was suspended for being overweight during the World Championships in Zagreb, Croatia in September while Neha faced action after her disqualification from the Junior Worlds in Samokov, Bulgaria, in August.

advertisement

Both wrestlers were served show-cause notices — Aman on September 22 and Neha on August 25 — and their replies were received on September 28 and September 18 respectively.

The coaches appointed for the Zagreb event were also issued notices.

According to WFI, the wrestlers, in their written submissions, termed the incident their first lapse and assured the federation that such violations would not recur.

A meeting of the WFI Disciplinary Committee on November 13 examined their replies and noted that both athletes have a strong track record of performances at the international level. The committee recommended a lenient view in light of their past achievements.

Accepting the recommendation, WFI president Sanjay Kumar Singh issued an order lifting their suspensions and allowing them to participate in all future competitions.

The federation, however, cautioned that any repeat offence relating to weight-management or discipline would attract "stricter disciplinary action."

- Ends

title: Tanzanian woman lands in Mumbai with cocaine worth Rs 17.18 crore, arrested
content:
In a swift operation against narcotics trafficking, the Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI) on Friday seized 1.71 KG of cocaine valued at approximately Rs 17.18 crore in the illicit market in Mumbai from one Tanzanian woman who came at Mumbai’s Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport (CSMIA) from Uganda’s Entebbe.

Since the DRI had previous information, it intercepted the passenger upon her arrival. After the detailed examination of her baggage, the body recovered two food packets and one plastic container with white powder. In addition, the DRI also found one pellet pouch, carrying a powdery substance.

advertisement

The officials also found two capsules. All of these recovered items were tested using the NDPS field test kit, and the test showed positive results for cocaine.

The contraband was seized under the provisions of the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (NDPS) Act, 1985, and the passenger was arrested and remanded to judicial custody.

Seized items of cocaine

The operation has added another feather to the hats of DRI, which has been relentlessly pursuing its operations against narcotic substances. Nearly 10 days ago, the DRI, in an operation called Weed Out, seized 42.34 kg of high-grade Hydroponic Weed, valued at approximately Rs 42 crore in an illicit market, from two passengers who came from Bangkok.

title: Tough self-judge? Vaibhav Suryavanshi rates his 42-ball 144 out of 100
content:
Young Vaibhav Suryavanshi appears to be a harsh self-critic. Even after smashing a 42-ball 144 — the fourth-highest individual score by an Indian batter in Twenty20 cricket — the 14-year-old Rajasthan Royals youngster did not seem entirely satisfied with his effort.

When asked to rate his record-breaking knock against the UAE for India A in the opening match of the Emerging Asia Cup in Doha on Friday, Suryavanshi did not hesitate.

advertisement

“75,” he said, speaking to the official broadcasters after being named Player of the Match.

Vaibhav’s 144, along with captain Jitesh Sharma’s 32-ball 83, powered India A to a colossal 297 in 20 overs. The UAE managed only 149 in reply as India began their Rising Stars Asia Cup campaign with a dominant 148-run victory.

The 14-year-old was at his big-hitting best, striking 15 sixes and 11 boundaries. At one point, he even looked set to threaten Chris Gayle’s world record of 175 — the highest score in men’s T20 cricket — before falling while trying to hit off-spinner Muhammad Farazuddin in the 13th over.

Vaibhav cleared the ropes at will at the West End Park International Cricket Stadium in Doha, where the boundaries were not the largest. He sent the ball to all parts of the ground, displaying a dazzling range of strokes against a hapless UAE attack.

NOT HAPPY WITH JUST BOUNDARIES?

In the 11th over from Harshit Kaushik, Vaibhav launched four consecutive sixes before mistiming a fifth attempt. Despite still finding the boundary, he looked visibly displeased.

Asked why, he was blunt and disarmingly honest: “I scored two runs less, that’s why I feel frustrated when I hit only boundaries.”





Vaibhav Sooryavanshi’s interview is guaranteed to melt your heart



Watch #INDvUAE in the #DPWorldAsiaCupRisingStars2025, LIVE NOW on Sony Sports Network TV channels & Sony LIV. #SonySportsNetwork #SonyLIV pic.twitter.com/Obrhy0lE8K— Sony Sports Network (@SonySportsNetwk) November 14, 2025

Yet blind slogging is far from his approach. The Rajasthan Royals prodigy, whose hunger for runs continues to capture attention, insisted there is method behind the mayhem.

“Not every ball I try to hit. I try to play my game and help the team win,” he said.

At just 14, Vaibhav appears remarkably adept at handling pressure. Each time he walks out now, expectations are high. He has set the benchmark — and so far, he has lived up to it.

There is a simple mantra behind his composure.

“It’s all part of the journey. I always wonder where I was playing a few years ago and where I am playing now. I am grateful for all this. There’s no pressure. Fans are here to support me. When I enter the field, I leave everything else behind. My focus is only on the next ball,” he said.

advertisement

From an early age, Suryavanshi showcased prodigious talent in his home state of Bihar. He excelled in youth domestic tournaments before making his first-class debut for Bihar in the Ranji Trophy at just 12 years and 284 days, becoming one of the youngest players ever to feature in the competition.

Advancing into the India Under-19 setup, he made an immediate impact by smashing a 58-ball century in a youth Test against Australia Under-19s — the fastest by an Indian in that format.

During the 2024 ACC Under-19 Asia Cup, he followed it up with quick-fire half-centuries, including 76 off 46 balls against the UAE Under-19s and 67 off 36 against Sri Lanka Under-19s.

Suryavanshi’s ascent then continued at senior level. Signed by the Rajasthan Royals ahead of IPL 2025, he announced himself in style, hammering a blistering century in his third appearance — becoming the youngest centurion in IPL history and reaching the milestone in only 35 balls, the second-fastest in the league.

title: IND vs SA: Kagiso Rabada's availability remains uncertain for 2nd Test
content:
South Africa face uncertainty over Kagiso Rabada's participation in the upcoming second Test against India, following his withdrawal from the series opener at Eden Gardens due to a rib injury. The team management confirmed on Friday that their leading fast bowler is still "undergoing further assessments," leaving his status for the Guwahati Test in doubt.

Rabada sustained the injury during South Africa's first training session on Tuesday, which was followed by a series of medical checks, including a scan on Wednesday and a fitness test on the morning of the match. "So KG (Kagiso Rabada) sustained the injury during the first training session on Tuesday, then he underwent a scan on Wednesday morning, and then underwent a fitness test this morning and was experiencing discomfort and then was ultimately ruled out of the game," the team media manager told PTI.

advertisement

South Africa delayed their decision on Rabada's inclusion until the last possible moment, keeping hopes alive until Friday morning before officially ruling him out. This last-minute change forced a reshuffle in the playing XI as Corbin Bosch was selected to play his fourth Test, joining Marco Jansen and seam bowling all-rounder Wiaan Mulder in the pace attack.

Asked about Rabada's chances for the second Test starting November 22 in Guwahati, the manager responded, "He's still undergoing further assessments with the medical team."

Meanwhile, South Africa were bundled out for just 159 on Day 1 of the first Test at Eden Gardens in Kolkata. After captain Temba Bavuma won the toss and opted to bat, openers Aiden Markram and Ryan Rickelton got the team off a good start, adding 57 runs for first wicket off 63 balls.

However, a sensational spell from Jasprit Bumrah saw South Africa capitulate. He picked up his 16th five-wicket haul, registering figures of 5/27 in 14 overs to bring India into ascendancy.

Later, India finished Day 1 on 37/1 trailing South Africa by 122 runs in the first innings with KL Rahul (13*) and Washington Sundar (6*) at the crease. Yashasvi Jaiswal (12) was the only player dismissed from India, who chopped one back onto his stumps against Marco Jansen.

title: Allies at war, narrative in ruins: Inside Mahagathbandhan's Bihar meltdown
content:
Recording its worst performance since 2010, the Rashtriya Janata Dal (RJD)–Congress grand alliance stands decimated in the Bihar assembly election. As the high-stakes contest delivered a historic victory to the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) led by the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and Janata Dal-United (JDU), here are five key factors that likely contributed to the dramatic collapse of the Tejashwi–Rahul partnership.

advertisement

A QUARRELING ALLIANCE

The decision to project Tejashwi Yadav as the coalition’s chief ministerial candidate proved contentious. “One of the biggest mistakes we made was announcing Tejashwi as CM. We never wanted this, and Congress appeared reluctant throughout,” a senior Congress leader admitted.

Congress leaders privately felt Tejashwi carried heavy baggage — corruption charges and the “jungle raj” legacy. At a time when Prashant Kishor was emphasising credibility and educational qualifications, Tejashwi’s projection divided voters further.

Congress brought in veteran leader Ashok Gehlot as a troubleshooter, but his intervention came too late. At a key rally in Maurya, Gehlot read out a script sent from Delhi, with Congress minder Krishna Allavaru seated at the far end of the stage, prompting speculation of a widening rift.

Posters dominated by Tejashwi signalled that the RJD had overridden Congress. Announcing Mukesh Sahani as deputy CM candidate was another misstep: it alienated the Muslim community, and sections of the Mahadalits who were being actively courted by the NDA.

TEJASHWI AS CM FACE: A FIASCO

The decision to project Tejashwi Yadav as the coalition’s chief ministerial candidate proved contentious. “One of the biggest mistakes we made was announcing Tejashwi as CM. We never wanted this, and Congress appeared reluctant throughout,” a senior Congress leader admitted.

Congress leaders privately felt Tejashwi carried heavy baggage of corruption charges and the “jungle raj” legacy. At a time when Prashant Kishor was emphasising credibility and educational qualifications, Tejashwi’s projection divided voters further.

Congress brought in veteran leader Ashok Gehlot as a troubleshooter, but his intervention came too late. At a key rally in Maurya, Gehlot read out a script sent from Delhi, with Congress minder Krishna Allavaru seated at the far end of the stage, prompting speculation of a widening rift.

Posters dominated by Tejashwi signalled that the RJD had overridden Congress. Announcing Mukesh Sahani as deputy CM candidate was another misstep: it alienated the Muslim community, and sections of the Mahadalits who were being actively courted by the NDA.

GANDHI ENIGMA BUSTED IN BIHAR

The opposition campaign lacked energy and cohesion. By the time Rahul Gandhi returned from his Latin America trip, Congress had already “missed the bus”. During the Voter Adhikar Yatra, the disconnection between him and Tejashwi was evident. Apart from a few joint rallies, Tejashwi received limited support.

advertisement

Rahul’s late entry also came with jibes at PM Modi that many felt were unnecessary. One candidate remarked: “Why did Rahul Gandhi jump into a pond with fishermen in Khagaria? He is the Leader of Opposition. While he accuses Modi of theatrics, he indulges in the same. Does this suit his stature?”

Rahul’s speeches on migration felt outdated in a campaign shaped by Prashant Kishor’s development narrative. Young voters, in particular, struggled to relate. “Rahul Gandhi has no stake here. Bihar is about Nitish Kumar or Tejashwi Yadav, not Prashant Kishor,” one youth said.

Priyanka Gandhi Vadra, usually an aggressive campaigner, also failed to make an impact. Her presence was limited, and she appeared to play a secondary role: a far cry from her influence in Uttar Pradesh or Karnataka.

SIR: THE WRONG CAMPAIGN ISSUE

Rahul Gandhi launched the Voter Adhikar Yatra after his press conference on alleged “vote chori” (election fraud). But the SIR issue fizzled out quickly. While Rahul remained fixated on it, the Congress failed to recognise that the message did not align with Bihar’s political realities.

A senior RJD leader told India Today: “While the contest was close, Rahul’s yatra drained our manpower. He insisted it end with a mega rally at Gandhi Maidan. Our workers were already stretched. Many carried Congress flags, but we didn’t receive similar cooperation.”

advertisement

The SIR narrative became stale, while the NDA aggressively countered it by highlighting schemes, cash transfers, and the Lakhpati Didi Yojana, especially effective among women voters.

CHAOS OVER SEAT SHARING

Seat-sharing negotiations spiralled from Patna to Delhi, with tensions escalating daily. Unlike earlier years, when Lalu Prasad Yadav and Sonia Gandhi defused crises, this time there were no senior mediators to keep the alliance intact.

“Rahul Gandhi is happy with the state unit’s seat proposal. He has told us to negotiate firmly,” Bihar Congress president Rajesh Ram said after meeting him at 10 Janpath. Congress leader Krishna Allavaru, close aide of Rahul Gandhi, remained firm on certain “winnable seats”, further straining ties.

Talks eventually froze, and allies ended up fighting each other in nearly a dozen constituencies. This not only weakened the campaign but also deepened resentment among party cadres, leading to a complete breakdown of unity.

title: A foreign country using Pakistan soil to hit Afghanistan with drones?
content:
Peace talks between Afghanistan and Pakistan in Turkey look to have hit a dead end even as a fragile ceasefire holds after a brief war that saw hundreds killed earlier in September and October. Pakistan made a rare admission during the talks, that it has an agreement with a foreign country based on which drone attacks were carried out, according to TOLO News of Afghanistan.

advertisement

The Pakistani delegation expressed helplessness in preventing drone attacks inside Afghanistan because it was bound by an agreement with a third country, the report said, citing a source.

"It was also revealed that, for the first time, Pakistan admitted to having an agreement with a foreign country allowing drone strikes, and that it cannot prevent such strikes because breaking the agreement is not possible," TOLO News reported on the peace talks being held in Istanbul, Turkey.

There was no clarity on the foreign country with which Pakistan has an agreement.

An agreement remained elusive even as the Pakistani delegation asked the Afghan team to agree that Islamabad had the right to carry out strikes inside Afghanistan during attacks by the TTP.

The source noted that the Pakistani delegation appeared disorganised, offering no coherent arguments and seeming more focused on pulling back from the negotiations. At one point, they even requested that the Afghan side acknowledge Pakistan's right to strike Afghan territory in response to TTP attacks, TOLO News reported.

This report comes just months after Pakistan inked a landmark Strategic Mutual Defence Agreement with Saudi Arabia in September, committing to mutual defence against any external threats and deepening both military and economic ties.

At the same time, Islamabad has boosted its defence and strategic alignment with the United States under President Donald Trump. This was highlighted by several high-level meetings, including PM Shehbaz Sharif rushing to meet Trump at the Oval Office visit, with army chief Asim Munir in a glittering attendance.

Moreover, Trump has publicly demanded the return of Bagram airbase from Taliban-controlled Afghanistan. He even threatened that if it did not get the airbase, "bad things would happen". Sharif, meanwhile, has repeatedly lauded "Trump's leadership", praising his "role in the India-Pakistan ceasefire as a historic achievement". He even nominated Trump for the Nobel Peace Prize.

The Afghanistan-Pakistan talks in Istanbul ended inconclusively, with both sides blaming each other for failing to reach a long-term truce. News agency Reuters, citing two anonymous sources familiar with the discussions, reported that the negotiations yielded no resolution.

The brief Pakistan-Afghanistan war erupted in early September. Escalating TTP attacks on Pakistani forces sparked deadly clashes between both neighbours. This made Islamabad launch precision airstrikes deep into Afghan territory, targeting suspected militant hideouts in Kabul and Kandahar.

advertisement

Drone strikes and JF-17 jet bombings left over 200 dead on both sides. The Taliban reported dozens of civilian casualties, including women and children in an eastern marketplace.

Pakistan said its targets were only TTP commanders.

In retaliation, Afghan forces shelled Pakistani border posts along the Durand Line.

At least 23 soldiers were killed and hundreds wounded. Heavy artillery exchanges and ground clashes broke out in hotspots like Spin Boldak and Kurram.

Days before both countries reached a ceasefire, Afghanistan's Taliban government said that Pakistan had carried out two drone strikes on Kabul the previous day.

Alarmed by the escalation and risk of regional conflict, Pakistan sought mediation from Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the United States. Diplomatic pressure led to a fragile 48-hour ceasefire on October 15, which has held tenuously amid accusations of violations.

title: SRK launches first-ever property named after him: My mother would have been proud
content:
Shah Rukh Khan attended a mega event in Mumbai on Friday, to unveil the first-ever property named after him. The Dubai-based property, Shahrukhz Danube, is a 56-storey tower, featuring approximately 450 sq ft of premium office space.

“My mother would have been very happy. It is a very big honour. When my kids come, I will tell them - ‘Papa ka naam likha hai, Papa ki building hai (papa’s name is written on it, it’s papa building),” he said the event, also attended by Danube’s founder and chairman Rizwan Sajan.

advertisement

Characteristically, as you would expect from an SRK evening, the event did not lack entertainment. The superstar regaled the guests with his trademark wit, and also brought alive whiffs of Bollywood magic, highlighted by his recreation of iconic moments from 'Om Shanti Om' and ‘Don’.

"I don't find myself that important that I put anything in my name except my films. Films are part of my profession and worship,” said Shah Rukh. To this Farah Khan, who was also a guest, said: “Shah Rukh has given his name to four people: Gauri, Aryan, Suhana and AbRam."

The classic SRK wit, of course, kept coming. He said he had become "Eid ka chand (Moon from the pious festival in Islam)... kam dikhta hu but jab dikhta hoon, kamaal hota hai (I am seen rarely, but when I am seen, it is spectacular)."

In another light-hearted moment, Shah Rukh told the audience that Rizwan wanted to have a viral moment with him. The actor then taught him his signature open-arm romantic pose from his movies. He also taught him the Don walk and his iconic 'Om Shanti Om' dialogue: "Itni shiddat se main tumhe paane ki koshish ki hai"(I have craved you with so much devotion and passion)."

While speaking about his association with Danube property, Shah Rukh said, "I never found myself to be in this position. But Rizwan Bhai told me about his wife, who has been quite unwell, and Insha Allah (by God's mercy) she will soon be fine. It touched my heart. First time, I agreed to this idea with what Adil explained. Their team had a simple idea: A lot of people come to big cities to make their homes. Their dreams are to make businesses and houses. If I could be a part of it and an inspiration, it would be the greatest gift for me."

Notable amenities at Shahrukhz Danube include a helipad and a swimming pool. The project is expected to be completed within three to four years, and its entrance will feature a statue of the actor for visitors' to cluck photos with. Danube plans to expand this tower concept to other cities as well.

advertisement

Shah Rukh will next be seen in Siddharth Anand's 'King', featuring Deepika Padukone, his actor-daughter Suhana Khan, Rani Mukerji, Abhay Verma, Abhishek Bachchan and others in pivotal characters.

The actor's home company, Red Chillies Entertainment, recently backed the Netflix series 'The Ba***ds of Bollywood', marking his son Aryan Khan's directorial debut.

title: Delhi man claims WFH denied despite headache from pollution, shares chat with senior
content:
An employee of a Delhi-based company has shared screenshots of his conversation with his senior after he was denied work-from-home despite complaining of health issues caused by the worsening air pollution in the national capital.

In the Reddit post on r/IndianWorkplace, the employee explained that he had been suffering from severe headaches for two days due to the polluted air but had still been reporting to the office regularly.

advertisement

He also said that he stayed back till 8:45 pm the previous day because of project commitments, even while managing his health.

However, he requested just one day of WFH to avoid aggravating his condition while continuing to work. His senior, but, wasn’t convinced and responded saying that “everyone is suffering from pollution” and allowing WFH was “difficult” since others were coming in.

The employee also claimed that the team had been requesting air purifiers for over a week, but management refused, giving “vague reasons.”

Thus, he wrote that the same pollution affecting employees’ health was now being dismissed, and instead he was told to “take a day off and still work,” which he called “absurd.”

See the post here:

Here are the screenshots of his WhatsApp chat with his senior:

In the comments section, a user advised, “Just take sick leave and let work fall where it may. Your health is most important. If the work is critical enough, they will offer WFH themselves.”

One of the users pointed out the legality of the manager’s suggestion: “That’s unethical and illegal. You can’t take leave and still be working. If it’s caught during a company audit, you will be questioned.”

The discussion continues as Delhi’s pollution levels remain a pressing health concern.

On Thursday morning, Delhi woke up to dense smog as air quality remained in the 'severe' category for the third consecutive day.

Delhi’s air quality plunged into the ‘severe’ category on Tuesday evening for the first time this season, with the overall AQI reaching 428, the highest pollution level recorded this year.

title: Goli maaroge mujhe, asks Uber cab driver as Delhi man pulls out gun during dispute
content:
An Uber cab driver in Delhi’s Laxmi Nagar recorded a tense confrontation after a passenger allegedly pulled out a gun during an argument over a ride booking.

As described in the post shared by NCMIndia Council For Men Affairs, the passenger had booked two rides at once, following which both drivers arrived at the location.

When one of the drivers questioned him, a dispute occurred and the passenger took out a firearm as the driver began recording the incident immediately.

advertisement

The driver could be heard asking the passenger why he was showing a gun and whether he intended to shoot him.

“Yeh kya pistol dikhaa rahe ho tum mujhe? Goli maaroge mujhe? (Why are you showing me a pistol? Will you shoot me?)”

Startled, the passenger responded that he was leaving the spot, saying “Main jaa rahaa hoon yahaan se (I’m leaving from here).”

The video showed the driver moving closer to record the weapon on camera, while the passenger repeatedly attempted to hide it behind his back.

The driver insisted, “Pistol dikhaao na (Show the pistol, then),” but the man refused. Bystanders eventually intervened and urged the driver to let the matter go.

Watch the video here:

As the now-viral video sparked outrage, users reiterated that the passenger was entirely at fault for booking two rides and pulling out a pistol in a crowded area, and called for strict action.

Another user argued that the driver’s repeated attempts to get close to the weapon could have escalated the situation, potentially giving the armed man grounds to claim self-defence.

Several others tagged Delhi Police, urging them to identify the passenger and take necessary action.

title: iPhone 16 Pro price drops by Rs 13,901, should you buy it over iPhone 17 Pro?
content:
If you have been thinking about upgrading to a premium iPhone, this might be the right time. The iPhone 16 Pro is currently selling at a discounted price on Flipkart, making it one of the most attractive flagship deals right now. However, with the latest iPhone 17 Pro already on the shelves, this also brings the confusion of whether getting the iPhone 16 Pro is the right choice or if you should get your hands on the latest flagship to enjoy the most premium and best experience from Apple.

advertisement

Let us help you solve your confusion so you can choose if you should seal the ongoing deal from Flipkart.

Closer look at the Flipkart deal on iPhone 16 Pro

First, let’s check the deal on Flipkart. The e-commerce site is offering the iPhone 16 Pro at Rs 99,999, down from the listed price of Rs 1,09,999. But you can save more. With select bank discounts — such as Rs 4,000 off via Flipkart Axis or SBI Credit Cards — the price effectively drops to Rs 95,999, making it a Rs 13,901 discount and one of the lowest available deals for most users. On top of this, Flipkart is offering an exchange bonus of up to Rs 68,050, depending on the smartphone you trade in. But let’s not talk of the exchange deals because that is so dependent on your current phone and its condition etc.

So, is the iPhone 16 Pro a good deal at Rs 99,999 with this discount?

It’s worth noting that Apple has discontinued the iPhone 16 Pro and Pro Max to push its latest flagship, and the iPhone 16 Pro is currently available only at select retail stores. Most online websites aren’t selling the phone right now, with many showing it as out of stock. They may drop in limited stock here and there to keep up the hype. Even Flipkart is showing limited availability. So getting your hands on this flagship for under Rs 1,00,000 right now is definitely not a bad idea.

But is it worth buying compared to the iPhone 17 Pro?

Now this really depends on what you want from your next iPhone. The iPhone 16 Pro, launched in 2024, still packs a strong punch with its 6.3-inch Super Retina XDR display, ProMotion 120Hz refresh rate, the A18 Pro chipset, and a versatile camera system that includes a 48-megapixel main shooter, a 48-megapixel ultra-wide lens with autofocus, and a 5 telephoto camera. It also features a titanium build, improved battery efficiency, and USB-C support — all of which make it a very capable flagship even today.

However, what makes the decision tricky is that the iPhone 17 Pro is a fairly substantial upgrade. It brings the newer A19 Pro chip, which offers stronger sustained performance and better thermal management. The thermal management itself makes it a better choice compared to the iPhone 16 Pro.

advertisement

Then its display is brighter, tougher, and more efficient, and Apple has updated the camera system in the iPhone 17 Pro with improved low-light performance, faster processing, and a more advanced telephoto setup. And Apple has brought back the aluminium body, which means it is slightly lighter compared to the iPhone 16 Pro, although the older iPhone sure looks more jazzier with its titanium frame.

Apple has also improved battery life, cooling, and long-term software support with the iPhone 17 Pro. So, if you want a phone that will last you the next four to five years with absolute top-tier performance, the newer Pro model gives you more breathing room.

But the price matters

Of course, we cannot ignore the price. At Rs 95,999 after offers, the iPhone 16 Pro is undoubtedly a good deal. You are getting a flagship-grade device with incredible cameras, strong performance, a premium titanium build, and long-term support, making it a great deal.

However, if you want to experience the very best Apple currently offers, and you don’t mind spending the extra amount, the iPhone 17 Pro will give you better performance headroom, improved cameras, and a more future-proof package. It costs around Rs 1,30,000 which is a bit of premium compared to the current price of the iPhone 16 Pro. But we feel that better cooling and better set of cameras, including arguably the best selfie camera in any phone, makes it worth it.

title: Launched This Week: GoPro Max 2, Dell Pro Plus Earphones and 4 more new gadgets to check out
content:
A lot happened in tech in India this week. We had some drama on X (formerly Twitter) between Elon Musk and writer Joyce Carol Oates, Microsoft brought Xbox Cloud Gaming to India, OnePlus unveiled its latest flagship — the OnePlus 15 — so on and so forth. Amid all the usual tech buzz, we also saw a wave of new launches across brands. So, keeping up with our weekly ritual, India Today Tech is back to update you on what’s new in the market. Who knows — one of these products might just be the one you were looking for.

advertisement

From GoPro’s expanded India line-up to Dell’s earbuds — yes, not laptops but earbuds — to a massive 100-inch smart TV from Acerpure and more, here are some of the top launches from this week.

GoPro Max 2

This week, GoPro expanded its India line-up with three new devices aimed at creators and everyday users alike. The main highlight is the Max 2, GoPro’s next-gen 360 camera capable of True 8K capture, featuring 10-bit colour, twist-off replaceable lenses, built-in GPS, a six-mic audio setup and a range of new in-camera POV modes.

Alongside the Max 2, the company also introduced the GoPro Lit Hero, a tiny 93-gram lifestyle camera with a built-in light for all kinds of shots, offering 4K 60 video, slo-mo and GoPro’s signature rugged design. Rounding off the trio, GoPro launched the Fluid Pro AI, an AI-powered gimbal that works with GoPros, smartphones and compact cameras, offering face and body tracking, three-axis stabilisation, an integrated fill light and up to 18 hours of runtime.

If you’re thinking about picking up any of the new GoPro devices, you can check out these models on Amazon, Flipkart, Croma, Reliance Digital and authorised imaging retailers. In India, the GoPro Max 2 is now available at an introductory bundle price of Rs 54,999 with a complimentary 64GB SD card. The Lit Hero will go on sale in the first week of December for Rs 28,500, while the Fluid Pro AI gimbal will arrive in early January 2026 for Rs 23,000.

AcerPure 100-inch QLED TV

How big is too big for a smart TV? Well, for anyone who loves a big screen, Acerpure has launched its new flagship Nitro Z Series 100-inch TV in India. This smart TV is built for users who want a true cinema-like experience at home. The QLED panel supports a 144Hz native refresh rate, Dolby Vision, HDR10 and MEMC. It runs on Google TV with 3GB RAM and 32GB storage, while features like ALLM and VRR should please gamers looking for low-latency performance. You also get 60W Dolby Atmos speakers, Dual Wi-Fi, Film Maker Mode and a single remote that can control multiple devices.

With a screen this size, Acerpure has set the price high — but still fairly competitive compared to rivals. You can buy the Acerpure Nitro Z Series 100-inch smart TV exclusively on Flipkart, priced at Rs 2,59,999. AcerPure 100-inch QLED TV

Blaupunkt SBW600 Emperor soundbar

Now, if you already have a smart TV — or are planning to get one — what better companion than a soundbar, right? Giving you a few more options to choose from, Blaupunkt has introduced its latest high-end home theatre system in India, the SBW600 Emperor, a 12.1.4-channel Dolby Atmos soundbar that, according to the brand, will offer users a full-blown cinematic experience.

The soundbar comes packed with 17 precision-tuned neodymium drivers, including centre, side and up-firing units, paired with an 8-inch wireless subwoofer capable of reaching 20Hz bass. The rear satellites also fire both forward and upward, creating a layered 3D sound field with zero-lag wireless connectivity. The bar itself features an aerospace-grade metal body, an adaptive LED interface and EQ modes, with connectivity options including HDMI eARC, optical and AUX-in. It even comes with a wireless mic designed for karaoke, with support for a second mic if you fancy a duet.

advertisement

Blaupunkt says the SBW600 Emperor will be available in India soon, although the exact pricing and sale dates haven’t been revealed yet.

BenQ screen Bar Halo 2

Too much screen time can harm your eyes. So for anyone glued to their computer screen be it for work, gaming, or a casual Netflix night, BenQ has launched the ScreenBar Halo 2 in India. It’s a monitor light aimed at professionals, creators and gamers who work in dim or changing lighting conditions.

According to BenQ, this new model uses a dual-light system with a redesigned triple-curvature backlight that provides 423 per cent wider coverage than the previous version, which, according to the brand, helps reduce contrast and eye strain. Its ASYM-Light optical tech directs light onto the desk instead of the screen, avoiding glare and reflections entirely. Users can fine-tune brightness and colour temperature through an upgraded wireless control dial, while a revamped zinc-alloy clamp allows the bar to rest gently on everything from ultra-thin to curved monitors without causing damage. The Screen Bar Halo 2 also comes with smart features such as motion detection, auto-dimming and memory settings.

advertisement

If you’re interested in this rather unique accessory, the BenQ Screen Bar Halo 2 is now available in India for Rs 17,490 and can be purchased via the BenQ India E-Store, Amazon India and select retail partners. BenQ screen Bar Halo 2

Dell Pro Plus earbuds

Over the last few months, we’ve seen several new PCs launched by Dell. But this week, the brand introduced something a little different for its Indian customers. The PC maker has unveiled its new Dell Pro Plus earbuds (EB525) in India. The earbuds are designed with advanced noise filtering, voice optimisation and all-day comfort in mind.

If you are interested in the newly launched Dell Pro Plus earbuds (EB525) they are now available for business customers in India, priced at Rs 18,699.

Urban Vibe Clip 2

Home-grown brand Urban has recently expanded its audio line-up with the Vibe Clip 2 open-ear wireless earbuds in India. And these earbuds come with quite a unique design. They have a clip-on, open-ear style that sits around the ear instead of sealing the ear canal. Urban says this design makes the Clip 2 more suitable for jogging, cycling, daily commutes or outdoor work, as it keeps users aware of their surroundings.

advertisement

On the feature side, the Vibe Clip 2 uses large 16.2mm dynamic drivers for detailed audio and deep bass, while AI Environmental Noise Cancellation helps improve call clarity. They also include Bluetooth 5.3, low-latency mode, dual-device pairing, touch controls, voice-assistant support and IPX5 water resistance. The earbuds promise up to 60 hours of total playtime, including 18 hours on a single charge. Urban Vibe Clip 2

The Urban Vibe Clip 2 is now available at an introductory price of Rs 1,999, and you can purchase them through Urban’s official website, Amazon, Flipkart and select offline retail partners across India.

- Ends

title: No magic, just mastery: Jasprit Bumrah on dismantling South Africa in Kolkata Test
content:
It looked mystical. On a dry Eden Gardens surface, tailored for India’s first four-man spin attack in a Test in 13 years, Jasprit Bumrah produced a bowling effort for the ages. Leading the attack on Day 1 of the first Test against South Africa in Kolkata, Bumrah was at his ruthless best, finishing with figures of 5 for 27 in 14 overs, five of which were maidens.

advertisement

World Test champions South Africa won the toss and opted to bat on a bright morning in Kolkata. Openers Ryan Rickelton and Aiden Markram gave the visitors a fine start, moving briskly to 57 for 0 in just 10 overs. IND vs SA, 1st Test Day 1 Highlights | Scorecard

However, Bumrah struck in the 11th over of the innings, bowling Rickelton with an absolute peach. Coming around the wicket, he got the ball to land on the seam and shape away just enough to beat the outside edge and knock back the off stump.

Bumrah had made life miserable for the two openers in his first spell, conceding just nine runs in his opening five overs. The ball was behaving unpredictably, with uneven bounce appearing as early as the first over. Yet whenever loose deliveries came from the other end, the South African openers punished them.

The pressure Bumrah built in those first 10 overs paid dividends as he removed Rickelton before producing another ripper—one that kicked from a good length—to dismiss Markram in the 13th over. South Africa collapsed from 57 for 0 to 62 for 2, with Bumrah delivering exactly what India needed with the new ball at a stage when the visitors looked poised to seize the advantage.

At the other end, Mohammed Siraj leaked 25 runs in his first three overs.

“In Test cricket, if you need success, you need to be patient,” Bumrah said after becoming the first fast bowler since Dale Steyn in 2006 to take a five-wicket haul with the red ball on Day 1 of a Test match in India.

Jasprit Bumrah does it again, a sensational five-wicket haul, his 16th in Test cricket!

A pin-point yorker lights up Eden Gardens, uproots Maharaj, and seals South Africa’s innings at 159 all out.



India’s spearhead. India’s show-stopper. #INDvSA 1st Test LIVE NOW pic.twitter.com/GBiLkBTmIm— Star Sports (@StarSportsIndia) November 14, 2025

“Especially on these pitches. Here, the outfield is quite fast and the wicket is hard. If you are very desperate here and try to bowl magic balls, you can be at risk of leaking runs,” he said, explaining what was required to succeed on a tricky Eden Gardens pitch.

advertisement

“You have to control your temptations. You need to assess the run-scoring options for the opposition batter. Every ball won’t do magic here. There are some deliveries that cause trouble to the batters. You need to consistently bowl in good areas to get rewards. In Test cricket, your ability to remain patient will be tested. Only in a few matches will you get 6–7 wickets in heaps. In the majority, you need to keep bowling well. Sometimes you won’t get wickets even when you’re bowling well. But if you keep working hard, you will have days when wickets come.”

OLD BALL HELPED BETTER?

Bumrah demonstrated just how adept he has become at reading conditions. Even seasoned pundits struggled to assess the pitch, which appeared dry and offered variable bounce from one end.

But Bumrah said he tried to decode whatever the surface was offering, noting that excessive movement with the new ball can sometimes make it difficult to settle on the ideal length.

It was a perfect demonstration of a champion’s mindset as Bumrah stressed the importance of not getting carried away by the assistance on offer.

advertisement

“Yes, this pitch has a bit of help. It’s not a dead wicket. But you need to be patient. If you’re off the mark, run-scoring can be quick. If you’re not disciplined, you will pay the price,” he said.

Bumrah explained that it became easier to bowl with a slightly older ball, saying the pronounced seam made control difficult earlier in the day.

“It’s a harder ball game. When the ball is new, the deviation will be a lot quicker. Once the ball softens, the deviation lessens and then your accuracy comes into play. When I bowled the first over, everything happened: the ball swung, it stayed low, it kicked high. It’s a little difficult to understand what the right length is. You keep bowling and keep figuring things out.

“For the first three or four balls, everything happened: one ball kicked, one kept low. Where do you bowl? Then you see, okay, this is what it’s shaping into. As the ball became a little softer, it settled down; the deviation wasn’t consistent. When the ball is nice and hard, the seam is pronounced and it will do a little more. Once it softens, it becomes slightly easier.”

advertisement

Bumrah’s 16th five-wicket haul helped India bundle South Africa out for 159. In response, India reached 37 for 1 in 20 overs before bad light brought an early end to play. India lost Yashasvi Jaiswal early, but KL Rahul and new No. 3 Washington Sundar battled through the fading light to ensure there were no further hiccups.

It will not be an easy task batting on this surface in Kolkata. But without Kagiso Rabada, who missed out due to injury, it remains to be seen whether South Africa have the bowling depth to make the most of the conditions at Eden Gardens.

- Ends

title: Rising Stars Asia Cup: Vaibhav Suryavanshi smashes 32-ball hundred for India A vs UAE
content:
14-year-old Vaibhav Suryavanshi set the stage on fire in India A's opening match against the UAE in the Rising Stars Asia Cup in Doha on Friday, November 14. The Rajasthan Royals star hit a hundred, and he got there in just 32 balls, smashing 10 boundaries and nine sixes by then.

Vaibhav Suryavanshi bettered his own record, bringing up his second hundred in Twenty20 cricket. Vaibhav hit a 35-ball hundred in the IPL for Rajasthan against Gujarat Titans in 2025 and set the record for the fastest century by an Indian batter in the IPL.

advertisement

The 32-ball hundred for Vaibhav on Friday is the joint third-fastest by an Indian in men's T20 cricket.

Vaibhav Sooryavanshi is a superstar. Period.



| A statement century from our Boss Baby to set the tone



Watch #INDvUAE in the #DPWorldAsiaCupRisingStars2025, LIVE NOW on Sony Sports Network TV channels & Sony LIV. #SonySportsNetwork #SonyLIV pic.twitter.com/K0RIoK4Fyv — Sony Sports Network (@SonySportsNetwk) November 14, 2025

Vaibhav had an opportunity to break Chris Gayle's all-time T20I record of 175. However, the young left-hander was out, caught in deep cover in the 13th over when he was batting on 144. Off-spinner, Muhammad Farazuddin, got the big wicket, leaving the spectators in the stands disappointed.

Vaibhav was dispatching the UAE bowlers to all parts of the ground. At one stage, the attack looked so jaded that they resorted to bowling wides in an attempt to escape the onslaught from the young batting superstar.

Vaibhav was gutted as he expressed his frustration on the field, knowing fully well he had missed out on a chance to script history. Going at the rate Vaibhav was going, the teenager was in line to become the first batter to hit a double hundred in T20 cricket.

However, he was dismissed for 144 in just 42 deliveries.

FASTEST T20 HUNDREDS BY INDIA

1. Urvil Patel - 28 balls for Gujarat vs Tripura in Indore in 2024

2. Abhishek Sharma - 28 balls for Punjab vs Meghalaya in Saurashtra in 2024

3. Rishabh Pant - 32 balls - Delhi vs Himachal Pradesh in Delhi in 2018

4. Vaibhav Suryavanshi - 32 balls - India A vs UAE in Doha in 2025*

Vaibhav finished with 15 sixes and 11 boundaries as he raced past his peers, including Priyansh Arya, captain Jitesh Sharma and Nehal Wadhera. The young batter from Bihar was on a league of his own as he tore into the UAE bowling attack, which had no clue as to how to stop the Indian batting sensation.

It was also the fourth-highest score by an Indian in T20 cricket.

Tilak Varma - 151 (67 balls) for Hyderabad vs Meghalaya in 2024 Shreyas Iyer - 147 (55 balls) for Mumbai vs Sikkim in 2019 Punit Bisht – 145 (51 balls) for Meghalaya vs Mizoram in 2021 Vaibhav Suryavanshi - 144 (42 balls) for India A vs UAE in 2025

advertisement

India fielded a power-packed squad, with an array of rising IPL stars including Vaibhav, for the Rising Stars Asia Cup. Until the last edition of the tournament, India had fielded U-23 players, but the selectors made an exception and sent the likes of Jitesh Sharma for the tournament.

title: Delhi blast | New white collar terror
content:
The message the Jammu & Kashmir Police posted on social media site X at 6:10 pm on November 10 was short and terse: “You can run but can’t hide!” It was directed at Umar un-Nabi, a 32-year-old doctor at Al-Falah Hospital in Faridabad. He was among the last key members of a white-collar terror module they had been cracking down on—one suspected of planning major strikes in the National Capital Region and elsewhere. In the preceding two weeks, the J&K Police had arrested key members of the module, mainly doctors like Umar, but he himself had proved elusive, and they had hoped to nab him that fateful Monday morning. Having got wind of his impending arrest, Umar fled his Faridabad house in an explosives-laden white Hyundai i20 at 7:30 am. The J&K Police had reportedly asked their Delhi counterparts to issue a BOLO (Be On Look Out) notice for him.

advertisement

title: No place to take a break | Highway amenities
content:
G urugram-based Cyril Nair, a senior software executive, was en route to Jaisalmer with family when, just an hour along the new access-controlled highway, his toddler son piped up with some urgency: “Daddy, I need to pee.” They were in the middle of what seemed like nowhere, ominous clouds thundering overhead and heavy rain lashing the windshield. All 44-year-old Nair could see through the persevering wipers were a few metres of asphalt. No sign of a rest stop anywhere. “I had to tell my family that we couldn’t stop... We had to drive another 30 km to find a place with a decent wash room.”

advertisement

title: Rajasthan's recruitment scam | Inside the fraud factory
content:
F or countless young aspirants, a government job is the ultimate prize—a ticket to stability, respect and a secure future. But in Rajasthan, that dream has curdled into a marketplace of deceit. Leaked papers, Bluetooth-aided cheating, dummy candidates, forged certificates and quota scams have riddled the very recruitment process. Desperation has bred collusion, where aspirants, middlemen and insiders come together to con the system. The cost has been high—for honest aspirants and for the credibility of public service itself.

title: Tamil Nadu | Saffron's southern paradox
content:
A s india’s polity navigates yet another cycle of electoral rhetoric, Tamil Nadu has acquired a curious duality for the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP): it is a name, an idea, an entity that’s at once desired and demonised. To be more precise, Tamil Nadu is mocked outside its borders, and courted at home. This split in the saffron political imagination has not gone unnoticed within the ruling DMK, as Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s recent campaign speeches supplied fresh evidence. title: Chinese astronauts land safely on Earth after being stuck due to vehicle damage
content:
Chinese astronauts aboard Shenzhou-20 crewed spacecraft safely returned to Earth after a brief delay caused by space debris impact concerns on their return module.

The mission, part of China’s continuous presence aboard the Tiangong space station, faced an unprecedented obstacle when the return capsule developed a minor crack likely caused by orbital debris.

Originally scheduled to land on November 5, 2025, the crew's return was postponed pending detailed impact analysis and risk assessment conducted by the China Manned Space Agency (CMSA). Engineers determined that the Shenzhou-20 return module was unsafe for reentry and, to ensure astronaut safety, the crew switched to use the docked Shenzhou-21 spacecraft for their journey home.

advertisement Welcome home. Shenzhou-20 astronauts CHEN Dong, CHEN Zhongrui and WANG Jie, in Shenzhou-21 spacecraft, safely landed at DongFeng landing site at 08:40UTC. https://t.co/iLw8zCY8lh pic.twitter.com/QddRfHA4tG — China 'N Asia Spaceflight (@CNSpaceflight) November 14, 2025

This marked the first time a Shenzhou mission’s return was delayed due to debris damage, highlighting the growing threats posed by space junk in low Earth orbit.

The three-person crew, including mission commander Senior Colonel Chen Dong, remained aboard Tiangong during the assessment and continued joint scientific experiments with their relief crew on Shenzhou-21, which arrived in late October.

Shenzhou-21’s return capsule functioned as the crew’s lifeboat, allowing a safe Earth reentry within the designated landing window on November 13, 2025.

Meanwhile, CMSA plans to launch an uncrewed Shenzhou-22 mission soon, tasked with delivering additional cargo and supplies to Tiangong and supporting ongoing station operations.

The incident underscores the persistent hazard of space debris, ranging from paint flecks to defunct satellite fragments, traveling at extremely high speeds that can cause significant damage.

Even millimeter-sized debris can puncture spacecraft, necessitating updated safety protocols, debris tracking, and international cooperation to safeguard astronauts.

Despite the disruption, Chinese space officials emphasised that all life support systems aboard Tiangong functioned normally and that the crew remained safe throughout the process.

The successful return aboard Shenzhou-21 reiterated China’s commitment to maintaining a continuous human presence in orbit while managing emerging challenges of increasing congestion in space.

title: A walking tank: Crocodile that looked like a dinosaur before dinosaurs existed
content:
A newly discovered carnivorous lizard, named Tainrakuasuchus bellator, challenges popular perceptions by resembling a dinosaur but actually being a precursor of modern crocodiles.

This armour-plated reptile lived approximately 240 million years ago, just before the rise of dinosaurs, during the Triassic Period. As a member of the Pseudosuchia group, ancestors to today’s crocodiles and alligators, it was among the dominant predators of its ecosystem.

advertisement

Described in the peer-reviewed Journal of Systematic Palaeontology, Tainrakuasuchus bellator measured about 2.4 meters long and weighed roughly 60 kilograms. With a long neck and nimble movements, it used its slender jaw filled with sharp, recurved teeth to catch and hold prey, making it an agile hunter.

Despite its size, it was not the largest predator around, giants reaching seven meters roamed the same environment.

Lead author Dr Rodrigo Temp Mller from Universidade Federal de Santa Maria, Brazil highlights that although the lizard resembled dinosaurs superficially, anatomical differences such as the structure of its pelvis clearly distinguish it from them. The discovery offers new insights into pre-dinosaur biodiversity.

The discovery sheds light on the complexity of ancient ecosystems with various pseudosuchian species occupying diverse ecological niches.

The fossil was discovered during a May 2025 excavation in Dona Francisca, southern Brazil, revealing partial skeleton parts including the lower jaw, vertebral column, and pelvic girdle.

The preserved bony plates, or osteoderms, covering its back resemble those of modern crocodiles, and researchers believe it moved on four limbs like its relatives.

The name combines Guarani and Greek origins: ‘tain’ meaning tooth and ‘rakua’ meaning pointed, paired with ‘suchus’ for crocodile, while ‘bellator,’ Latin for warrior, honours the resilience of the people of Rio Grande do Sul after recent natural disasters.

Dr Muller describes the find as “extremely rare” and emphasises its evolutionary significance, reflecting early connections between South America and Africa when continents formed the supercontinent Pangaea.

The discovery offers new insights into pre-dinosaur biodiversity and the adaptive strategies of reptiles in arid environments 240 million years ago, illustrating a rich and varied prehistoric world.

title: Honda removes CBR1000RR-R Fireblade SP and Rebel 500 from India website
content:
Honda Motorcycle and Scooter India (HMSI) has quietly removed the newly launched CBR1000RR-R Fireblade SP and Rebel 500 from its official website, just months after both models made their return to the Indian market. The Fireblade SP was reintroduced as Honda’s flagship supersport, while the Rebel 500 marked the cruiser’s first official sales run in India.

advertisement

Honda CBR1000RR-R Fireblade SP

The CBR1000RR-R Fireblade SP was relaunched in September at Rs 28.99 lakh (ex-showroom) and arrived as the most track-focused litre-class motorcycle Honda has sold in India. Powered by a 999cc inline-four engine producing 215bhp at 14,000rpm and 113Nm at 12,000rpm, the new Fireblade SP features a short-stroke, race-derived architecture, a semi-cam design, and Honda’s new Two Motor Throttle By Wire system that independently manages each cylinder pair for more precise power delivery. Its suite of electronic rider aids is extensive, thanks to a six-axis IMU that supports features such as three-level ABS with Race, Track and Standard modes, a three-level Honda Electronic Steering Damper, updated wheelie control, nine-level Honda Selectable Torque Control, and three-level engine braking. A 5-inch TFT display serves as the command centre, allowing riders to choose from preset modes or customise settings, including entering rider weight for automatic preload adjustment.

Complementing the powertrain is a thoroughly track-oriented hardware package. Aerodynamics have been improved with new HRC-designed winglets that reduce yaw by 10 percent, while an RC213V-S-inspired swingarm provides greater rear grip and stability. The Fireblade SP also gets hlins Smart Electronic Control 3.0 suspension, including NPX USD forks and a TTX36 rear shock, offering precision damping and excellent compliance at high speeds. Honda has also revised ergonomics by raising the handlebars and lowering the footpegs for better rider control, and the standard Akrapovi titanium exhaust has been tuned for a cleaner, more progressive note that intensifies with engine rpm.

Honda Rebel 500

The Rebel 500, on the other hand, was launched in May at 5.12 lakh (ex-showroom, Gurugram), signalling Honda’s entry into the mid-size cruiser segment through its BigWing Topline dealerships. This was the first time the globally popular model was officially sold in India. The motorcycle is powered by a 471cc liquid-cooled parallel-twin engine delivering 45.59bhp at 8,500rpm and 43.3Nm at 6,000rpm, paired with a six-speed gearbox. True to its cruiser character, the Rebel 500 focuses on accessible torque and a smooth, predictable powerband, complemented by its low 690mm seat height that makes it approachable for a wide spectrum of riders.

Built on a tubular steel frame, the Rebel 500 features telescopic front forks and Showa dual rear shock absorbers. Braking duties are handled by a 296mm front disc and 240mm rear disc, supported by dual-channel ABS. The motorcycle rides on Dunlop tyres and comes equipped with a full LED lighting system, including a round LED headlamp and an inverted LCD display. It was offered in India only in Matt Gunpowder Black Metallic and in a single standard variant.

title: Royal Enfield plans major rollout: Bullet 650, Himalayan 750, Flying Flea EVs
content:
Royal Enfield is preparing for one of its most aggressive product expansions yet, with four all-new motorcycles set to arrive over the next two years. The line-up spans everything from a modernised Bullet flagship to a next-generation adventure bike and the brand’s first-ever electric motorcycles under its new sub-brand, Flying Flea. Here’s a detailed look at what to expect.

advertisement

Bullet 650: The most powerful Bullet ever

Royal Enfield has unveiled the Bullet 650 at EICMA 2025, positioning it as the most potent and refined version in the model’s 93-year history. While the design stays firmly rooted in tradition upright stance, signature teardrop tank with the classic winged badge, casquette headlamp with tiger-eye pilot lamps, hand-painted pinstripes, the motorcycle receives a substantial technical upgrade.

Powering the Bullet 650 is RE’s 647.95cc parallel-twin engine, producing 47bhp at 7,250rpm and 52.3Nm at 5,650rpm, paired with a 6-speed gearbox. The new model preserves the Bullet’s old-school metal construction and silhouette but adds a modern character. The Bullet 650 will be introduced in India soon, taking its place as the flagship Bullet.

Himalayan 750: A new chapter for RE’s adventure range

Royal Enfield has showcased the Himalayan 750 prototype at EICMA 2025, signalling a major step into the premium middleweight ADV segment. Displayed as a "Testing in Progress" unit, the motorcycle features a new 750cc oil-cooled parallel-twin engine, an evolution of the 650 twin and is expected to deliver around 50hp and 60Nm, with a 6-speed gearbox and slip-assist clutch.

The Himalayan 750 gets a completely reworked chassis with a fresh headstock design, a new subframe, and a trellis-style main frame. Suspension components include adjustable USD forks and a linked monoshock. Other equipment upgrades include twin front discs, a 19-inch wire-spoke (tubeless-ready) front wheel, cruise control, and a round digital cluster similar to the Himalayan 450’s TFT display.

The final production version is expected sometime in 2026 or early 2027.

Flying Flea C6: Royal Enfield’s first electric motorcycle

Royal Enfield’s electric journey begins with the Flying Flea C6, arriving in the fourth quarter of FY 2025–26. Shown originally at EICMA 2024, the C6 launches under the brand-new Flying Flea umbrella, created to operate outside Royal Enfield’s legacy positioning.

advertisement

The C6 differentiates itself with a minimalist, lightweight ethos. A forged aluminium Girder-style front fork, articulating mudguard, forged aluminium frame, and magnesium battery casing give it a distinctly retro-futuristic presence. The round headlamp and single-pod instrument cluster further nod to pre-1930s motorcycle design.

Beneath the retro styling is a sophisticated electric platform. The VCU supports over 2,00,000 ride mode combinations, offers continuous monitoring, and receives OTA updates. Lean-sensitive ABS, a domestic 3-pin charging plug and single- or dual-seat options are confirmed.

The C6 will launch first, followed by the scrambler-styled S6.

Flying Flea S6: An electric scrambler

The second model from the Flying Flea brand, the S6, made its EICMA 2025 debut. Designed as a dual-purpose city+ scrambler, the S6 aims to merge everyday commuting with mild off-road flexibility.

The S6 features a taller stance, wide handlebars, long-travel suspension, 19-inch front and 18-inch rear wheels, a USD fork, and chain final drive. The finned magnesium battery enclosure helps with cooling and keeps weight in check. A long, enduro-style seat signals extended-ride comfort rather than short-hop urban use.

advertisement

The platform runs an in-house OS powered by a Qualcomm Snapdragon QWM2290 processor with 4G, Wi-Fi, Bluetooth and support for wearable-device connectivity. OTA updates, remote diagnostics, location tracking and charging status monitoring are built in.

The S6 is scheduled for launch toward the end of 2026, post localisation and final testing.

title: Expert explains why your 12% equity returns aren't real
content:
Many investors feel confident that their equity portfolios earn around 12% every year. But certified financial planner and personal finance expert Ritesh Sabharwal says the real picture is very different once inflation and taxes are considered.

In a recent LinkedIn post, he wrote, “Your 12% equity returns are actually 6.7%, and I haven’t even included taxes yet. This is a reality check that most investors miss.”

advertisement

INFLATION SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCES REAL GAINS

Sabharwal explained that the common mistake investors make is ignoring the effect of inflation on long-term returns. He pointed out that the correct way to measure gains is through the real return formula. “Real return = (1 + return) / (1 + inflation) – 1,” he said.

Using this formula, a 12% equity return falls to 6.7% when inflation of 5% is added to the calculation. Once long-term capital gains tax of 12.5% is applied, the return reduces even further to 5.8%, making the final earnings much smaller than expected.

FIXED-INCOME OPTIONS FARE EVEN WORSE

Sabharwal warned that people who keep large sums in savings accounts, fixed deposits or debt funds may be losing money in real terms.

According to him, “Your real returns post inflation and post-tax are likely negative,” which means the value of money quietly decreases over time. He added that many investors do not realise how much of their earnings are lost before they even notice the impact.

A LARGE GAP BETWEEN PAPER RETURNS AND REAL WEALTH

To show the difference clearly, Sabharwal used the example of a Rs 1 crore portfolio. A 12% return gives Rs 12 lakh on paper. But after adjusting for inflation and tax, the real earnings shrink to Rs 5.8 lakh.

“You lose Rs 6.2 lakh to inflation and tax alone,” he explained, highlighting how much of the return is wiped out each year.

EQUITY EXPOSURE IS ESSENTIAL FOR WEALTH CREATION

Sabharwal stressed that meaningful equity exposure is necessary to build wealth over the long term. He said that investors must think beyond short-term movements and adopt a steady approach.

“This is exactly why equity exposure is non-negotiable for long-term wealth creation,” he wrote. According to him, a mix of strategic allocation, a long-term mindset and occasional portfolio rebalancing can help protect savings from being eaten away by inflation.

Meanwhile, for those unsure of how to enter the equity market, Sabharwal said, “If you want exposure and don’t know where to start, just start with a simple index fund, period.” Simply put, start early, stay invested and focus on real returns, not just headline numbers.

title: Fresh ED summons to Anil Ambani in fraud case after he skips second date
content:
The Enforcement Directorate has tightened its stance in its probe involving industrialist Anil Ambani. The ED has issued a fresh summons to Anil Ambani under FEMA, asking him to appear next Monday after rejecting his request for a virtual statement.

SFIO TAKES OVER NEW INVESTIGATION

Earlier, the government had ordered a fresh investigation into several companies linked to the Anil Ambani–led Reliance Anil Dhirubhai Ambani Group (ADAG). This time, the probe has been handed to the Serious Fraud Investigation Office (SFIO), the specialised wing of the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA).

advertisement

The SFIO has stepped in after earlier enquiries by the ED, the CBI and market regulator Sebi. The new focus is on whether there were any gaps in corporate governance and whether funds were diverted across group companies.

WHY THE NEW PROBE WAS ORDERED

According to people familiar with the matter, the MCA received several alerts from auditors and financial institutions. These alerts pointed to possible irregularities in the financial statements of some ADAG firms.

Forensic audits ordered by banks, especially after the loan defaults at Reliance Capital and Reliance Communications, also raised red flags.

COMPANIES UNDER THE SCANNER

At least four entities are currently being closely examined—Reliance Infrastructure, Reliance Communications, Reliance Commercial Finance Ltd (RCFL) and CLE Pvt Ltd. More group companies may be added if links to fund movements are uncovered.

The intensified scrutiny comes after the ED recently attached assets worth nearly Rs 7,500 crore, including land in Navi Mumbai, a property in Bandra’s Pali Hill, and the Reliance Centre in New Delhi.
