title: History sheeter in Chennai attempts to throw footwear at judge during court hearing
content:
A history-sheeter in Tamil Nadu arrested for throwing a petrol bomb at Raj Bhavan caused a commotion inside a Chennai court on Thursday after he allegedly attempted to throw his footwear at the judge.

Karuka Vinoth, who is also accused in a separate case of hurling a petrol bomb at a Tamil Nadu State Marketing Corporation (Tasmac) outlet in T Nagar, was produced before the 6th Additional Court. The hearing was presided over by Judge Pandiaraj.

advertisement

According to police, Vinoth suddenly began shouting that he had been given the maximum punishment in the Raj Bhavan case.

In the middle of the outburst, he removed one of his slippers and attempted to throw it at the judge. Policemen present in the courtroom immediately intervened and restrained him before the footwear could be hurled.

He was then taken out of the courtroom by security personnel. The proceedings continued under tightened security.

In October this year, the Supreme Court witnessed a dramatic scene when a lawyer attempted to throw a shoe at Chief Justice of India BR Gavai during a hearing. While the accused was being escorted out of the courtroom, he screamed, “India will not tolerate the insult of Sanatan Dharma.”

The accused was immediately detained, while Chief Justice Gavai remained composed and continued the proceedings without interruption.

"Don't get distracted by all this. These things do not affect me. Continue with the hearing," he added.

title: Complaints to compliments: Kiran Shaw now praises DK Shivakumar for Bengaluru roads
content:
Industrialist Kiran MazumdarShaw, chairperson of Biocon Limited, has publicly acknowledged the improvements in Bengaluru’s footpaths and roads, singling out the leadership of DK Shivakumar, who also holds the development portfolio in the Karnataka government, for playing a “key” role in rescuing the city from garbage, debris and potholes.

Her praise marks a full-circle moment, coming just weeks after she launched a public critique of the city’s infrastructure, invited Shivakumar to her nephew’s wedding, and held a sit-down meeting with him at his residence.

advertisement

FIRST, THE CRITIQUE

On October 13, Mazumdar-Shaw, in a post on X, drew attention to the dilapidated state of Bengaluru’s roads and piling garbage. She quoted an overseas business visitor to the Biocon campus as saying: “Why are the roads so bad and why is there so much garbage around? Doesn’t the Govt want to support investment?” She tagged state leaders (including DK Shivakumar and the Chief Minister) and urged better civic-management, accountability for slow or shoddy work.

Her post triggered a strong government response: ministers said work was underway and that her criticism “hurts the state”.

The Deputy Chief Minister responded by saying Bengaluru deserves “collective effort, not constant criticism” and defended the government’s work, saying large funds had been sanctioned for road repair and pothole filling.

She later faced trolling about her “Kannadiga” roots after the civic-issue call-out, prompting her to write: “I was born in this city and have spent seven decades loving my city I am a proud Kannadiga.”

THEN, THE WEDDING INVITE

On October 21, Mazumdar-Shaw visited Shivakumar’s residence to extend a wedding invitation, and at the same time, civic issues were reportedly raised.

The meeting was described by Shivakumar on X as an “engaging discussion on Bengaluru’s growth, innovation, and the path ahead for Karnataka’s growth story.”

After DK Shivakumar attended her nephew’s wedding reception in Bengaluru, Mazumdar-Shaw posted on X: “Thank you @DKShivakumar for graving the reception,” meaning to use “gracing” instead, which triggered a sea of jokes.

And now, she is backing the government’s clean-up push, saying the work on the ground is visible and giving credit to both DKS and civic officials.

title: Video: Leopard leaps onto safari bus, claws woman's hand in Bengaluru
content:
A 50-year-old woman from Chennai sustained injuries to her hand on Thursday after a leopard at Bannerghatta National Park leapt onto a safari bus and clawed her through the mesh window. She was immediately rushed to a hospital in Jigani and is stable.

Officials said the incident took place around 1 pm during a leopard safari trip. The woman, identified as Vahitha Banu (56), received first aid on the spot before being shifted to a private hospital for further treatment.

advertisement

A video of the episode, widely circulated on social media, shows the leopard climbing onto the safari bus and pawing through the window in an attempt to attack her.

According to officials, the safari buses are fitted with metal wire mesh on their windows and openings to prevent direct contact between animals and visitors. However, the leopard managed to reach its paw through a small gap in the mesh and scratch the woman.

“The woman received scratch injuries to her hand and was given first aid. She was shifted to a private hospital for treatment and is stated to be doing fine,” an official said.

The park authorities said safari drivers had earlier been warned about a previous leopard attack and instructed to follow precautionary measures during the leopard safari.

In an official statement, the authorities announced that the non-AC bus safari has been halted indefinitely pending a complete safety assessment of the vehicles. “The buses will be assessed for complete safety during the downtime. Inconvenience caused to visitors is regretted,” the statement added.

title: I got irritated: Upset over honking, Bengaluru techie rams 3 on scooter
content:
In a road rage case on Bengaluru road, a techie rammed his car into a scooter as he got irritated due to continuous honking. The incident was caught on a CCTV camera and was techie was later arrested.

Bengaluru Police arrested the software engineer for allegedly attempting to murder a motorist after a quarrel at a traffic signal in north Bengaluru. The incident took place on October 26 and was initially registered as a hit-and-run accident.

advertisement

According to police, the altercation began when the victim honked at the accused, Sukruth Keshav, for blocking a free left near Ramaiah College. Angered, Sukruth allegedly chased the vehicle and intentionally rammed his Tata Curve into it.

Though the case was first filed as an accident by the traffic police, inconsistencies in statements prompted further inquiry.

Deputy Commissioner of Police (Central), Akshay, said that CCTV footage later confirmed the collision was deliberate.

“Once the footage was obtained, it became clear that the collision was not accidental but deliberate. The case was transferred from the Traffic Police Station to the Sadashivanagar Law and Order Police Station. Based on the complaint and video evidence, police confirmed it was a case of attempt to murder,” he said.

Police traced the accused using vehicle details and arrested him. During questioning, Sukruth claimed he was only trying to “scare” the other motorist, insisting he did not intend to cause harm. However, investigators concluded it was a clear instance of violent and negligent behaviour on the road.

During questioning, the accused said, "Near Ramaiah College, there was no free left, but he was honking at me. I got irritated, allowed him to overtake, and tried to scare him — but ended up hitting the other vehicle."

He claimed it wasn’t intentional, but investigators found it to be a clear case of violent and negligent behaviour on the road, not a mere accident.

The police have seized the vehicle and further investigation is underway.

title: How strong has the 'mahila' factor been in the Bihar elections?
content:
Women have indeed made history by turning out in large numbers to vote in the 2025 Bihar Assembly polls. For the first time, nearly 4.5 lakh more women voted than men, combined across both phases. That’s a turnout gap of nearly nine percentage points.

According to reports, women’s voter turnout reached nearly 90 per cent in Kishanganj; 84 per cent in Katihar, Supaul, and Purnea; and around 78 per cent in Araria and the two Champaran districts. In fact, in as many as 17 districts, the turnout gap was 10 percentage points or more. In all but one district, women’s turnout exceeded that of men — in most cases, by a substantial margin.

advertisement

In the 2020 Assembly elections, there were as many as 167 constituencies where women’s turnout exceeded that of men. The National Democratic Alliance won a majority of these seats — 100 in total — with a strike rate of nearly 60 per cent. The Rashtriya Janata Dal-led Mahagathbandhan, on the other hand, secured only 61 such seats, a strike rate of just 36.5 per cent. These numbers indicate that the NDA received the lion’s share of women’s votes.

But we examined another data point to test this trend further. Data shows that 42 of the 167 constituencies are strongholds, seats won by the same party in the last three elections. Of the 100 seats the NDA won where women thronged the polling booths, as many as 34 were its strongholds. In other words, the NDA managed to retain a large share of seats in areas where it already enjoyed an edge. The alliance won 66 such seats where it did not have an edge.

On the other hand, the Mahagathbandhan had just a handful of strongholds in constituencies recording higher women turnout. Of the 61 seats won by the alliance in higher women turnout seats, there were just eight where it enjoyed an advantage. In other words, the Mahagathbandhan won 53 of the 61 (87 per cent) seats in places where it did not have a distinct electoral advantage.

These numbers show that while women have emerged as a powerful force in determining the fate of political parties in Bihar, a range of factors shape their voting preferences. Among these are the social groups they belong to, the regions they come from, and their socio-economic status. It is therefore premature to assume that women have become a distinct social group, insulated from the multiple identities with which they are associated.

title: How women held the baton of record poll participation in Bihar elections 2025
content:
Polling in the Bihar Assembly elections concluded with an unprecedented voter turnout of more than 67 per cent. Turnout in 10 out of the 38 districts — Katihar, Kishanganj, Purnia, Supaul, Muzaffarpur, Samastipur, East Champaran, West Champaran, Banka, and Araria — was above 70 per cent, as of 2 pm November 12.

The bumper rise in the turnout was led by an over nine per cent increase in voter participation in 25 of the 38 districts and over 10 per cent in 18 districts, including Munger, Lakhisarai, and Sheohar.

advertisement

The spurt was largely led by women voters. Against a turnout of 62.8 per cent among males, it remained 71.6 per cent among the female voters, according to the Election Commission of India.

While women’s voter turnout has been consistently higher than men’s since the 2010 Assembly elections in Bihar, in absolute numbers, they surpassed men for the first time this year — 2.47 crore men cast their votes compared to 2.52 crore women.

The election concluded in two phases, and the female participation was higher in both. In Phase 1, the female turnout was 69.04 per cent against 61.56 per cent male, and in Phase 2, the female turnout was 74.03 per cent against 64.1 per cent male.

The result will be declared on November 14 and will determine if the sitting Chief Minister, Nitish Kumar, gets to form the government once again. It was also the first time that 16 delegates from six countries — South Africa, Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines, Belgium, and Colombia — visited and witnessed the poll proceedings as part of the International Election Visitors’ Programme.

title: Bihar elections 2025: Can Phase 2 match Phase 1's historic surge?
content:
The final numbers from Phase 1 on November 6 rewrote Bihar's electoral history: a 64.7 per cent turnout, the highest ever recorded in the state’s Assembly elections. The spotlight is now on the 122 constituencies that will vote in Phase 2 on Tuesday.

Will it match Phase 1's surge?

The answer lies not in speculation, but in a decade of data that reveals Phase 2's distinct trajectory, one that, historically, has actually outpaced Phase 1.

advertisement

When voters in Katihar's Korha constituency cast their ballots on November 11, they'll likely continue an extraordinary tradition. For three consecutive elections, this Seemanchal seat has recorded turnout exceeding 67 per cent, making it Bihar's most engaged electorate in Phase 2.

Just 150 kilometres southwest in Bhagalpur, the contrast is jarring. Despite being a major urban centre, this seat saw the turnout drop to 48.43 per cent in 2020, the lowest among all 122 Phase 2 constituencies.

These two seats tell the tale of Seemanchal's democratic vibrancy, transformative growth in interior districts, and urban apathy that mirrors — and exceeds — what we saw in Phase 1.

Phase 2 outpaces Phase 1

The numbers are unequivocal. Turnout in Phase 2 constituencies has grown faster than in Phase 1. Between 2010 and 2020, average voter turnout in Phase 2 seats increased from 53.8 to 58.8 per cent, a five-point gain. That's 1.1 points more than Phase 1's 3.95-point increase.

What’s more impressive is that 108 out of the 122 seats (89 per cent) recorded higher turnout in 2020 than in 2010, a better consistency rate than Phase 1's 93 per cent, but with larger absolute gains. The pattern is clear: while Phase 1 was already relatively mobilised, Phase 2 had more room to grow. And it did.

The Seemanchal phenomenon

Seemanchal, comprising Katihar, Kishanganj, Purnia, Araria, and Supaul, dominates Phase 2's high-turnout rankings with an intensity that Phase 1's Muzaffarpur can only envy. Katihar’s district average is 64.3 per cent across three elections, the highest for any Phase 2 region, surpassing even Muzaffarpur's 59.8 per cent in Phase 1. Four of the five seats with the highest turnout in 2020 are from Seemanchal:

Korha (SC), Katihar: 67.4 per cent

67.4 per cent Barari, Katihar: 67.2 per cent

67.2 per cent Kasba, Purnea: 66.4 per cent

66.4 per cent Thakurganj, Kishanganj: 66.1 per cent

66.1 per cent Chakai, Jamui: 66.1 per cent (honourable outlier)

What explains Seemanchal's democratic fervour? Demographics matter. These are Muslim-majority or significant-minority constituencies where electoral mobilisation runs deep. Caste arithmetic is complex. And crucially, these are not safe seats; parties fight hard here, and voters respond.

Yet here's the paradox: Seemanchal's growth is slowing. Katihar grew by only 1.58 points (2010–2020), and Purnea by 1.32 points. When you're already at more than 60 per cent, there's little room to climb.

The interior awakening

advertisement

The real story is in Bihar's interior. Districts that were electoral backwaters in 2010 have surged since. Jamui leads Phase 2's transformation, from 49.5 per cent in 2010 to 60.6 per cent in 2020, an 11.06-point increase that’s also the highest in Phase 2, comparable to Phase 1's Darbhanga. Every single Jamui constituency in Phase 2 shows dramatic growth:

Chakai: 47.3 per cent to 66.1 per cent (+18.8 points), the single largest gain in either phase

47.3 per cent to 66.1 per cent (+18.8 points), the single largest gain in either phase Jamui: 50.4 per cent to 59.7 per cent (+9.3 points)

50.4 per cent to 59.7 per cent (+9.3 points) Sikandra: 51.2 per cent to 58.8 per cent (+7.6 points)

51.2 per cent to 58.8 per cent (+7.6 points) Banka follows close behind: +10.7 points, with Katoria (ST) jumping 15.5 points.

These aren't Seemanchal's already-mobilised electorates. These are constituencies where democracy was anaemic a decade ago. Something fundamental changed. Better roads? Stronger party organisation? Caste assertion? The data can't tell us, but the transformation is undeniable.

Urban crisis deepens

If Seemanchal represents Phase 2's strength and Jamui its transformation, Bhagalpur represents its crisis. The city recorded a 48.4 per cent turnout in 2020, lower than any Phase 1 urban seat except Patna's trio. This isn't just urban apathy. It's urban decline. Bhagalpur's turnout barely budged from 2010 (48.1 per cent) to 2020 (48.4 per cent), a miserly 0.3-point gain, while rural seats surged by more than 10 points.

advertisement

Nawada district shares this malaise. It's the only Phase 2 district with an average turnout below 50 per cent (49.2 per cent). Three of its five seats are among the bottom ten:

Warsaliganj: 48.8 per cent

48.8 per cent Rajauli (SC): 50.4 per cent

50.4 per cent Hisua: 50.5 per cent

Compare this to Katihar's 64.26 per cent average, and the gap, 15 percentage points, exceeds Phase 1's urban-rural divide.

The competitiveness mirage (again)

Phase 2 confirms what Phase 1 suggested: close contests don't reliably drive turnout. In 2020, the correlation between victory margin and turnout was near-zero (+0.054). Look at Ramgarh in Kaimur, the closest race in Phase 2, decided by 189 votes. Its turnout? 64.13 per cent, good but not exceptional. Meanwhile, Korha and Barari in Katihar, with comfortable 10,000+ vote margins, topped at 67 per cent.

Safe seats in Phase 2 average 59.01 per cent turnout. Highly competitive seats — 59.08 per cent. The difference is negligible. Turnout isn't about suspense. It's about mobilisation infrastructure, community engagement, and whether people believe their vote matters, regardless of who wins.

advertisement

The decline dozen

While 89 per cent of Phase 2 seats grew, 14 constituencies bucked the trend — all declining since 2010. And all 14 are in Seemanchal or its periphery:

Araria district: Five seats declined (Raniganj, Narpatganj, Sikti, Forbesganj, Jokihat)

Five seats declined (Raniganj, Narpatganj, Sikti, Forbesganj, Jokihat) Katihar: Balrampur dropped by 1.96 points

Balrampur dropped by 1.96 points Purnea: City seat declined by 1.65 points

This isn't random. These constituencies started with more than 60 per cent turnouts in 2010, among Bihar's highest. Regression to the mean suggests some decline was inevitable. But it's also possible that as other regions caught up, Seemanchal's mobilisation edge eroded. Or perhaps, having voted in huge numbers for a decade with limited local development returns, some disillusionment set in.

What this means for Nov 11

The story is richer, the contrasts sharper. A decade of data suggests Tuesday will see 59 per cent turnout, higher than Phase 1's 56–57 per cent expectation, continuing Phase 2's trajectory of exceeding its counterpart. Based on a decade of data, here's what to expect when Phase 2 votes on Tuesday:

advertisement If the 2015–2020 trend continues (+0.52 points), expect a turnout of 58–60 per cent

Korha, Barari, Kasba, and Thakurganj will likely cross 65 per cent; Katihar's average will remain 63–65 per cent

Jamui, Banka, and Madhubani should add another 1–2 points; the catching-up isn't over

Don't expect urban Bhagalpur to suddenly cross 50 per cent

Nawada's seats will struggle to reach 52 per cent

Multiple Phase 2 seats have high-profile battles, but mobilisation matters more than competitiveness; expect a normal turnout in most

With a 58.77 per cent base, Phase 2 should record a 1–2 points higher turnout overall

The bigger questions

Why did Phase 2 grow faster than Phase 1?

Lower starting point: At 53.8 per cent in 2010, Phase 2 had more room to grow than Phase 1's 52.1 per cent, and it caught up

Seemanchal's baseline: Starting with Katihar at 62 per cent in 2010 gave Phase 2 a high floor. Interior growth combined with Seemanchal maintenance equals strong overall gains

Development timing: Phase 2 districts may have received infrastructure/welfare benefits that boosted faith in democracy precisely when Phase 1 was plateauing

Caste mobilisation: Interior districts like Jamui saw aggressive Dalit and EBC mobilisation in the 2010s, groups that had low turnout before

But the data also raises uncomfortable questions:

Why is urban Bhagalpur stuck at 48 per cent?

It's not Patna's wealth-driven apathy. It's something else.

Why is Nawada still below 50 per cent?

It's not remoteness. Madhubani and Sitamarhi grew. What's different?

On November 14, when votes are counted, don't be surprised if Phase 2's higher turnout translates to different electoral arithmetic than Phase 1. When more people vote, outcomes become less predictable. And in a democracy, that's exactly how it should be.

Methodology: This analysis uses official Election Commission of India data for the Bihar Assembly elections 2010, 2015, and 2020. Phase 2 constituencies were identified using the official 2025 polling schedule. Seemanchal is defined as Katihar, Kishanganj, Purnea, Araria, and Supaul districts.

- Ends

title: Every single seat saw more voters. What's driving Bihar's historic turnout?
content:
On a warm Thursday morning in November, something remarkable happened across Bihar's countryside and cities. From the teeming lanes of Patna to the rice fields of Gopalganj, voters queued up in numbers the state hadn't seen in seven decades. By evening, when the last ballot was cast, Bihar had recorded a 64.7 per cent turnout in the first phase of its Assembly elections, the highest ever in its history.

advertisement

But the truly striking pattern emerged only when comparing this election to the 2020 polls. Every single one of the 121 constituencies that voted on November 6 saw more people turn up than five years ago. Not one registered a decline.

In Bhorey, a constituency reserved for Scheduled Castes in western Bihar's Gopalganj district, turnout jumped by more than 16 percentage points. In the state capital's affluent Kumhrar neighbourhood, it rose by just under five points. But it rose everywhere.

THE DALIT SURGE

A closer look at the data reveals one clear pattern: constituencies reserved for Scheduled Castes saw the sharpest jumps. Seven of the 10 constituencies with the highest turnout increases were Scheduled Caste-reserved seats. Bhorey led with a 16.1-point jump, followed by Kalyanpur in Samastipur (up by 15.7 points) and Sonbarsha in Saharsa (up by 14.6 points). In Bhorey, the turnout climbed from 54 per cent in 2020 to over 70 per cent this year.

Dalits make up about 19.5 per cent of Bihar's over 13 crore population, and their mobilisation could prove decisive in what's expected to be a close contest between the ruling National Democratic Alliance and the Opposition, the Mahagathbandhan. The ruling Janata Dal (United), in alliance with the Bharatiya Janata Party, seeks to retain power against a resurgent Opposition led by the Rashtriya Janata Dal and the Indian National Congress. Both sides have made direct appeals to Dalit voters, promising everything from land rights to better education access.

THE CITY PROBLEM

But if rural and Dalit-dominated constituencies saw a surge, Bihar's cities remained stuck in low gear. In Patna, the state capital, Kumhrar, Bankipur and Digha recorded turnouts below 42 per cent, even with modest increases from 2020. Kumhrar, which includes some of Patna's most affluent neighbourhoods, saw just 39.6 per cent turnout.

The contrast is stark. While Patna's urban constituencies languished below 45 per cent turnout, rural seats like Minapur in Muzaffarpur touched 77.6 per cent, the highest in the state. In village after village across the Gangetic plain, voting was treated as a social obligation and a community event, with entire families walking to polling booths together.

This urban-rural split could matter. Patna and other cities tend to vote differently from the countryside, often favouring parties that campaign for development and governance. But with such low turnout, their electoral voice remains muted.

advertisement

SAMASTIPUR'S MOMENT

Geography tells another story. When the data is mapped, a clear belt of high turnout emerges across central Bihar, running through Samastipur, Begusarai and into Munger.

Samastipur district, in particular, stands out. Of its eight constituencies that voted in the first phase, seven recorded double-digit percentage increases. Kalyanpur jumped 15.7 points, Mohiuddinnagar 14.4 points, and Warisnagar 13 points. Even the district's lowest increase, Ujiarpur, was up by a healthy 11.9 points.

In contrast, Darbhanga district showed more modest gains. The eponymous constituency saw turnout rise by just 4.1 points. Political observers suggest this might reflect confidence among voters that their preferred alliance will win anyway, reducing the urgency to vote.

This regional variation matters in a state where elections are often decided by narrow margins. In 2020, the NDA won by just 125 seats to 110, a margin thin enough that swings in a few districts could change the outcome.

SEVEN DECADES OF VOTING

To understand what Thursday's numbers mean, you need to look back. Way back.

Bihar's first election in 1951 saw 42.6 per cent turnout — modest by today's standards but considered healthy for a newly independent nation where literacy was low and democracy was a novel concept. Turnout gradually climbed over the decades, peaking at 62 per cent in 1990 during the height of the Mandal agitation, when caste politics brought millions of backward-caste voters into the electoral mainstream.

advertisement

But after 2000, turnout plateaued. It hovered in the high 50s through the 2000s and 2010s, with the 2020 election recording 57.3 per cent in its first phase. This year's 64.7 per cent doesn't just break the 1990 record. It represents a fundamental shift in voter behaviour, coming at a time when turnout has been stagnant or declining in many other Indian states.

WHAT'S DRIVING THE SURGE?

First, the Election Commission's infrastructure improvements. Over 67,000 polling stations were set up for this phase, many in remote areas. Waiting times have reduced. Women get separate queues. Disabled voters get priority access.

Second, the campaign went hyper-local. Both major alliances used WhatsApp, Facebook, and Instagram to reach voters, sending messages in Bhojpuri, Maithili, and Magahi. This appears to have energised younger, first-time voters.

Third, the contest itself is close. Pre-poll surveys showed a tight race, making voters feel their ballots mattered. When elections seem predetermined, turnout drops. When every seat counts, people show up.

advertisement

And finally, there's something harder to quantify: a growing sense among Biharis, especially younger voters, that the state's future depends on them showing up.

WHAT IT MEANS

High turnout doesn't tell you who will win. But it does tell you something about the nature of the contest. Historically, turnout surges in Bihar have tended to favour challengers over incumbents. The 1990 spike, for instance, brought Lalu Prasad Yadav to power, ending decades of Congress dominance. The 2005 decline helped Nitish Kumar dislodge Yadav's Rashtriya Janata Dal.

Whether the pattern holds this time is unclear. The current government is itself a coalition that includes both Nitish Kumar's JD(U) and the BJP, making the challenger-incumbent binary less clear-cut.

But the data does suggest some groups are more energised than others. The Dalit surge, the urban apathy, and the regional variations will likely translate into differential voting patterns when results are declared on November 14.

For now, though, one thing is certain: Biharis turned up. In numbers that surprised even seasoned election-watchers.

On Friday morning, as Phase 1 wrapped up and attention turned to the 122 constituencies that will vote in Phase 2 on November 11, the question everyone was asking was simple: Will it see a similar surge?

- Ends

Published By: Pathikrit Sanyal Published On: Nov 7, 2025

title: Bihar polls 2025: What does a record high turnout signal?
content:
Bihar set a new record in the first phase of the 2025 Assembly elections, covering 121 constituencies across 18 districts. Voter turnout stood at around 65 per cent, the highest ever recorded in the state, surpassing the previous high of 62.5 per cent in 2000. Compared to the 2020 Assembly polls in the same seats, turnout surged by an impressive 8.6 percentage points.

advertisement

Does this rise signal a change of guard or a vote for continuity? To find out, we examined turnout patterns across five major Hindi-speaking states in Assembly elections: Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, and Haryana.

Let’s begin with Bihar. Historically, the state witnessed modest voter participation, typically in the 42–44 per cent range in the first three elections. The first major spike came in 1967, when turnout crossed 51 per cent. That election ushered in Bihar’s first non-Congress government. Two more surges followed in 1980 and 1990, and both resulted in regime changes.

However, this pattern broke in 2000, when turnout touched a record 62.5 per cent, yet the incumbent retained power. The next regime change occurred five years later, despite a steep 17-point drop in voter participation.

Turnout-verdict correlation

Based on recent trends, one can safely say that the correlation between voter turnout and election outcomes in Bihar is quite weak.

In neighbouring Uttar Pradesh, the pattern is broadly similar. Periods of sharp increases in turnout have often coincided with the emergence of a new ruling party or coalition. Yet, much like Bihar, a significant drop in turnout in 2007 also accompanied a change of guard. Interestingly, a record-high turnout in 2022 resulted in continuity, with the incumbent retaining power.

Has the story been any different in Madhya Pradesh? In earlier decades, a surge in voter turnout typically signalled political change. However, that correlation has largely weakened in recent years. Since 2003, voter participation in every Assembly election has shown a steady rise. Except for 2018, most of these elections resulted in the continuation of the ruling party. The state recorded its highest-ever turnout of 77 per cent in the 2023 polls, which delivered a resounding victory for the incumbent.

Rajasthan has a long history of alternating governments every five years. The state recorded a record-high turnout of 75 per cent in 2013, and participation has remained near that level ever since.

Haryana, traditionally known for its high voter turnout, registered its highest-ever participation rate of 76 per cent in 2014. That was also a year that saw a regime change. Turnout declined in subsequent elections, and the incumbent has remained in power since.

The numbers, therefore, do not present a clear pattern. Voter participation has risen across almost all major states, and Bihar has been no exception. Part of this increase can be attributed to the Election Commission’s voter awareness campaigns. While incumbents have often weathered these surges in recent years, in some cases, higher turnout has preceded a change of government.

- Ends

title: The problem with your cup(s) of matcha
content:
Matcha, often dubbed the “Gen Z green juice,” traces its origins to Japan. While it has long been a staple there, the drink has turned into a global fad, so much so that people are now brewing business ideas around it.

This green tea powder, celebrated for its nutritional and wellness benefits, has found its way into smoothies, coffees, cakes, cookies, and even cocktails. But now, the internet has a new claim: it may cause hair fall, especially among women.

Such claims first surfaced around midyear but soon faded away. However, the internet is buzzing about them again. So, we decided to set the record straight - not just about the hair fall concerns, but also other potential side effects and how to get your matcha right.

PS: Don’t put that cup of matcha down just yet. Read on to find out what experts say about whether it’s truly everyone’s cup of tea.

Spilling the tea about matcha

At its core, matcha is just powdered, shade-grown green tea leaves. It began as part of Japan’s traditional tea ceremony but is now a global sensation. It is loaded with antioxidants called catechins, which help reduce inflammation. It also contains L-theanine, an amino acid that slows caffeine absorption, making it a comparatively better beverage option than regular coffee.

Broadly, based on quality, matcha is classified into three categories: ceremonial grade, premium grade, and culinary grade.

The highest is ceremonial grade, made from the youngest, most tender leaves, and ideal for traditional tea ceremonies. Premium and daily grades are slightly more robust and popular for making lattes or for everyday drinking. Meanwhile, culinary grade matcha, often divided into further subcategories, is more intense and slightly bitter, making it suitable for cooking, baking, or smoothies without the premium price tag.

But just like a coin, it turns out even the matcha story has two sides. Despite being known as a healthy beverage, its potential side effects are what everyone is talking about now.

Viral claim: Matcha causes hair fall.

Is this viral claim true, though? Not quite. At least, that’s not how experts say.

“Matcha itself doesn’t directly cause hair fall. In fact, its antioxidants (especially EGCG) may protect hair follicles and support scalp circulation. However, excessive caffeine intake from multiple cups daily can raise cortisol levels in sensitive individuals, potentially contributing to hormonal hair shedding,” Vidhi Chawla, dietician and founder of FISICO Diet and Aesthetic Clinic, tells India Today.

Now, this is where the confusion brews about iron deficiency and its connection with hair fall.

advertisement

So, can matcha cause iron deficiency? Possibly, but terms and conditions apply.

This is possible if matcha is consumed in excess. Matcha is rich in tannins and catechins, which can inhibit iron absorption from plant foods. In such cases, the body’s ferritin (the protein that stores iron) levels can drop, leading to shedding and thinning of hair.

“Low ferritin (iron stores) is a major cause of hair thinning in Indian women. When combined with stress or poor sleep, this can worsen hair shedding,” says Twincy Ann Sunil, clinical nutrition and dietetics, Apollo Spectra Hospital, Bengaluru.

Digestive issues

Tea is known to have certain gastric effects when consumed in excess. Similarly, the caffeine and L-theanine content in this green tea can stimulate gastric acid production too, according to experts.

On an empty stomach, it may lead to bloating, acidity, or nausea. To avoid discomfort, it’s best to drink matcha after a light meal or snack, not first thing in the morning. Matcha, today, is found in drinks, cookies, lattes, doughnuts and more (Photo: Unsplash)

advertisement

Menstrual cycle

This, once again, is an effect that can occur only when matcha is consumed in excess. Experts agree that excessive caffeine can amplify PMS symptoms, cause cycle irregularities, or worsen anxiety and cramps in caffeine-sensitive women. However, when consumed in moderate amounts (about one cup daily), matcha is unlikely to affect menstrual cycles significantly.

Quality

Matcha lovers, take note! The beverage can become problematic if you compromise on quality. Cheap, low-grade versions may not only taste bitter but can also cause health issues.

Should Indians drink matcha?

Viral trends keep surfacing, some fade away like a whisper in the wind, while others actually leave an impact and stay. Matcha belongs to the latter. But here’s the thing: wellness and food-related fads don’t always translate the same way everywhere. What works for one culture may need a little tweaking in another.

For instance, the matcha tea culture has been a part of Japanese tradition for centuries. And there’s no denying how several concepts from Japan — like Ikigai, Hara Hachi Bu, and Wabi-Sabi - have become global markers of healthy, mindful living. Bamboo whisks help mix the powder better (Photo: Pexels)

advertisement

But when the same green ritual travels to India, the story changes slightly. Our tropical climate already increases body heat and dehydration risk. And matcha, being a warming and stimulating drink, can add to that. That’s why it suits mornings or cooler seasons better than hot afternoons.

Both experts point out that Indian diets are typically carbohydrate-heavy and low in antioxidants, so matcha can still offer a valuable polyphenol and chlorophyll boost. However, those prone to acidity or heat-related issues - like migraines, acne, or PCOS flares - should go easy and limit their intake to just a few times a week.

How to drink your matcha right

Clearly, the world is not giving up on the green drink and even health experts sort of approve of it. Just a little moderation, some body awareness, and you’re good to go.

Here are a few quick notes on how to match up with your matcha:

advertisement Look for ceremonial-grade matcha (lower bitterness, higher antioxidants), mostly.

Whisk gently using a bamboo whisk to avoid oxidation.

Add milk (dairy or oat/almond) if caffeine-sensitive, it helps buffer acidity. You can add a pinch of collagen, cinnamon, or ashwagandha for added adaptogenic benefits.

It is best to drink it around mid-morning or early afternoon. It should be avoided on an empty stomach, late evening and with heavy meals at all costs.

Stay hydrated as matcha can mildly dehydrate.

Don’t toss away your matcha just yet - sip, enjoy, and let it work for you, not against you. Because, as far as experts say, side effects are mostly a 'you problem' (if you over consume) and not actually a matcha problem.

- Ends

title: SBI Asha Scholarship deadline ends tomorrow, apply now to get up to Rs 20 lakh
content:
The State Bank of India, through the SBI Foundation, is preparing to close applications for the Platinum Jubilee Asha Scholarship 2025, with the deadline ending tomorrow.

The programme offers scholarship up to Rs 20 lah for financial support, especially for students from economically modest backgrounds, and aims to help them pursue studies without financial challenges.

One of the bank’s largest educational initiatives, the scheme will support 23,230 students across India. The scholarship covers learners from Class 9 to postgraduate programmes, making it accessible to a wide pool of applicants.

advertisement

Under this scholarship, students may receive an annual award ranging from Rs 15,000 to Rs 20,00,000, depending on their academic level and category.

The support continues throughout the duration of their course, ensuring stability for learners pursuing long-term academic goals. Applications must be submitted online via sbiashascholarship.co.in.

WHO CAN APPLY

The scholarship is open to Indian nationals studying from Class 9 up to the postgraduate level. Eligible candidates include:

Students from Classes 9–12

Undergraduate and postgraduate students

Scholars at IITs and IIMs

Students preparing for medical careers

Aspirants planning to study abroad

SC/ST students seeking master’s or higher studies at top global universities

Applicants must have scored at least 75 percent marks or a 7.0 CGPA in the previous academic year. Income limits apply, up to Rs 3 lakh per year for school students and up to Rs 6 lakh per year for college or postgraduate applicants.

All candidates must provide valid supporting documents during the application process.

HOW TO APPLY

Eligible students must complete the application before November 15, 2025, by following these steps:

Visit: www.sbiashascholarship.co.in

Select ‘Apply Now’ under the Platinum Jubilee Asha Scholarship 2025

Register using a valid email ID and mobile number

Fill out the application form with accurate details

Upload required documents: Mark sheets Income certificate Identity proof Recent photograph

Submit the form and keep a copy of the confirmation

Direct link to apply for SBI Platinum Jubilee Asha Scholarship 2025

SCHOLARSHIP BENEFITS AND DETAILS

The scholarship provides tailored financial support for students studying in NIRF top 300 or NAAC 'A' rated institutions, including leading institutes such as IITs, IIMs, and medical colleges. Support for study abroad aspirants, particularly SC/ST candidates, is also included.

The annual award may go as high as Rs 20,00,000, depending on the course and level. This year, SBI has allocated Rs 90 crore towards the initiative, underscoring its commitment to promoting inclusive education and supporting meritorious students.

With the deadline approaching tomorrow, eligible students are urged to apply without delay to access this valuable opportunity.

content:
The CBSE Class 12 board exams 2026 are expected to begin in mid-February, with the English Core paper scheduled for March 12. As one of the highest-scoring papers, English plays a key role in improving overall aggregate, making it important to prepare smartly and revise consistently.

Practising CBSE sample papers helps students understand the question pattern, section-wise weightage, and marking scheme while improving speed and accuracy. It also builds confidence for comprehension passages, creative writing tasks, and literature-based questions.

title: Can India move from job hunting to job creation?
content:
India stands at an inflection point where its economic rise depends not just on leveraging existing opportunities, but on creating entirely new ones. As global wealth increasingly shifts toward innovation-led industries, the gap between India’s resource-driven success stories and the world’s technology-driven wealth creators has become more visible than ever.

This shift raises a critical question: can India continue to rely on traditional sectors, or must it now accelerate its transition toward invention, research, and deep-tech entrepreneurship? The answer lies in reimagining how the nation builds wealth and what it chooses to value.

advertisement

According to the Forbes Global Billionaires list 2025, the top three richest Indians, Mukesh Ambani, Gautam Adani, and Savitri Jindal,drive their wealth mainly from energy, infrastructure, and steel.

In contrast, global leaders such as Elon Musk, Larry Ellison, and Mark Zuckerberg have built their fortunes on technological innovation and scientific breakthroughs.

In this analysis, Mahindra University’s Rajkumar Phatate and Abhishek Sinha explore why the nation must evolve from spotting opportunities to creating the breakthroughs that shape tomorrow.

This comparison highlights two models of wealth creation: India’s resource and scale-driven approach versus the US’s innovation- and knowledge-driven model. Bridging this gap is essential for India to create the next generation of global leaders.

Entrepreneurs learnt to harness India’s mobile revolution, digital payment infrastructure, and consumer base to create scalable businesses. However, scaling existing opportunities is fundamentally different from generating entirely new industries. The next wave must move beyond leveraging trends toward pioneering technologies that will define global markets.

LEARNING FROM THE US INNOVATION MODEL

Breakthroughs in electricity, computing, and artificial intelligence began in laboratories. Success depends on close cooperation between government, academia, and industry: federal agencies fund research, universities convert discoveries into technology, and venture capital turns ideas into startups.

A culture that embraces experimentation and failure has produced companies like Bell Labs, Apple, Google, and Tesla. American entrepreneurs do more than serve markets; they create them.

US universities and labs incentivise commercialisation of research, allowing ideas to move efficiently from concept to product. Venture capital and risk-taking frameworks support entrepreneurs through uncertainty.

FROM FINDING TO CREATING OPPORTUNITIES

India’s entrepreneurs have always been skilled at spotting opportunities in telecom, retail, real estate, and consumer services.

Opportunity creation, however, requires a different mindset: investment in intellectual property, patience in research, and tolerance for failure. It demands moving from exploiting what exists to imagining what could be.

A few Indian ventures have begun this journey. Biotech firms such as Serum Institute and Bharat Biotech show that world-class science can emerge from India. Electric mobility pioneers are developing home-grown EV ecosystems. A new wave of deep-tech startups in AI, robotics, and quantum computing is emerging from leading institutes and private universities.

R AND D IMPERATIVE

India’s R&D expenditure stands at roughly 0.7 percent of GDP, far below South Korea, the US, or China. Most of this spending comes from the government; industry accounts for less than one-third. Universities produce bright graduates but limited intellectual property, while startups innovate in business models but rarely in core science.

advertisement

Building a robust research ecosystem requires stronger university–industry links, talent mobility, and a financial environment that rewards long-term risk. Tax incentives, challenge funds, and grants can encourage firms to invest in R&D. Academic institutions should have autonomy to partner with private firms and convert patents into products.

Every rupee invested in R and D seeds the industries of tomorrow, in fields like clean energy, biotechnology, AI, and quantum computing. A sustained commitment to research will ensure India moves from an economy driven by replication to one led by invention.

-----

The true measure of a nation’s progress is not how effectively it can mine its soil, but how deeply it can mine its mind. India’s entrepreneurs have excelled at recognizing potential and scaling it. The challenge now is to invent the future, making India a land of opportunity creation. If government, industry, and academia align, the next generation of billionaires will design chips, launch satellites, and discover new medicines. India’s destiny will be shaped not by what lies beneath its land, but by what thrives within its labs.

title: Ankur Warikoo's killer career advice can make you irreplaceable at work
content:
For years, workplace wisdom has been obsessed with the idea of being "the best." There's immense pressurere to become the top coder, top marketer, top designer, or top something.

But Ankur Warikoo — entrepreneur, educator and one of India’s most followed career voices — argues that chasing perfection in a single lane is old advice in a new world.

His viral LinkedIn post lays it out plainly: "Your career doesn’t have to depend on one big talent."

advertisement

Instead, he says the fastest-growing professionals are the ones building a mix of skills that makes them impossible to swap out.

This idea isn’t about becoming superhuman. It’s about becoming interesting — the kind of person employers remember, rely on and reward.

A NEW KIND OF CAREER PLAYBOOK

Warikoo’s post begins with the myth many of us inherit early: that growth depends on mastering one skill better than anyone else. The classic "be the best at coding" or "be the best at sales."

But as he writes on his slide deck, "this is the most limiting way to look at your career."

Being world-class at one skill still works for a small number of people. But most professionals are competing in crowded markets. When everyone around you can code, design, crunch numbers or manage accounts, simply being good at your core skill stops being enough.

So what makes someone irreplaceable?

THE MAGIC OF SKILL INTERSECTIONS

Warikoo says there are two ways to truly stand out:

Be in the top 1–5% at one skill. Or be in the top 20% at a few skills that rarely overlap.

The second is where most people win. As he puts it: "When skills intersect, your uniqueness becomes your edge."

Think of it this way:

A designer who can also run experiments.

A finance analyst who can write clearly.

A teacher who understands storytelling.

A coder who can speak to customers.

Each individual skill might be "average-plus," but the combination is rare, and rarity is power.

WARIKOO’S THREE-LAYER FORMULA

The heart of his framework is simple and surprisingly actionable. He calls it building your edge through three layers:

1. The anchor skill: The skill you’re already known for. Your base.

2. The adjacent skill: Something that naturally expands your value — a skill that supports the anchor.

3. The creative amplifier: A skill that changes how you think, injects fresh ideas, and gives your work a spark.

This is where most careers transform. A reliable professional becomes an original one. Someone who solves problems differently. Someone others turn to.

HIS OWN CAREER IS THE PROOF

Warikoo even uses himself as an example.

advertisement

“I’m not the best teacher not the best speaker not the biggest social media creator not the best leader,” he says.

He’s simply good at many things that work beautifully together — teaching, public speaking, simplifying ideas, and leading teams.

The result is a career that looks nothing like anyone else’s.

That’s the point. You become irreplaceable when your skill mix is hard to copy.

WHY THIS MATTERS IN THE AGE OF AI

One of the strongest lines from his post is: “Which new skill makes me harder to replace?”

That question reshapes everything about upskilling in this age of AI-induced layoffs.

Instead of chasing whatever tool is trending — Python today, prompt engineering tomorrow, something else next year — the focus shifts to strategic stacking.

A human who can:

think critically

understand context

connect ideas

communicate in a way machines can’t

immediately becomes more valuable than someone relying on a single technical skill.

THE SUM IS STRONGER THAN THE PARTS

Warikoo ends with a line that captures the beauty of this idea:

“The sum of your ‘average’ skills can be your strongest advantage.”

This is freeing for anyone who has ever felt “not the best” at anything. Most careers aren’t built by out-performing everyone at one thing. They’re shaped by weaving together skills most people never think to combine.

advertisement

A small crossover can open an entirely new door, and a few crossovers can change a life.

THE TAKEAWAY

Warikoo’s final advice is almost poetic: "Anchor deep. Expand wide. Be positively unpredictable."

You don’t need to outshine everyone. Your skills just need to out-combine them.

And in a world where jobs, tools, and skill demands change faster than ever, the professionals who blend, and not only specialise blindly, are the ones who stay one step ahead.

They’re not just good. They’re irreplaceable.

- Ends

title: Mumbai court grants bail to doctor in ex-Maharashtra Deputy CM pension case
content:
A Mumbai Sessions Court has granted anticipatory bail to cardiologist Dr Lekha Ramrao Adik-Pathak in connection with an alleged pension fraud case involving the family of former Maharashtra Deputy Chief Minister and Congress leader Ramrao Adik.

The case stemmed from an FIR registered in March this year by the Marine Drive Police Station following a complaint by the late leader's son, Prithviraj Adik. The complaint alleged that after Ramrao Adik's death in 2007 at the age of 78, Dr Lekha, who had lived with him in a relationship since 1995, began receiving his pension as his 'widow' despite never being legally married to him.

advertisement

Following the FIR, the 79-year-old cardiologist sought anticipatory bail on charges including cheating, forgery, and criminal breach of trust under the Indian Penal Code.

Dr Lekha's counsel, Aabad Ponda, argued that the dispute was primarily a civil matter over family pension, previously addressed by the Bombay High Court, which allowed parties to pursue civil remedies. Ponda claimed the criminal proceedings were maliciously initiated to harass and defame her. Citing her advanced age, ill health, clean record, and cooperation with authorities, he contended that arrest would cause irreparable harm.

Dr Lekha maintained that she married Ramrao Adik in 1995 following his divorce from his first wife, Shobha, in 1989. She cited a High Court proceeding in which Prithviraj's mother allegedly accepted her status as Ramrao Adik's wife.

Prithviraj Adik, however, opposed the plea. His lawyer, Eknath Sawant, submitted that Ramrao Adik and Shobha remained legally married from 1948 until Shobha's death in 2022. He described Dr Lekha's so-called divorce document as fabricated, executed on a three-year-old stamp paper without notarization or witnesses, and argued that she had no legal proof of marriage.

After hearing both sides, Sessions Judge Avinash P Kulkarni noted that the case largely concerned civil aspects of pension entitlement and that there was no evidence of criminal intent on Dr Lekha's part. Considering her age, health, clean record, and willingness to cooperate, the court granted her anticipatory bail, stressing that civil disputes should not result in unnecessary criminal harassment.

Dr Lekha was released on bail after executing a PR bond of Rs 15,000 with one surety. She is required to report to the Marine Drive Police Station every Tuesday for the next three months or until the filing of the chargesheet.

- Ends

title: Court orders framing of charges against NCP leader in money laundering case
content:
A special court under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA) on Thursday rejected a discharge application filed by Malik Infrastructure, one of the accused entities in the money-laundering case involving former Maharashtra minister and NCP leader Nawab Malik. The court has directed that charges be framed against all accused, including Malik, on November 18, and ordered their presence in court.

advertisement

Malik Infrastructure had argued that the Enforcement Directorate’s case was based on “surmises and conjectures,” claiming the company did not exist when the alleged illegal act occurred. Special Judge Satyanarayan R Navander, however, held that there was prima facie evidence to proceed. The court observed that Nawab Malik, in connivance with D-Company members Haseena Parkar, Salim Patel and accused Sardar Khan, participated in laundering illegally usurped property, which it said constituted proceeds of crime.

Meanwhile, Malik sought an adjournment and a six-week deferment of the charge-framing process, saying he was awaiting the outcome of a criminal writ petition before the Bombay High Court. His lawyer, Taraq Sayed, argued that the ED had withheld seized documents that were favourable to the defence and that the prosecution had suppressed material beneficial to Malik. He contended that if all seized documents were produced, there would be no basis to frame charges.

Special Public Prosecutor Sunil Gonsalves opposed the request, stating that the High Court had issued no stay order. The court agreed with the ED’s submission, noting that both the Supreme Court and the High Court have directed that cases involving MPs and MLAs be expedited. It said that without a stay, it could not defer the proceedings, and therefore rejected Malik’s application.

Malik was arrested by the ED in February 2022. The agency later filed its prosecution complaint under Sections 3, 4 and 70 of the PMLA, following which the court issued process in May 2022 against Malik, another accused individual, and two of his companies. The matter has been pending framing of charges since then, with the trial effectively on hold due to the discharge plea filed by one of the companies.

The ED alleges that Malik laundered proceeds of crime amounting to 16 crore and illegally occupied a three-acre plot of prime land in Mumbai’s Kurla area. According to the agency, he acquired the land using forged documents and with the help of underworld don Dawood Ibrahim’s late sister, Haseena Parkar.

- Ends

title: Air pollution's hidden fallout: The rise of diabetes risk
content:
Toxic air is affecting your lungs. No rewards for guessing that.

But did you know that it also has an impact on your heart? It has been linked to dementia as well.

But what about the impact of dirty air on our metabolic health? And the link with diabetes?

Experts now say that the risk of diabetes increases if the patient lives in a highly polluted region.

advertisement

"It is rather unusual because we always associate air pollution with respiratory disease, either upper respiratory diseases like coughs, allergies etc or lower respiratory diseases like infections including bronchitis, tuberculosis and even lung cancer," says Dr V Mohan, diabetologist and the founder of Dr. Mohan's Diabetes Specialties' Centre.

However, from the lungs they can easily get into the blood and once enter into the blood, they can damage many other organs. In the case of diabetes, air pollution causes diabetes through several mechanisms. There is increased inflammation and chronic inflammation has been linked to metabolic disorders including type 2 diabetes.

THE OXIDATIVE STRESS LINK

Air pollution also causes oxidative stress, a cause of diabetes. Research has identified oxidative stress as one potential feature underlying the toxic effect of air pollutants, which trigger a number of redox sensitive signalling pathways, such as those of inflammatory response and cytokine production. Oxidative stress leads to diabetes.

"Pollution can also directly affect the pancreatic beta cells leading to decreased insulin secretion, leading to diabetes," adds Dr Mohan.

IMPACT ON ORGANS

Air pollution affects all organs, including the liver and pancreas, increasing insulin resistance.

"Due to air pollution people may not walk and would be confined indoors which means the physical activity comes down and this can also lead to increase in weight leading to diabetes," says Dr Mohan.

THE HYPERTENSION LINK

In addition to diabetes, air pollution is also linked to high blood pressure (hypertension), hypercholesteremia and other lipid disorders and once it increases the risk of diabetes, hypertension and dyslipidaemia (high cholesterol), it can also increase the risk of heart attacks.

There is emerging evidence that air pollution is linked to various forms of cancer.

INDIA THE DIABETES CAPITAL OF THE WORLD, AIR POLLUTION TO BE BLAMED?

Experts say that not just in urban India, but also in rural India, cases of diabetes is increasing and that there is a clear air pollution link to this.

However, there are other factors at play.

"It is difficult to disentangle it from other causes of diabetes, example obesity rates are going up in rural India, physical activity is going down and people are getting more affluent and therefore, they are also eating more of junk foods, high in calories, sugar, carbohydrates and fat. All of these can contribute to the rising incidence and prevalence of diabetes in rural India," says Dr Mohan.

advertisement

A new dashboard launched by Climate Trends and IIT-Delhi shows how air pollution impacts public health, from diabetes among women to respiratory infections in children.

The findings highlight how a 30% reduction in PM2.5 levels could drastically improve health outcomes across the country.

The Health Benefit Assessment dashboard reveals a 30% drop in PM2.5 could lower the nationwide disease prevalence from 4.8% to 3%.

For women, diabetes rates could fall from 1.7% to 1.4% overall, with the most significant reductions (8–25%) seen in Delhi, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Assam and Haryana.

Dr. Mohan explains that the connection between air pollution and diabetes is becoming increasingly clear as more data accumulates.

“When we look at the prevalence of diabetes in areas where there is more air pollution, we are seeing a correlation with increasing rates of diabetes,” he says. Researchers are now finding that polluted air doesn’t just affect the lungs — it may also interfere with the body’s metabolism.

There is also basic research being done more in animals where the effect of various pollutants, for example particulate matter 2.5 (PM2.5), has been shown to have a toxic effect on various tissues, disturbing the metabolism.

advertisement

To strengthen this evidence, scientists are not just looking at pollution levels at one point in time. They are following people over many years.

“Longitudinal studies looking at air pollution have been able to track the incidence of new-onset diabetes in various populations. Our group at the Madras Diabetes Research Foundation along with scientists from the Centre for Chronic Diseases (CCDC) in New Delhi have shown this link in the CARRS study,” Dr. Mohan notes.

With newer tools in the growing field of Geohealth, researchers can now map pollution levels more precisely. By using GPS-based geocoding, they can link the air quality of specific neighbourhoods to the metabolic health of the people living there.

“It is also possible to measure both outdoor air pollution as well as indoor air pollution and look at metabolic health. All these research studies are pointing in the same direction, showing the impact of air pollution on metabolic health,” Dr. Mohan says.

- Ends

Published By: Daphne Clarance Published On: Nov 14, 2025

title: Toxic air surge in Delhi-NCR leaves residents fatigued, say doctors
content:
As Delhi-NCR grapples with a continued spell of hazardous air quality, doctors across specialties are reporting a surge in complaints of fatigue, lethargy, poor sleep and overall drop in energy levels.

Health experts warn that escalating pollution levels are not only harming the lungs but also draining the body’s ability to function optimally.

Over the last several weeks, almost all areas in Delhi and adjoining areas have been registering air quality index (AQI) levels ranging from ‘poor’ to ‘hazardous’ category with chief pollutants – PM2.5 and PM10 – reaching over 100 times the ‘safe limits’ set by the World Health Organisation.

advertisement

PM2.5, in particular, is highly toxic and can penetrate deep into lungs, can easily reach the bloodstream and its build-up in the body following prolonged exposure has been linked with several serious conditions including metabolic and cardiovascular diseases, neurological issues and even cancers.

LESS OXYGEN MEANS HIGH LETHARGY

Dr Kuldeep Kumar Grover, critical care and pulmonology head at CK Birla Hospital, Gurugram, said prolonged exposure to polluted air directly impacts oxygen intake.

“When we breathe polluted air, the body gets less oxygen, which can make us feel lethargic," he said.

The fine dust and chemicals in the air also cause irritation or soreness, which affects how well our body and mind function. Over time, this can lead to constant fatigue, headaches, and even poor sleep, making people feel drained through the day.

Internal medicine specialists say the mechanism behind this exhaustion is well established.

Dr RR Dutta, head, Internal Medicine at Paras Health, explained that inhaling pollutants like PM2.5, PM10, nitrogen dioxide and carbon monoxide interfere with oxygen supply.

“This means that even though a person is breathing normally, less oxygen actually reaches the bloodstream and organs. As a result, the body has to work harder to maintain basic energy levels, which can make people feel constantly tired or sluggish,” he noted.

Additionally, inflammation and oxidative stress triggered by pollution reduce alertness, muscle efficiency and concentration.

“Many people also experience disturbed sleep or shortness of breath due to high pollution levels, which further adds to fatigue,” Dr Dutta said.

Pulmonologists warn that toxic air could also be worsening both acute and chronic respiratory issues.

According to Dr Shailesh Jain, pulmonologist and chest physician at Saifee Hospital, the health impact depends on exposure, immunity and underlying conditions.

“Poor air quality can increase the vulnerability to respiratory infections and also exacerbate chronic conditions like asthma, bronchitis, and other lung diseases," Jain also said.

Prolonged exposure to poor air can also cause increased morbidity and frequent hospitalisation among children, older adults, and persons with previous medical conditions.

advertisement

The harm reduction measures may include the use of masks, indoor air purifiers and expanding urban green spaces.

These easy, yet efficient, measures will go a long way in safeguarding communities from the increasing risks of air pollution, experts suggest.

ADVERSE EFFECT ALSO ON SLEEP QUALITY

Family medicine experts emphasise that the impact extends to the brain and overall mood.

Dr Almas Pathan of Ruby Hall Clinic, Pune, said polluted air disrupts oxygen supply and induces constant inflammation.

“This means your immune system is always fighting the effect of these toxins, and this drains all your energy,” she said.

She added that pollution also interferes with neurotransmitters as large amounts of pollutants can alter neurotransmitter activities, especially those featuring serotonin and dopamine, which act on mood and motivation.

This is why people complain about mental cloudiness, aggravation, and lack of productivity due to poor air quality.

Sleep quality takes a hit as well. “Air pollution may cause irritation of the nose and throat, resulting in snoring, night coughing, or troubled breathing. In the long run, this leads to chronic fatigue and even insomnia,” Dr Pathan further said.

As Delhi-NCR’s pollution crisis deepens, the burden of fatigue may become yet another silent but significant public health concern this winter.

title: 40 lakh diabetics at high risk of blindness. New guidelines demand AI-enabled screening across India
content:
India has issued revised guidelines to confront the rapidly growing threat of diabetic retinopathy, recommending the widespread use of easy-to-operate AI-enabled retinal imaging across primary health centres to ensure early detection.

Released by the Right to Sight-India in collaboration with leading ophthalmologists and supported by the All India Ophthalmological Society (AIOS), the updated guidelines arrive a decade after the previous version and propose introduction of mandatory annual retinal screening for every person living with diabetes.

advertisement

Diabetic retinopathy, caused by damage to the retina’s tiny blood vessels, can affect anyone with type 1 or type 2 diabetes, with risk escalating over time and with poor blood sugar control.

Once the disease reaches an advanced stage, vision loss is typically irreversible.

India currently has an estimated 10.1 crore people with diabetes, of whom about 1.26 crore are believed to have eye-related complications and nearly 40 lakh face the danger of irreversible blindness.

The new recommendations aim to transform diabetic eye care by creating a technology-enabled, system-wide pathway to boost screening coverage to 80 % of the diabetic population.

At present, 85 % of diabetics in India are unaware that their condition can impair vision and have never undergone a retinal check.

According to Dr Vishali Gupta, president of the Vitreo Retinal Society of India (VRSI), the revised guidelines signal a strategic shift toward early, systematic detection.

She noted that timely intervention can reduce the risk of severe vision loss by half.

Dr R. Kim, chief medical officer, Aravind Eye Hospital added that although cataract and glaucoma were once the predominant causes of blindness in India, diabetes-related eye disease is emerging as a major concern.

SILENT BUT SERIOUS THREAT

Diabetic retinopathy often advances silently, causing no symptoms initially. Over time, persistent high blood sugar damages small blood vessels, leading to leakage, swelling and blurred vision that can rapidly progress to blindness.

Despite improvements in diabetes care, major gaps continue in identifying and managing the condition across the country, prompting the revised 2025 guidelines to address issues such as weak integration with non-communicable disease (NCD) programmes, inadequate monitoring, limited awareness and underuse of AI-based tools.

The updated framework proposes a tiered pathway for diagnosis and treatment.

CHANGES NEEDED IN SCREENING, TREATMENT

At the primary level, AI-enabled fundus imaging is recommended for early screening. Secondary centres are advised to adopt Optical Coherence Tomography, the most sensitive tool for detecting diabetic macular edema.

Tertiary facilities should have access to advanced imaging, including wide-field systems and other specialised assessment technologies.

The guidelines also recommend including essential treatments—such as lasers, anti-VEGF therapy and bispecific IVI injections—under Ayushman Bharat Pradhan Mantri Jan Aarogya Yojana to reduce financial barriers.

advertisement

Additionally, experts urged the creation of national diabetes and diabetic retinopathy registries to enable real-time surveillance and informed policy development.

These guidelines, said Dr Vishal Agarwal, member, VRSI, could mark a turning point in India’s fight against this vision threatening disease.

“By integrating technology, policy, and preventive care, they bring us closer to ensuring that no individual loses vision to a preventable cause because vision is not a luxury – it is fundamental to one’s independence, dignity, and quality of life.”

- Ends

title: Why smog is giving more Indians a headache — literally
content:
Coughing, sneezing, watering eyes, and a slight pinch in the throat - these are common problems most people face during the smog. But the thick, grey blanket of smog settles over Indian cities each winter, also brings with it a stubborn headache that refuses to leave.

Doctors say these pollution-linked headaches are more than just seasonal discomfort, they’re a sign of how deeply toxic air is beginning to affect the body.

advertisement

“The pollutants swirling in the air, like nitrogen dioxide, carbon monoxide, sulphur dioxide and PM2.5, don’t simply irritate the lungs. They irritate the respiratory tract and cause inflammation, which can lead to vascular changes in the brain and activate pain-sensitive nerves," says Dr. Neetu Jain, senior consultant in pulmonology, critical care and sleep medicine at PSRI Hospital.

There is also the matter of oxygen. When the air is dirty, the body has to work harder to pull in the oxygen it needs. “Inhaling polluted air reduces oxygen supply, causing blood vessels in the brain to dilate, resulting in a dull, persistent headache,” says Jain.

For people who already battle migraines or sinus issues, smog becomes an instant trigger.

NOT YOUR USUAL 'STRESS HEADACHE'

These aren’t the familiar tension headaches people get after a long day at a screen. Those are typically linked to stress, eye strain or poor posture and feel like a tight band wrapped around the head.

Pollution headaches, Dr. Jain says, are a different beast. Pollution-related headaches are more inflammatory and vascular in nature.

"They tend to throb or weigh heavily on the temples, forehead or behind the eyes," she adds.

They also come with other smog-related symptoms: watery eyes, a blocked nose, or a sense of heaviness in the face. They often appear only after a stretch of time outdoors — disappearing once the person moves to cleaner air.

SO WHAT CAN PEOPLE DO?

With air quality in cities frequently dipping into the "severe" zone, these headaches are increasingly difficult to escape. Dr. Jain says the first step is not heroic, it’s practical.

“The first step is to minimise exposure — wear an N95 mask outdoors, use air purifiers indoors, and avoid peak pollution hours,” she says. It’s also important to stay hydrated, because dehydration can make the pain sharper.

Some low-tech remedies still help. A saline nasal rinse may help clear pollutants from nasal passages.

Over-the-counter painkillers can provide short-term relief, but persistent headaches should not be brushed aside.

If headaches are frequent or severe, a neurological evaluation is advised to rule out underlying causes. Those with a history of migraines need to be particularly careful.

A WARNING SIGNAL WE CAN’T AFFORD TO IGNORE

advertisement

Pollution-linked headaches have become a quiet barometer of the country’s worsening air. They are the body’s early alarm — signalling that what we breathe is now capable of triggering inflammation, reducing oxygen, and affecting the brain.

As winter smog becomes an annual fixture, doctors say the only sustainable solution is cleaner air.

But until then, understanding these headaches and how to shield ourselves from them is be one of the few defences ordinary people have left.

- Ends

title: Fact Check: Is Pak Army mobilising troops after Delhi terror attack? Viral video is OLD
content:
The Centre assured Indians on November 12 that the perpetrators and sponsors of the terror attack near the Red Fort would be brought to justice swiftly. According to news reports, Pakistan-based outfits Jaish-e-Mohammad and Ansar Ghazwat-ul-Hind may be linked to the terror module that was nabbed in Faridabad the morning of the attack.

Now, a five-second-long video of a train carrying military tanks is being widely shared online. Allegedly, it shows the Pakistan army mobilising its troops from Balochistan to the Indian border, fearing retaliation from India.

advertisement

Sharing the video on X, one user wrote, “Fearing Indian retaliation after the Delhi Blast, Pakistan Army is moving troops, Arms and ammunition from Balochistan to the Indian border. With PoK, Balochistan will also get freedom.”

India Today Fact Check, however, found that the video clip has been online since as early as April, and is therefore not related to the terror attack in Delhi.

OUR PROBE

Reverse-searching a screenshot from the video led us to the same clip shared on TikTok. We checked the date of upload, which said April 26 this year. This proves that the video far precedes the November 10 terror attack in Delhi.

We then reviewed the profile “mrbeast66” that shared the video on TikTok. On the account, we found several posts geotagged to United King, Karachi, a bakery shop in Karachi’s Badar Commercial Street.

Additionally, the video of the train shared by “mrbeast66” includes hashtags like “pak fooj zindabad” and “pakistan zindabad”. Based on these details, it’s likely that this video is from Pakistan.

That being said, we were unable to determine the exact location of the video, or where the train’s destination was. Notably, however, April 25 was right in the aftermath of the Pahalgam terror attack. India would go on to retaliate against Pakistan with Operation Sindoor in May.

Thus, it is evident that while the video of the train carrying military tanks is likely from Pakistan, it predates the Delhi terror attack by several months — making the two things unrelated.

(Written by Aryama Bhattacharjee)
